PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BJELKE-PETERSEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 166 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-A petition has been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethinic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under Federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwalth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the Government's statement relating to the airlines and the statement that the Government has decided to establish Trans-Australia Airlines as a public company. What does that mean?

—A public company, as I understand it, is one created for the purposes of having public participation. The detailed definition is something which I think I should refer to the Minister and obtain an answer for Senator Button.

—Mr President, I ask the Minister a supplementary question. If the Minister is not able to explain what it means-for example, Qantas Airways Ltd is a public company and many public companies are listed on the stock exchanges-why did the Government make this decision if there can be no explanation of it?

—I would have thought Senator Button understood that the term 'public company' had a very broad meaning and in fact had several different interpretations. Consequently, in this context I believe it is a question for the Minister and I will refer it to him and obtain a reply.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface it by saying that I am one of those who believe this country should follow such energetic countries as Hong Kong and Switzerland and establish a tax rate that is constant no matter what income a person works toward because I believe the present tax rates do remove incentive. Is the Minister able to say how much money would be lost to the Treasury if the maximum tax rate were reduced from the present 60c in the dollar to 50c in the dollar, something that would be at least a step in the direction of an even tax rate? If the Minister is not able to let me know the exact amount at this stage from his notes, I would be grateful if, when he can, he would also advise the percentage loss to revenue of such a reduction. Finally, will the Minister advise the Treasurer that many senators and members do believe that a flat tax rate is possible and that the proposition should be examined again in discussions leading up to the Budget?

—As to the actual quantum of money that would be lost to revenue by the reduction of the ceiling from 60c to 50c I am not able to say, but I will invite the Treasurer to give me the information for Senator Townley and indeed, to express it in the percentages which Senator Townley seeks. As to the final part of Senator Townley's question, the Government has made it quite clear that it opposes the concept of a flat tax. It believes that a progressive tax scale is the equitable one. The Government, of course, is striving to reduce the impact of all taxation upon the community. That can only come about either by reducing the size of government spending-and that implies both State and Federal government spending because the States absorb 39.87 per cent of personal income tax revenue-or by cutting functions. The Government is very keen that there should be the maximum restraint on Commonwealth and State government spending. I have no doubt that that will be a matter heavily before the governments in their future meetings at Premiers Conferences.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Has the Chairman of Trans-Australia Airlines, Sir Robert Law-Smith, this morning been reported to have said that if TAA becomes a public company it should immediately shut down its Fokker Friendship services? Did he say that closure of these services would enable TAA to increase its profitability? What plans therefore does the Government have to see that should closure of these services, which are almost exclusively for country areas, take place, TAA will be able to increase its profit? In that event, what plans does the Government have to maintain services to these affected country areas?
—I have not seen any report along these lines attributed to Sir Robert Law-Smith or anybody else. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Transport and obtain an early reply.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that under the Administrative Arrangements Order issued by the Governor-General and the Prime Minister the Minister for Transport administers the Department of Transport? Under whose authority was the name of that Department changed to Transport Australia? Is it not a fact that documents have been overprinted showing 'Department of' in fine print over 'Transport Australia' in large letters? Will the Minister request the Auditor-General to conduct an inquiry into the cost of this overprinting and retitling of the Department and report the cost of this to the Parliament? Finally, will the Prime Minister ensure that departments describe themselves correctly as laid down in the Administrative Arrangements Orders?

—I believe it is a fact that the Administrative Arrangements Orders state as Senator MacGibbon says. I am aware that a subtitle, or what is in modern terms a logo or a logo title, 'Transport Australia', has been developed. I am able to say that it has been developed with the full authority and support of the Minister concerned because I have heard him say exactly that. I am unable to say what the cost is. I will seek that information and let Senator MacGibbon know.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Was there any move on the part of the public servants in the Department of Transport to create a statutory authority rather than a department by this action?

—The answer is emphatically no. Basically I think what was sought was a logo type of title which could identify the Commonwealth role in transport as distinct from the role of the six States and some territorial roles. My understanding-I am subject to correction by the responsible Minister-is that what was sought was a simple phrase which on vehicles or letter heads identify the Commonwealth or Australian authority for transport as distinct from these individual State authorities. I will refer the general question to the Minister concerned, and if he desires to add anything further, including anything on the question of costs, I will let the honourable senator know.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEDICAL BENEFITS SCHEDULE: COSMETIC SURGERY EXCLUSION

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health refers to the Government's decision applicable as from yesterday to exclude from the medical benefits schedule items covering so-called cosmetic surgery. Is the Minister aware that in many cases the implementation of this ruling from yesterday is likely to have a severe retrospective effect as several patients about to undergo operations such as breast augmentation have already purchased the surgical implants, prostheses, at considerable expense. As they were legally entitled to claim medical benefits at the time they purchased the implants, will the Government consider delaying the effect of the ruling until, say, 1 May next?

QUESTION.PARA: Are cosmetic surgery items to be removed only from the schedule of medical benefits or from the hospital benefits schedule as well? Does the Minister realise that a seemingly cosmetic operation often results in a marked improvement in the psychological health of the patient? How does the Minister propose to draw the line between purely medical and purely cosmetic surgery in cases such as these? Will the Minister add a rider to the decision stating that medical benefits will still be payable in surgical cases where the reduction or removal of psychological trauma is involved?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is correct that a number of procedures have been affected in the way that Senator Chipp has generally averted to. From my own professional knowledge I can indicate to the Senate that there are occasions when some of these operations are medically indicated. There is no argument about that. Reduction mammaplasty would be the obvious example. This is something I would have to check but it is my understanding that the Minister did not rule out the payment of benefits where particular medical indications exist. It is very hard to put, say, face-lift operations in that kind of category.
—No, it is not.

—Senator Coleman has disagreed. I still say it is difficult to put such operations into that category. Senator Chipp really asked whether they are only transitional arrangements to cover people in particular circumstances. I think that is a perfectly reasonable proposition which I will transmit to the Minister for Health. I will try to get an early answer for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In the first sitting week this year I asked about the press announcement of the Minister for Transport on 10 February that Adeliade Airport would be upgraded to receive international flights. Has the Minister for Transport provided a reply to the particular parts of that question?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided me with some information in connection with the questions asked about this matter by Senator Teague and also, I believe, Senators Young and Bishop. The Minister is aware of proposals by some international airlines to operate services to Adelaide Airport. I understand there have been discussions between the South Australian Government and some international airline operators on this matter. However, to date, the Minister has received no formal approach from any international airline for the implementation of such a service. In the event that an application is made he will give it very careful consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the provision of facilities at the Adelaide Airport, including a new terminal, is currently being considered by the Department of Transport. When that consideration is complete, the Minister will place the submission before the Government.

Senator Teague also referred to the runways at Adelaide Airport. The Minister has advised me that the main runway has sufficient length, width and strength to enable an international aircraft such as Boeing 747 or a DC10 to fly to destinations such as Perth or Sydney, although with a somewhat less than maximum payload. However, the runway is not long enough to enable those aircraft to fly directly to such destinations as Tokyo or Honolulu. Let me assure honourable senators of the Government's firm intention to see that the people of South Australia receive the benefits of international air services to Adelaide. The Government will strive to see that this is done as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Could the Minister indicate which recommendation of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares suggested the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Transport and obtain an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce and relates to the settlement of the 35-hour week dispute at the Altona petrochemical complex in Victoria. Can the Minister tell the Senate what the unions agreed the workers would do in return for the negotiated shorter working hours? Can the Minister also tell us the value in money terms of each part of the agreement in improved productivity to the companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator has raised a question about the terms of settlement of the Altona dispute. My advice is that the terms of settlement are contained in an agreement between the unions and the six companies concerned. It is a very long and complicated document which covers in detail work practices and arrangements at each company. This morning I am not able to detail to the honourable senator the terms of settlement and the productivity gains. However, I will refer the question to the Minister for Industrial Relations to provide a detailed answer. The honourable senator would be aware that the Commonwealth intervened before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to oppose the Altona settlement. When the matter had been dealt with, my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations issued a statement on 24 March. In noting the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission ratifying the agreement for reduced hours the Minister said:

ANSWER.PARA: I must accept the decision of the Commission. Nevertheless it is disgraceful that the form of industrial pressure used by the unions concerned at the complex over such a long period of time has now brought about a settlement so costly to the public interest.
The Government intervened in this hearing and strongly argued against the settlement. It continues its opposition to the productivity bargaining concept in its application to reduce working hours.

Although I am unable to give the precise detail, and I think that a considerable amount of detail is required to answer the honourable senator's question, I make it quite clear that the Government is opposed to the concept in its application to reduce working hours. I think that it must be quite clear now that the Government is determined in the national interest to do what it can to prevent the campaign for a shorter working week succeeding. We believe that it will do great damage to our economy and to employment in this country. Accordingly, we will continue to take the sorts of steps that have been outlined over the last few weeks, primarily by the Minister for Industrial Relations, to resist this trend, which is not in the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his various capacities as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, and also Minister assisting the Treasurer. I ask: Is it true that two deals currently being negotiated between the Government and Mr Rupert Murdoch relate to the sale of Trans-Australia Airlines and the amendment of the Broadcasting and Television Act to enable Mr Murdoch to retain control of Channel 10 Melbourne? Could the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government is involved currently in any other negotiations with Mr Murdoch? Could he also indicate whether the Government is involved currently in any negotiations with Sir Peter Abeles? In the light of that gentleman's presence in the chamber last night, in ministerial company, could the Minister also indicate whether the Government is currently engaged in any negotiations with Mr Robert Holmes a'Court?

—I have no information whatever on the matters raised by Senator Evans. I will refer those matters to the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs and obtain an early reply.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, although I believe that it may also come under other portfolios. Is the Government aware of the recent failure of the suit of the Unification Church-sometimes known as the Moonies-in the United Kingdom, the longest in the legal history of that country, against the London Daily Mail and that the Church was consequently ordered to pay costs estimated to be in the order of $A1.5m? Has he been informed that this suit was a result of an article accusing the Moonies of brainwashing converts and breaking up families? Is he also aware that the jury said that the tax-free charitable status of the Unification Church in Britain should be investigated by the United Kingdom Board of Inland Revenue on the grounds that it is a political organisation? As this organisation has been operating in Australia since about 1973 and as senators and members have had their attention drawn to the fact that families have been broken due to the conversion of young people to this sect, will the Government initiate inquiries to establish whether similar practices are being employed by Moonies in Australia? I have a copy of the full text of telex on this subject. Would the Minister like to have a copy of it to provide him with further details?

—I have read the Press reports of the overseas jury decision-to reject a suit by the Unification Church for defamation in the form of an allegation by a newspaper that the Church was brainwashing people and breaking up families. I am aware of the huge costs awarded against the institution in that case. I was not aware of the details regarding its tax-free charitable concessions. I will look at that matter in terms of Australia. I will bring to the attention of the relevant Ministers that part of the question which related to the operation of the Church in Australia. I will invite the Government to undertake a similar study. I would certainly welcome a copy of the telex. I will investigate the matter. I am unaware whether the Treasury provides any tax-free concessions for the institution in Australia. I will find out.

—Mr President, my question is addressed to you. What statements have you made to the Senate or to committees of the Senate within each of the last three years about accommodation for the Parliamentary Library in Parliament House and other parliamentary buildings? When were those statements made? What assurances were contained in those statements to the effect that the Parliament would be consulted prior to the making of decisions on accommodation? Have those assurances been honoured? If not, for what reasons?

—I shall look into the matters contained in the question asked by Senator McAuliffe. I shall check on the statements that have been made in the Senate and actions which have been taken and will report back to him.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the October Federal election campaign the Prime Minister announced that the Government is to introduce full tax deductibility for the costs of the insulation of a person's first home, to become effective from the date of delivery of the proposal. As the proposal was made more than five months ago, I ask the Minister: How much longer will new home owners need to wait for its implementation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question referred to full tax deductibility. That would apply in the year of income dated from the date of the proposal, but I would need to check that with the Treasurer. If people are unclear as to the statement perhaps some comment could be made on that, but it would be unlikely that people are having tax assessments dealt with at present, prior to the end of the year of income.
—It was on the insulation of homes.
— I will see that some statement is made to make the proposal clear as to when the concession is applied.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. After Question Time yesterday Senator Messner indicated that a previous answer given to me to the effect that the imported material KTCP did not contain dioxin was wrong and that it was likely that this material basic to the preparation of 2,4,5-T did contain dioxin. In the course of that statement Senator Messner said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . I had been advised that the imported material known as KTCP did not contain dioxin. That was my understanding of the conversation that I had with Dr Hall of the Australian National University.

On whose initiative did such conversation take place? Did Dr Hall state that he had no knowledge of the matter as he was a statistician? Did Dr Hall refer the Minister to a chemist to obtain the necessary information? Will the Minister affirm the professional integrity of Dr Hall in this matter and remove any suspicion that Dr Hall had misled the Minister and had gone outside the sphere of his scientific competence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Addressing my remarks to the last part of Senator Tate's question, I would be perfectly happy to relieve Dr Hall of any feelings that he may have had his name besmirched in this regard at all. In fact, the purpose of my making the statement yesterday was to draw the Senate's attention to the fact that my original statement was unconfirmed. I stated that in the original answer. In fact, it was as a result of confirming facts yesterday that I made the statement at the end of Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly, there is no intention at all to draw attention to Dr Hall's situation. Rather, in fact, I thought the conversation we had on that day was very interesting and certainly important from the point of view of providing information to the Parliament. In no way did I seek to besmirch Dr Hall's professional integrity. If he requires a statement to that effect in writing I would be happy to provide one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I asked whether Dr Hall stated that he could not give an answer as to the presence of dioxin in KTCP because he was a statistician. I further asked whether Dr Hall referred the Minister to a chemist. Did the Minister, in fact, take up that further reference to a chemist? With whom did he consult before he gave a wrong answer to the Senate as to the presence of dioxin in that material?
—Yes, I did check with a chemist.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction forecast a reduction in the waiting period prior to recipients receiving homes savings grants? Currently nine months elapse between the time of application and the receipt of funds. I seek this reduction as in my State of Tasmania the Government gives a stamp duty relief which cannot be calculated until the grant is made and, further, the delay can mean that the recipient has to take out costly bridging finance.
—I will need to refer that matter to the responsible Minister and obtain an early reply.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. In view of the fact that Australian National Railways-I emphasise the word 'Railways' so that there is no confusion with shipping, airlines, mental health, industries or many other bodies with the preface 'Australian National'-has savagely increased freight charges, particularly charges for small parcels and sundry goods to country areas in South Australia, how can the Minister justify a payment of $409,000 to the image consultancy firm of Pieter Huveneers of Milsons Point, New South Wales, just to recommend the change of name from Australian National Railways to Australian National?
—It will probably come as no surprise to Senator McLaren that I have no information on the subject. I will refer the question to the Minister for Transport and obtain a reply.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Senator Messner has just told us that he has no information; but on Tuesday I received from him an answer to a question upon notice setting out in detail the amount of money which the Government has paid to Pieter Huveneers, Corporate Positioning and Identification, of Milsons Point, New South Wales. Senator Messner now tells me he has no information on the matter; yet he provided me with an answer on Tuesday.

—I thought Senator McLaren was trying to draw the implication that there was some kind of connection between the money spent on consultants' fees and the matter mentioned earlier. Consequently I intend to seek information for him on the other matter.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Did the Treasurer on 24 September 1978 state that the Government intended to legislate against blatant tax avoidance schemes including recoupment-type devices? Is the Minister aware that the tax avoidance industry is currently marketing on a large scale throughout Australia a recoupment-type tax avoidance scheme whereby the taxpayer obtains an offset against his tax for moneys invested in an afforestation company but in circumstances where the taxpayer is reimbursed all of his investment less the scheme's seller's fee by means of a combination of loans and dealings in shares of the afforestation company? Is it a fact that under this type of arrangement the taxpayer obtains the tax benefit but at no time is he at financial risk? Will the Treasurer investigate this type of scheme in accordance with his statement of 1978 and take action accordingly to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether the precise date of the Treasurer's statement is as stated. I am aware of statements made by the Treasurer with regard to legislation that would be used to combat tax avoidance schemes. Senator Douglas McClelland has asked me whether I will ask the Treasurer to investigate the scheme the honourable senator has outlined. I will do so and seek a comment from the Treasurer. I also make the general comment that the Treasurer, following his announcements from time to time on tax avoidance schemes, has taken action to minimise the avoidance of tax in this country. I think honourable senators are aware of the further statement he has made concerning action that he intends to take through legislation. I will ask for the Treasurer's comment on the afforestation scheme which has been outlined.

—My question is devoted to the Minister representing the Prime Minister whose responsibility covers the Auditor-General's Office. I refer to reports that Mr Bruce Gyngell is to resign his $59,000-a-year job as a consultant to the Special Broadcasting Service. Can the Minister give the Senate an assurance that this decision is in no way related to the fact that the Auditor-General is currently investigating expenditure incurred by Mr Gyngell?

—I have no knowledge of the circumstances of Mr Gyngell's intended resignation. I read in the paper of his intention. I do not believe there would be any such connection. My knowledge of Mr Gyngell over the years is that he is a very honourable man who has made a considerable contribution to this country. I will look at the matter and ask the Treasurer, who I think is responsible for such matters, to ascertain the nature of the matters being looked at by the Auditor-General. I will seek a response for Senator Walsh.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister confirm that certain expenditures incurred by Mr Gyngell are being investigated by the Auditor-General?

—I have no reason to know whether that is a fact. If the Auditor-General's report is available to Senator Walsh he will be able to identify the circumstances. I will take the question on board with the former question and seek information.

—Mr President, I direct a question to you and refer to the normal work sheet for the Senate which today is more or less a working book. Is the fact that the work sheet is now being printed in Parliament House a result of the printers' strike? Can you inform the Senate of the latest position regarding the printers' strike, particularly in relation to the workings of this Parliament?

—Yesterday I made a statement in respect of the disability under which we are operating at the moment as a result of a strike by members of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union. I indicated then that the 24-hour strike which began yesterday morning would lead to a delay of a day-today's Hansard will be out tomorrow, and so on. I have no information further to that which I had yesterday in respect of this matter. For the time being we are producing for the convenience of honourable senators the document I am holding up, but no printing of daily matter is being done at this time by the Government Printing Office.

—Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate say yesterday that Mr Laurie Power of the Government Information Unit does not act as his Press secretary and does not engage in partisan political activity? If that is so, how does Senator Carrick explain the Press statement headed 'Labor's petrol price policy confusing and contradictory' which was released in his name on 11 February last year? Are journalists invited at the end of the statement to refer any inquiries regarding that partisan political statement to Mr Laurie Power at either his home or Senator Carrick's office, and are telephone numbers provided?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say yesterday that Mr Power is not my Press officer. That is perfectly true.
—You also said he only reports Cabinet decisions.

—Thank God I do not have to depend on Senator Walsh to answer my questions for me, because such answers would be wrong in substance. However, I did say that, and I did say that he acts as a Government Information Unit officer to put out such things. In fact what I said yesterday was that if one looks at the Press statements that are handed out by me, one will see that they come from here but that one or two had come from Mr Power.
—You did not say that. That is a total invention. Come on now! Get out the Hansard and read us that bit.

—I suggest that that is quite unnecessarily offensive. That fact is that I said that Laurie Power from time to time makes statements which are part of government business-that is his job-and had made a number of statements in my name in that regard. That is in Hansard and is not a total invention. While we are talking about these matters, yesterday at Question Time I was asked by Senator Button about a number of matters concerning junior Ministers in the Fraser Government. During that reply Senator Grimes interjected on a number of occasions to the effect that both Mr Newman and Mr Hodgman, two Tasmanian Ministers, had Press officers. I verified the accuracy of that matter, and I took steps to check the situation.

ANSWER.PARA: As we are talking about invention, I can assure the Senate that, as I stated yesterday, neither Mr Newman nor Mr Hodgman has a Press officer. They have never had Press officers, contrary to Senator Grimes's interjections yesterday. I am advised that Mr Bruce Montgomery, the Government Information Unit officer for Tasmania, is no longer located in Mr Newman's office in Launceston. He is located in the Commonwealth Government Centre in Hobart. In that location I understand Mr Montgomery will be closer to the new offices that Senator Grimes plans to take two floors below in the Commonwealth building than he will be to Mr Hodgman. The information which I gave the Senate yesterday is correct. My clear instruction on political matters to the Government information officer is that his job is to pursue Government information and not party political matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you call that? Have you read it?
—Order! Cease interjecting, Senator Walsh.

—As the matter relates basically to a statement by Senator Button that the Government is spending considerably more money on the employment of officers for the Ministry and for the Government, I wish to make it perfectly clear that the number of ministerial staff of all kinds, including press officers, is some 48 fewer for this Government than it was for the Whitlam Government. The Government exercises a great economy of staff, compared with the Whitlam Government. The Whitlam Government openly and notoriously used its ministerial staff and its Press officers for propaganda purposes. In other words, we have been far more economical. It is a fact that no Minister in the Senate employs a Press officer. Ministers in the Senate, as do Ministers in other places, use Government information officers, who are in each of the States, to carry out certain duties, and the carrying out of those duties is an economical way of discharging a role which was wastefully performed by the Whitlam Government.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of the semantics of the Minister's recent answer, has he seen the poster displaying ministerial telephone numbers issued by the Department of Administrative Services and which is available to all senators? Does it list under the staff of Senator Carrick, a Mr Laurie Power, who is described as a State co-ordination officer? Does it also list Mr A. Verbickis on the staff of Mr Lynch, Mr Ferris on the staff of Mr Killen, Mr Kessell on the staff of Mr Viner, Mr Montgomery on the staff of Mr Newman, and Mr Dunlevy on the staff of Senator Messner? Are these officers all employed by the Government Information Unit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said yesterday that there is a Government Information Unit and that in each State that office comes under the supervision of the senior Minister of that State. I indicated yesterday that Mr Laurie Power comes under my supervision in his role as a government information officer, and he is located in my suite. That statement is in the Hansard of yesterday, and it is as plain as can be. I do not know whether it is listed as such. Of course, if one wanted to locate Mr Laurie Power one would look towards my suite of offices and would find him there. Nevertheless, he is in no way a ministerial Press officer; he is a government information officer for the totality of government.
—He puts out political propaganda.
—Mr President, let me simply say--
—Senator Walsh, I will warn you again for interjecting. Cease interjecting completely.
—Well, stop him telling lies.
—Mr President, did I hear him say: 'Stop him telling lies'?
—I did not hear that.
—I did.
—Senator Walsh, will withdraw. The honourable senator heard that interjection. Withdraw immediately.
—Righto, I withdraw, subject to the usual conditions.
—You will withdraw subject to nothing. Withdraw.
—Righto.
—You will speak decently. Say 'I withdraw' not 'righto'.
—Oh, yeah, okay. I withdraw.
—Senator Walsh, I name you for persistent rejection of the authority of the Chair.
—Oh, come on, you are being ridiculous.
—Senator Walsh, I have named you.
—Mr President, in accordance with the procedures under the Standing Orders, you having named the honourable senator, I ask him to rise in his place to give an explanation to the Senate.
—Prior to Senator Walsh's doing that, we again have witnessed an extraordinary incident here. Senator Carrick thought he heard Senator Walsh say something and you did not hear it.
—I heard it.
—Of course, all you people can stand up and give evidence about it if you want.
—Let him now say that he did not say it.
—Senator Walsh made no allegation that Senator Carrick was telling lies. He said: 'Stop him telling lies'.
—What is the difference?

—Seriously, that is something which should be prevented at all times. With respect, I think the incident has got a little out of hand at this stage when Senator Walsh is named after that extraordinary beginning to the complaint which was made.
—I call Senator Walsh.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Carrick has asserted today that Mr Power deals only with government business. The matter which Senator Button has raised is a Press statement which refers inquiries to Mr Laurie Power, giving telephone numbers both at work and at home-and at home-on the stationery of the Minister for National Development and Energy; so presumably it is with Senator Carrick's knowledge and approval. That statement reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: Each new policy statement of Labor's Energy spokesman, Mr Keating is contradictory and utterly confusing.

His most recent statement in the Sunday Times, Perth, that a Federal Labor Government would freeze the price of petrol in its first year is a sign of further frenzy, no doubt inspired by the West Australian election.
Only a few days ago Mr Keating outlined Labor's policy in an in-depth interview with the Sydney Morning Herald.

He indicated then that Labor would not reduce the price of petrol as he had previously promised. On attaining office it would retain the pre-existing price and adjust it upwards according to variations in either the C.P.I. or import parity pricing whichever was the lesser.
He went on to reveal that Labor's proposed Resources Tax would yield more revenue than the existing levy.
Mr Keating has shown that petrol under Labor would be dearer not cheaper.

I interpolate to say that not only is that sentence which I have just read out a highly political statement-nothing to do with government business-but also it is objectively wrong. It is not only a political assertion but also a political assertion which is false. I continue to quote from the statement:
Since the Resources Tax would be imposed upon the oil producer, it must have the effect of stopping exploration.
Labor's oil policy must lead to dearer petrol and dry bowsers.

The statement is dated 11 February 1980 and it has the words 'Inquiries: Laurie Power' and gives both the work and home telephone numbers. I submit that the statement can by no stretch of the imagination be claimed to be a report of government policy. That is a blatantly political statement which contains false assertion as well as a political assertion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, I have heard enough in this way. The fact is that I have named you for wilfully disobeying my direction to you to withdraw.
—I did withdraw; the record will show that.

—I named you because of the manner in which you were replying. You knew you were trying to be funny in the matter, by saying 'okay' and that sort of thing, and that is why I named you. You will restrict your explanation to why you disregarded wilfully a direction from the Chair to do certain things, and that is the whole point.
—I withdrew, Mr President. I know what the rules here are, that is, that the test of acceptability is not truth; the test of acceptability is the Standing Orders.
—Order!
—If the test of acceptability were truth--
—Order! That is a gross reflection on the conduct of this place, the institution of parliament.

—Well, it is a statement of fact. The Standing Orders do not say anything about whether a statement has to be true. So the question just does not arise. It may be a reflection on the Standing Orders relating to the conduct of this place, but it is a statement of fact.
—I call Senator Carrick.

—Mr President, I have always said in this place when I have had no other alternative-when you have named a senator and I have suggested that the senator stand in his place and explain himself and apologise-the senator should do so, so that there is no need to take the next step. The fact is that there are two separate situations to this. One is the senator's behaviour towards the Chair for which he is in the process of being named. The other is the allegation that I have in fact given incorrect information. They are two quite separate issues.

ANSWER.PARA: I am perfectly prepared to pursue the matter. I ask that it not be necessary for me to do so. The simple answer is for Senator Walsh to apologise for his offence to the Chair. If he does that there will be no need to pursue the matter further under the Standing Orders. I would be very happy if that were to occur. Then, if the Senate wishes to pursue the matter relating to the Australian Information Unit I am perfectly happy for that to occur. I invite Senator Walsh so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for any disrespect to the Chair, Mr President. I am quite happy to pursue the matter of whether Senator Carrick gave misleading information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. By way of introduction I remind the Minister of a question I asked him last year when the Carter Administration was closing down the United States of America Consulate in Brisbane and I sought Australian Government assistance to dissuade the United States Administration from following that course of action. Now that a new and more enlightened Administration is in power in the United States, will the Australian Government use its influence to ensure that the Consulate is re-established? Not only are there about 10,000 American citizens in Queensland and the Northern Territory, but also this year the demand for consular services in Queensland has increased considerably-probably doubled as the new Qantas Airways Ltd service from the west coast of the United States to Townsville and Brisbane will bring in many thousands of tourists each year, to say nothing of the staging arrangements for B52s in Darwin and their crews.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will consult the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek his opinion on the desirability of the early establishment of a United States consulate in Queensland. I will ensure that Senator MacGibbon is kept informed of any developments on that matter that may arise.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Social Security, who will recall that on 11 March I asked a question in relation to delays in processing applications for invalid pensions in Queensland. In view of the distress that those delays are causing invalid pension applicants, has the Minister examined the delays? If so, what steps are being taken to overcome the problem?

—Following Senator Colston's asking his earlier question on that matter I referred it to my Department. As yet I have had no response on the matter. As I indicated previously in the Senate, there have been some difficulties with respect to invalid pensions, particularly in dealing with appeals. I was not aware of the difficulty raised by the honourable senator on 11 March. I am still awaiting a response from my Department on that. I will ask for the response to be expedited and try to get the honourable senator a reply today. I apologise for the delay.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I draw the Minister's attention to the Auditor-General's most recent report and its reference to the Special Broadcasting Service. Is the Minister aware that the report draws attention to expenditure in excess of that approved and also to expenditure incurred by people without authority to do so? Are those expenditures related directly to the operation of Channel 0-28? If so, can the Minister indicate the Government's intention in relation to multilingual and multicultural broadcasting and television? Will the Government increase the budget for the Special Broadcasting Service to meet those situations?

—Like other senators, I have seen the Auditor-General's recent report. As the honourable senator would know better than most, it is a very substantial document covering a whole range of departments. Therefore I have not directed my mind to the pages to which the honourable senator referred, namely, those dealing with the Special Broadcasting Service. I am unable to tell him whether references to excess expenditure or expenditures incurred without authority do in fact relate to Channel 0 and Channel 28. I will undertake to get that information for the honourable senator and will come back to him on it as quickly as I can. Regarding the Government's intentions, I understand that on a number of occasions our position has been set out publicly by means of Government statements and, indeed, the introduction of legislation. I understand that the honourable senator would want to know what the Government's intentions are in the light of its consideration of further material which has come forward, including Senate committee reports. I will undertake to have that looked at as well by my colleague.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HERCULES AIRCRAFT: TRANSPORT OF PROCESSED URANIUM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. Has Queensland Mines Ltd asked the Federal Government to make available a Hercules aircraft to fly processed uranium out of Australia? To what destination is the material to be flown? Has the Government made a decision on this matter? If it has not, when will this decision be made?
—I am not aware of any such activity. I will ask the responsible Minister and seek further information.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ARABIC NEWSPAPERS IN AUSTRALIA: RECRUITMENT OF MERCENARIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I remind him of questions I asked some time ago in the Senate regarding alleged advertisements appearing in Arabic language newspapers in Australia purporting to recruit foreign mercenaries for service in Libya. The Attorney-General indicated that he was undertaking further investigations of those allegations. I ask whether he has further information to give to the Senate on the matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Puplick asked me a question along those lines, as did Senator Elstob, on the same day or about the same time. No investigations into the matter had been made at that time. I am pleased to report there has been an investigation into the advertisements which did appear in Arabic language newspapers inviting applications to join one of several military academies in Libya. The Senate will be aware that under Australian law passed by this Parliament, namely, the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978, the publication of advertisements for the purpose of recruiting persons to serve in any capacity in an armed force in a foreign country is prohibited. Of course, the Government takes seriously any infringement of that law.

ANSWER.PARA: On 27 March 1981 representatives from the Department of Foreign Affairs discussed the matter with the Secretary of the Libyan People's Bureau. That is the form in which the Libyan Government is now represented in Australia. It has turned the Libyan Embassy into the People's Bureau. The Secretary of the Bureau said that the advertisement was placed by the Libyan Embassy in the Arabic papers before the Embassy had been transformed into the People's Bureau and that he had no knowledge of the advertisement prior to the recent Press publicity. He undertook that the Bureau would not do anything to help in the recruitment of persons in Australia for military training in Libya. The attention of the Secretary was drawn to the provisions of Australian law regulating these matters. He undertook that the advertisement would not be repeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. In view of the stress by both the Tertiary Education Commission and the Schools Commission in their recent reports on adapting education and curricula to the needs of the 1980s, what role does the Government see for the Curriculum Development Centre in this task? Is the Centre well placed to give a lead in devising curricula which have regard not only to traditional educational needs but also to the economic and employment conditions consequent upon resource development?

—The Curriculum Development Centre is only one of a range of curricula development activities. Basically each State has its own curriculum development institutions. Schools themselves have internal development of curricula, as of course do independent and State schools. The great bulk of curricula development is done widely throughout Australia. The CDC is an instrument set up between the Commonwealth and the States to supplement those activities. I have not had the privilege to read the latest Tertiary Education Commission and Schools Commissions reports. Therefore, I cannot say what particular emphasis is given in those reports. My understanding from Press reports is that in the latest Schools Commission report there has been a much greater emphasis on the need for basic skills. Of course, that has been an assertion of this Government since it came to office.

—Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs undertake to review the conditions concerning the maximum amount of income which recipients of veterans' pensions are able to earn annually without endangering the level of their pension payments? Many veterans who are still able and willing to work, even if only part time, are restricted due to the present income limit.
—This is a Budget matter, of course. I will undertake to review it, as Senator Kilgariff suggests, and bring down a reply for him later.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CABINET MINISTERS: DISCLOSURE OF PECUNIARY INTERESTS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It refers to Ministers' pecuniary interests and follows a question asked yesterday by Senator Primmer. In the Minister's response he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a well-accepted universal practice for a Minister, when a discussion is taking place in Cabinet on a particular matter, to indicate to Cabinet any pecuniary interest that he or his family may have. This is done and is accepted as being done.
Did the Deputy Prime Minister or any other Minister, at any stage before or during the recent talks on the broadcasting and television legislation indicate to Cabinet his interest in that matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I said that, since this Government was formed, there has to be a personal statement by way of confidential letter to the Prime Minister setting out pecuniary interests. I said also that it was a common practice for Ministers, before taking part in Cabinet discussions, to indicate whether they had a special interest. I think the question was raised yesterday about communications. From memory, I said that I had no recollection one way or another whether anyone had done so. I think that the question today is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, as distinct from Mr Sinclair. I cannot say whether that situation is so; nor in the ordinary protocol of government could I say because, as Senator Bishop, being a former Minister, would know, all Cabinet discussions are completely confidential. I can only assure him that it is our practice to follow that practice, and I hope that we will continue it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and concerns the problems epileptics have in securing life assurance. Is the Minister aware of certain difficulties that people suffering from epilepsy currently face in taking out life assurance policies? Will the Minister investigate the problems faced by these unfortunate Australians?

—I am aware that life assurance companies often load policies, based on actuarial experience in relation to certain kinds of illness and disability. I am also aware that the prospects for people suffering from various kinds of epilepsy have altered markedly over the last few decades with modern forms of medication and other treatment for epilepsy. It is my understanding that the outlook for most epileptics now is very good in terms of living a normal life and participating normally in society. I will undertake to refer to my colleague the question asked by the honourable senator. It may be that one needs to re-examine the actuarial basis on which decisions have been made in this area in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Did the Department of Transport carry out a comprehensive examination of Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines known as the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review? Did that review say that it had been impossible to determine the effect on the level of fares of non-airlines activities by Ansett or TAA? It is also true that the Holcroft committee in its recent report complained about the lack of co-operation by Ansett in the committee's inquiries into domestic air fares? Given the loss of millions of dollars by Associated Securities Ltd, a subsidiary company of Ansett, will the Government establish immediately an inquiry into the non-airline activities of these two companies? Does the Minister believe that the privileged position occupied by the two companies entitles the Government to ensure that air travellers are not propping up risky business ventures which have nothing to do with the running of an airline?

—I am aware that the Domestic Air Transport Policy Review was carried out some two years ago and that the report was handed down to the Government. I have no immediate information on the matters raised by Senator Sibraa. I think the subsidiary companies of Ansett have been the subject of questions from Senator Sibraa on previous occasions. I am still endeavouring to obtain information in that regard. I will do so and obtain a reply for him soon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several weeks ago both Senator Lewis and Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, questions concerning the employment of academic staff in Australian universities. I indicated that I would seek the information they required. I understand that the paper referred to by Senator Lewis is entitled 'Academic Staffing: The Research for Excellence'. Australian universities are autonomous institutions responsible for their own academic affairs, including the selection and appointment of staff. They aim to develop and maintain the highest standards of academic excellence. Consistent with this, their appointments procedures for filling academic positions are designed to select the best available qualified persons.

ANSWER.PARA: Most academic positions are advertised both within Australia and overseas. Applications for each position are considerd by an appointments committee which is appointed by the university governing body. It comprises members of the academic staff and, in many cases, other members from outside the universities-either from another university or the wider community. The appointments committee obtains referees' reports on the applicants and then interviews those who are placed on the short list. If the appointments committee considers that none of the applicants has the necessary qualifications and experience, it will leave the position unfilled rather than appoint a person who is not of the desired calibre. Also, universities always reserve the right to fill any position by invitation to ensure that a person of the highest academic quality is appointed. Unless the appointment committee has been given delegated authority to make the final appointment, the university governing body must ratify each appointment recommended by appointments committees before it becomes effective.

If statistics show that universities employ few female academic staff, or a disproportionate number with overseas qualifications, this is not evidence of discrimination against females or Australians. Indeed, it indicates that the female applicants have not been assessed as being the best available applicants for the positions and that applicants with overseas qualifications have been assessed as being the best available for the positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my earlier reply to a question from Senator Young in respect of the printing of Hansard and other Parliamentary publications, I have been advised that the Government Printing Office is operative today but that overtime bans are in force. Tuesday's Hansard will be delivered today, yesterday's Hansard will be delivered tomorrow and today's Hansard will be available on Monday.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Dame MARGARET GUILFOYLE

TALK.START.PARA: — On 1 April Senator Robertson asked for confirmation that a decision has been made to open a consulate in Bali. I refer the honourable senator to the answer that I gave to his question on this matter on 12 March. I stated:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . because of the consular pressures arising from the increasing numbers of Australians visiting Bali and the shortcomings inherent in trying to provide a satisfactory level of consular assistance from Jakarta, the Government is currently giving further consideration to the early opening of a consulate in Bali.

I confirmed today that there has been no change since I gave that answer in March. The letter referred to in the article quoted by the honourable senator repeated that the Government is giving further consideration to the early opening of a consulate, but I am not able to make any announcement with regard to it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MESSNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Tate asked me a question with regard to war service in Vietnam, in particular in relation to naval staff serving on HMAS Sydney. I now have some further information on the matter which may help him. Veterans who were allotted special duty for service in a special area are eligible to be considered for repatriation benefits under the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. Qualifying service is conceded to persons who, while members of the forces, served on special service and were allotted for special duty in a special area as prescribed. In respect of the Vietnam conflict, a person had to be allotted for service in South Vietnam or in waters within 100 nautical miles of Vietnam. Special duty is defined as duty relating directly to warlike operations or a state of disturbance which resulted in an area being declared a special area. Land areas were proclaimed special areas from 31 July 1967 while coastal waters were proclaimed from 1 March 1967.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Department of Defence was responsible for deciding those persons who were allotted in special areas. In the case of HMAS Sydney it is understood that the crew members of that ship were not allotted for special duty. Eligibility can also be conceded to a person who was not allotted for special duty but who was incapacitated or died as a result of action by hostile forces in an area outside Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat to the unemployment payments for the under-18 unemployed, and the failure of the Government to provide comprehensive youth employment and youth support policies.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues and I on this side of the chamber again raise the matter of youth unemployment in this country and the problems facing the young unemployed. We are spurred to do so at this time by the kite-flying exercise which has been conducted by senior Ministers such as the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and others plus many Government back benchers. I refer to the proposal to restrict unemployment benefit for those under the age of 18 years. The belief apparently is that these people are best cared for by their families.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe the unemployed are carrying an unjust share of the burden of this Government's restrictive policies. Within the ranks of the unemployed the hardship is unequally shared between the generations, with three times as many teenagers being unemployed as adults. In the past the Government has blamed everyone in sight for that. The trade unions are attacked for protecting their members. The public is attacked for not spending enough. The families of the unemployed are attacked for not supporting them enough. The education system is blamed for not educating the unemployed enough. Mainly, the unemployed teenagers are being criticised for not getting up and magically finding work. Now we have the situation that repeated warnings have been issued by the senior Ministers I have mentioned-I am afraid that it may be less of a warning than foreshadowed legislation-that the out of work 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds are not only to be blamed for their plight but also are to be punished for being unable to find non-existent work by no longer being paid the unemployment benefit.

The Government has stated that the review of the unemployment benefit for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds will be completed by May. It seems to us that the Government may be saying that it hopes to have the justifications for this illogical and callous measure-one it hopes will save some $100m-by May so that the legislation can be introduced. About 60 per cent of school leavers go directly from school to some sort of job and an independent wage. Almost 25 per cent of school leavers go on to further education and a proportion of these receive payments under the National Employment and Training System or receive tertiary assistance. Our problem is that it is conservatively estimated that 15 per cent of these people cannot find work. In May 1980 the figures showed that 20 per cent of those who left the education system in 1979 still had not found a job.

The most recent figures by the Australian Bureau of Statistics which are for February 1981 show that 128,000 teenagers were unemployed of whom half were looking for their first job. The percentage of 15-year-olds to 19-year-olds unemployed was 18.7 per cent. In December and January the percentage of unemployed in that age group was over 20 per cent. The under 20-year-olds represented 30 per cent of those unemployed. The figures exclude any young person who may have been employed doing a couple of hours paid gardening or baby-sitting. If young people do more than an hour's work they miss out on being counted as unemployed in the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The figure of 18.7 per cent for the teenage unemployed will gradually reduce during the year to a hard core and unhappy 15 per cent. Teenage unemployment accounted for 12 per cent of unemployment when this Government came in and it has risen steadily in spite of every effort of the Government to fiddle the books. Who are the teenage unemployed? First and foremost they are people who, in spite of denigration from wealthy senior Ministers in the Government, want a job, stability, financial independence and a counter to the boredom and hopelessness of their present situation. Most Australians identify themselves according to the work they do. They do not have to make the painful admission that they have no job, work mates or weekly pay packet. Having made such an admission some retreat and others rebel. According to figures from the Department of Social Security, 32,500 teenagers aged 16 years and 17 years receive unemployment benefit. They represent 12 per cent of unemployment benificiaries. About 60 per cent of those have received benefits for more than three months which means that they have been out of work for five months at least. Their benefit is $36 a week. It is six years since it was last raised. In flying this kite that the unemployment benefit to the young 15, 16 and 17-year-olds may be removed the Prime Minister stated:
The present payment of unemployment benefits may act as a disincentive to continue in formal education or training or to seek work.

I will take the second point first. No young person in his or her right mind would choose a $36-a-week dole payment when average junior earning rates will give them three times that amount and far better future prospects. Some of the $36 is needed to travel to work interviews, the Commonwealth Employment Service and Department of Social Security offices. Some of the amount goes on board at home or elesewhere. All of the amount will go on surviving. There is no way in the world those kids unlucky enough to have to go from rural areas to the cities to seek work because of the high rural unemployment levels can enjoy life on $36 a week. If the Government succeeds in cutting off the unemployment benefit for the under-18-year-olds the secondary effect will be to increase the extent of hidden unemployment in the community. The young jobless will be reluctant to register with the CES with the odds heavily stacked against them, as they are. They will not show up on Social Security statistics. In one stroke the Government will have saved money and concealed the problem as it has tried to do consistently.

On the figures, there is no incentive to be unemployed; there is a strong incentive to accept work, even at junior rates. The incentive to continue with education is the same as it has always been-young people who want to do so have the opportunity to learn more, to mature further and to improve their employment prospects. There is little short term financial advantage in education as compared with work. Junior earning rates are more than twice as high as the over-18-years unemployment benefit or the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance. Unemployment benefit is not a disincentive to education. It is a payment which in the case of teenagers is picked up on the way from schooling to the finding of work. Lack of work is the root of the problem. All the phoney arguments from Government members about schooling versus unemployment benefit should not be allowed to disguise that vital point. The fact is that at the same time more young people are staying in school and more young people are unemployed. The paper presented by Mr Peter Kirby at the conference of youth in training on 23 February stated that between 1960 and 1970 the school participation rate of 15-year-olds rose by over one-third, from 57 per cent to 81 per cent, and that of 16-year-olds almost doubled from 28 per cent to 52 per cent. School retention rates are higher now than they were in 1975 while unemployment has in fact worsened. The school leavers of the 1970s and the 1980s have spent and will spend longer in school than their counterparts in the 1950s and the 1960s. But over the two decades of the 1950s and the 1960s demand for labour was so strong that a choice of jobs was virtually guaranteed for the yearly output of the expanding education system. But jobs themselves are missing now, let alone there being the choice to which Mr Kirby referred.

Of course it is the poorest, the least schooled and often the least capable who are at risk. They come last in the job race. They have the hardest time mastering the unemployment benefit system and they are the ones, I suggest, at whose collective head the Government is now pointing the gun. Their crime, it seems to some members of the Government, is that they have not found work when they have left school and they show up in the unemployment statistics. The Government sees them as an embarrassment and a financial drain and hopes to hide them, apparently by attempting to conscript them back into the education system. If the Government could be persuaded to look again at the problem it might be able to see these people as potential assets being wasted because there are no jobs, as unhappy young people who are often given little support by their families or society at large. I quote from a paper given by Mr Daryl Dixon, a well-known public servant in this country, from the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat to the youth in training conference. He said:

In leaving school and seeking employment a choice has been made in favour of independence-and if the community cannot find the employment he or she seeks then the community should bear the cost of maintaining that person until employment and independence is achieved.

It is no good the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs telling us or those young people that young people should not enter the labour market until they are properly equipped to enter or to obtain employment. The point is that until the 1970s there was employment for young people, people younger than the ones now leaving school, whether they were properly equipped. Now there is not. The position is further complicated by the fact that there is evidence that employers are taking advantage of an excess supply of applicants to shift apprenticeship recruitment to those with higher academic standards. This year, the State Electricity Commission in Victoria has taken on apprentices with the highest ever qualifications. So the less qualified kids have been left behind without jobs, without choice and increasingly without hope.

One of the factors militating against their employment in recent years has been the increasing practice of some employers to reduce their full time, unskilled and semi-skilled work force to take on teenagers on a part time or casual basis. The employer can often cut costs by paying below award rates and offering below award payments and, in fact, sometimes below award conditions. Between 1971 and 1980 males at school increased their share of part time teenage jobs from 39 per cent to 64 per cent and girls, from 28 per cent to 62 per cent. No one can blame them for taking these jobs. No one can blame them for taking advantage of these opportunities given to them but it has a severe effect on the older people seeking work after leaving school. The Government line, apparently, is that there should be for the under 18-year olds something better than the unemployment benefit and one cannot deny that this would be a good thing. There are certainly better ways of spending $106m than on the under 18 unemployment benefit. But the answer-and the answer seems to bother the Government-is that there should be work.

It seems to us that this Government is a job-eliminator, not a job creator. It is about to take a carving knife to its own Public Service, the Commonwealth labour force that usually translates a service to the public. Jobs carved out of the Public Service will be jobs unavailable for school leavers in the future. There has been no automatic response to this reduction in the Commonwealth Public Service in the private sector despite the predictions of the Prime Minister in this regard. In the present system, even with the benefits as inadequate as they are now, the wealthier families, the wealthier teenagers, will be able to survive. They will be able to swim while the less wealthy, the kids from large families, the kids from an increasing number of families with adults unemployed will have a hard time keeping afloat. Some will sink.

The Government, it repeatedly proclaims, has spent considerable time thinking of means of overcoming the problems facing the young unemployed. Yet it studiously ignores the possibilities of finding them work. It has greatly lauded its so-called transition to work and youth unemployment schemes. I think in a debate such as this, brief though it is, both of those schemes can bear closer examination. According to Senator Carrick, the school to work transition scheme, when it was introduced into this place, was to help young people who leave school every year with poor unemployment prospects. The bulk of the $22m in Commonwealth grants announced by the Minister for Education, Mr Fife, on 16 February last year is going to the education system as a topping-up of schemes already existing in schools. Curriculum development, teaching resources, career information services, link courses and evaluation, for which provisions have not been made in State Budgets, have been given the go-ahead. They are commendable and they are as valid in the school context as other educational subjects, but they have nothing to do with the provision of work.

In the last few years other payments have been devised which come under the heading of youth employment schemes, but as Mr Dixon, whom I quoted earlier, and others have pointed out, the numbers concerned in individual schemes are frequently small and some of the schemes are of short duration. The same percentage of gross domestic product-about 0.47 per cent-is being spent on all the schemes as was being spent in 1977, though unemployment is higher. Under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme there has been hardly any increase in the number of apprenticeships on an annual basis for the past three years. Fewer apprentices are now in training than in 1976 and 1977. Since 1977-78 there has been a drop in real terms in the Budget allocation for the Special Youth Employment Training Program, and the program itself represents a direct subsidy to the employer while he takes on a young person for what may or may not be training. There are no guarantees that those young people will receive work at the end of the training period, but it takes them off the unemployment list for some time; and in the Government's eyes that is a useful exercise.

The Education Program for Unemployed Youth, funds for which are now incorporated in the school to work transition allocation, is a worthy program but is small. The courses last for between six weeks and six months and have so far helped fewer than 5,000 people a year. The latest figures on teenage unemployment show 146,000 without work. A few weeks of EPUY training for 5,000 of them makes very little dent on the problem, while there are 149,000, or 29 in every 30 of those unemployed, for whom it appears to be irrelevant. The young participants in the Community Youth Support Scheme, like those undertaking EPUY training, remain in the registered unemployed tally, but the CYSS allocation has been cut in real terms recently, by 10 per cent in the last two years, and the numbers are down by some 23 per cent. This scheme will always have problems until its guidelines are re-evaluated and until we have a proper evaluation of the effectiveness of the whole scheme.

It seems that self-help programs are forbidden unless they conform exactly to the Government's determination to prove that there is no youth unemployment problem. The Government persists in being very reluctant to allow youth unemployment organisations operating under such schemes as CYSS to take positive initiatives or to receive any assistance to set up such programs. We have received continual complaints of the battle between the New South Wales Government and the present Federal Government to make funds available for those sorts of schemes.

Repeated studies which one cannot go into in any detail now, have examined the problems associated with the size of youth unemployment and the social problems which result from it-the problems of increased drug taking, homelessness, increased alcoholism and petty and even major crime. Yet the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs admitted that the Government does not even monitor the social consequences of youth unemployment. It does not monitor the health problems of youth unemployment, the evidence of drug taking and the suicide levels within this group.

The Minister, in answer to a question by me, stated that the findings of people who make such reports are generally inconclusive. It seems to us that the Government is in fact unwilling to look carefully at the problem, to find out the truth, to look at the documentation of people who have looked at the problem or to make its own investigations. It is unwilling to look at the problem in a reasonable way so that we can have a proper manpower planning program for young unemployed persons. We raise this problem because it exists and because we are fearful that the Government, in its efforts to cut expenditure and to maintain its own firm ideological one-sidedness which it has had for some time, will take an unwise step such as removing the unemployment benefit from the 16 and 17-year olds, and therefore will throw a great burden not only on these young people but also on their families. We are fearful that the Government is taking a half-hearted approach to the youth employment and training programs which exist. We are fearful that the Government, as always, will try to push this problem under the mat--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take part in this discussion of the matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to the unemployment payments for the under-18 unemployed, and the failure of the Government to provide comprehensive youth employment and youth support policies.

I hope that we enter into this discussion in a constructive manner. There could be nobody in this community who is not aware of the problems of unemployment and there surely would be no Australian who wants to see Australia advance-even if it were possible-with discontented and unemployed youth because the youth of this country will be the adults of the future. There can be no question that this Government would not be as greatly and sincerely concerned as any other association or government with the problems of unemployment in general and, particularly, youth unemployment.

Senator Grimes, who has just spoken for the Opposition, mentioned that there was a tendency by the Government to blame 16 and 17-year olds for their plight. That is a totally ridiculous statement. Of course they are not to be blamed for their plight, but the determination of the Government, rather than to blame them, is to identify the causes of that plight and to seek solutions to it. I hope in the few minutes at my disposal to indicate that we are sincerely concerned with the identification and solution of the problems of the unemployed, and particularly of unemployed youth.

Senator Grimes went on to mention that 30 per cent of the unemployed are in fact 20 years of age or under. That is indeed a sad circumstance but it is not as he appeared to portray it.
