It is not a totally unusual situation. Of course, the younger people are the ones who, consistently throughout history, are faced with unemployment problems because they are in that extraordinarily important transition stage. Having admitted that, it is our duty to find ways of overcoming those problems. Senator Grimes mentioned that people from rural areas were forced to go the the cities to find work. That occurs from time to time but I have observed that people from rural areas who seek work in metropolitan areas seem to find work very rapidly. I am not certain whether that is related to their determination to get a job but it certainly is a fact that they find work available in most of the cities around Australia.

Lack of work, Senator Grimes said, is the root of the problem. That is a very simplistic statement. Indeed, no one could disagree that lack of work is related to unemployment, but we in the Government believe that the ultimate long term answer to unemployment problems lies in the solution of the economic problems which confront this country. It is the solution of the socio-economic problems across the board that has concerned us so greatly. A little later I may have time to identify some of the efforts and some of the results of Government policy in this area. Of course, the economy holds the ultimate solution to the problem of unemployment in the long term.

Unemployment exists in Australia. Let me state briefly why that is so. It exists for two basic reasons. One reason is that it is a legacy which this Government has received. Without trying to identify the root causes of that legacy, let us remind ourselves that in 1975 when this Government came to office the unemployment level was in excess of 5 per cent. In 1972, when the Liberal and Country parties lost office, the unemployment level was 1.2 per cent. The legacy of unemployment had to be countered and controlled. The second reason is that employment was and has continued to be a world-wide problem. What is this unemployment due to? I suggest, because of the shortness of time available, just a couple of, in my view, obvious causes.

In the first place it was significantly due in a real sense to the wages explosion which was unaccompanied by any sort of massive or real productivity increase in the early and middle years of the decade of the 1970s. As a corollary of the wages explosion we saw a surge into the technological age. The development of the computer age in Australia, I believe, was accelerated by the wages explosion. The advance of sophisticated technology into our economy at a time when we were not fully and totally prepared to absorb it was one of the most significant causes of the unemployment problem which confronts Australians today.

Having said that, there is surely a real challenge to the Australian Government, and indeed to the Australian people. The first challenge is that we must take a measure of real responsibility in wage levels. The Australian trade unions, which have played a mighty fine part in the history of this country in many fields over many decades, have insisted totally in recent years on continuing wage rises without reference to productivity, to the capacity of an economy to pay and, I believe, to the need for younger people to move quickly into employment. Consequently we will have to observe in the future a real measure of restraint in the wage system so that amongst other things youth unemployed will have a greater opportunity to find a niche in the economy.

Another challenge that comes from the unemployment situation, a challenge that is well recognised-I believe the history of the Government's effort in the field of youth unemployment in particular is evidence of its understanding of this problem-is the problem of education. We have to fit an educational system to deliver people with the sorts of skills that our technological age requires. There are many important ways of attacking this problem. They are the constant concern of this Government, but it is not a situation, as anyone who thinks about it for a moment or two will realise, that can be solved overnight or indeed in less than a period of years. There is an enormous need to encourage a longer and more appropriate educational procedure. That is the very basis of the review that the Government is carrying out referable to young Australians between 16 and 18 years.

Among other deliberations that will come from this review will be the determination of a method of adapting the educational system to the requirements of the economy in which we find ourselves including the way of life or the social circumstances of all Australians. I often wonder how this sort of thing can be achieved. It may well be that our schools today should be looking at the last two or three years of education as a period that should be devoted more specifically to students identifying themselves with certain trades because it is clear that in this community we need skilled tradesmen across a whole range of areas. It may well be that two or three years of schooling in trades, for argument's sake, such as plumbing, electrical, carpentery, bricklaying or whatever and young people leaving school at the age of 17 or 18 years should go on to the technical and further educational institutions and after three, four or five years there become qualified tradesmen ready to take their place in the community. That might be a more simple and more direct method. It would be a method related to those that are applied virtually to all the professions which are taught at university level where one having completed his learning over the prescribed number of years comes out capable and ready to become a teacher, a doctor, an engineer, a dentist or whatever. It may well be that such a change to the educational system would make a significant contribution not only to the employment of young people but also to the productivity of the Australian people as a whole. Advantages are also to be gained from young people remaining somewhat longer at school than they normally do. A longer period at school does permit a greater measure of maturity and, many people think a greater measure of concentration and we should look at that suggestion only from that point of view.

I will mention only one or two sets of statistics because I think this sort of debate is concerned not so much with statistics as it is with the values that community holds, a real analysis of the causes of unemployment and the directions we must take to find the solutions. Total unemployment in Australia fell in the year to January 1981 by 7,400 people or 1.7 per cent of the work force. The full time unemployment rate in January 1981 was 5.7 per cent compared with 5.8 per cent one year earlier. I think it is also significant, relevant to this discussion, that the largest fall in full time unemployment rates over the last 12 months occurred in the teenage category-the 15 to 19-years-olds-where the drop was 1.4 per cent. I am not suggesting that we should throw our hats in the air and say hooray about those figures, but they do indicate that not only is there a real concern on the part of the Government in those areas of unemployment in particular but also it is achieving a measure of success.

Let me look very quickly at some of the programs and the progress made in them in the last 12 months. Two hundred and sixty thousand are to be assisted under the Commonwealth Government's manpower training and youth support programs for 1980-81 which is an increase of 40,000 people or 18 per cent more than in the previous year, 1979-80. The money allocated to the employment and youth affairs budget for the current year is $33m more than it was for the previous year. It now stands at the sum of $246m. The main reason for this increased expenditure and the increased number of people who will benefit is the added emphasis in the number of government schemes such as the National Employment and Training System, known as the NEAT Scheme, and the Special Youth Employment and Training Program, known as SYETP. This year some 75,000 people are being helped under SYETP. This scheme helps employers to take on and train young people who have difficulty in finding stable jobs because of a lack of experience or qualifications. From 1 February this year subsidies of up to $80 a week are available from employers of young people unemployed for eight out of 12 months. These young people would be in a serious position. This subsidy of $80 a week is available for 17 weeks and for a further 17 weeks a subsidy of $55 a week is available; a total of 34 weeks. This is a very significant contribution to the solution of unemployment in that category. Assistance available under the School to Work Transition Program has been raised to the unemployment benefit plus $6. The Education Program for Unemployed Youth will help some 13,500 young people this year to improve their employability prospects. The Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme, known as the CRAFT scheme, will involve no fewer than 80,000 young people in 1980-81 while an additional 50,000 will be assisted through the Community Youth Support Scheme.

As I said, I do not want to continue with a whole heap of statistics, but let me draw my remarks to a conclusion with one or two points that occur to me as being important. I do not want to see this unemployment situation, particularly as it refers to youth, become some sort of a political football. It is not something to be kicked around the place in an attempt to get some sort of emotional attraction from certain areas of the community. It is something to be recognised as a national problem which we all have an absolute responsibility to identify and to solve. We must come to grips with the problem. The solutions we are finding as time goes by are not the be-all and end-all but a continuing contribution. There is no straight-out stark threat to deny unemployment benefits to the teenagers in this country. The Government's determination is identified by the establishment of a committee by the Minister to review the circumstances pertaining to that group of people. It will determine in fact whether unemployment benefit is a disincentive to some people or is an opportunity, as it were, for them to get away from parental or teacher control. These matters will be examined with a view to overcoming the problems.

I remind the Senate that the economy holds the long term solution to the unemployment problem. The inflation rate is down to 9.2 per cent, the third lowest in the Western World. The growth rate in 1981 is up from 3 per cent or 4 per cent to 4 1/2 per cent. The resources boom offers exciting prospects. Finally, we must observe the problems and seek solutions, something which we are indeed doing with a real measure of success. There is responsibility on both sides. By generating pride and enthusiasm this country will overcome the problems that confront it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance submitted for discussion by my colleague Senator Don Grimes reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat to the unemployment payments for the under-18 unemployed, and the failure of the Government to provide comprehensive youth employment and youth support policies.

As the matter deals with unemployed youth I intend to outline, with reference to the State that I represent, the extent of the problem. The most recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released relate to unemployment in February this year. These figures were issued on 13 March. They indicated that in Queensland 15.5 per cent of those people aged 15 years to 19 years are unemployed. This is about two and a half times as high as the overall rate of unemployment in Queensland. I hold that the overall rate of unemployment for Queensland is totally unacceptable.

The fact that we have 15.5 per cent unemployment in Queensland for the age group 15 years to 19 years sometimes looks a little reasonable when compared with the figures for other States. Although Queensland has an unemployment rate above the national average the figures for this age group compare favourably with those of other States. Can one really say that to have 15.5 per cent of people within a particular age group unemployed is a favourable situation? I do believe not. I believe that it is unacceptable. What it really means is that many young people go to school for 10 or 12 years enthusiastic that when they leave school they will join the work force and take their rightful place in society, only to find when they leave school their prospects of entering that work force are extremely limited.

When I look at the figures for unemployed youth in Queensland and other States I am amazed that the figures evoke so little action. At this stage I would like to mention that the previous speaker, Senator Scott, suggested that the current unemployment levels were a legacy of the previous Government. He did not mention that Mr Fraser made a pledge in 1975 to provide jobs for all who wanted to work. Over five years have gone by and the unemployment figures, if anything, have increased.

I referred to the unemployment figures for juniors in the State I represent. I will indicate how bad the employment situation is in three of the 24 employment districts in Queensland. The latest Commonwealth Employment Service figures show that in the Rockhampton employment district 45 juniors were chasing every job listed as vacant by the Commonwealth Employment Service. In the Atherton employment district, in the northern part of my State, for every job listed as vacant for juniors 46 people were looking for a job. In the Maryborough employment district the position was even worse, fifty three juniors were chasing every job listed as vacant.

What do these people have to look forward to while they are waiting for a job to come along? We all know it has been nearly six years since there was an increase in the level of unemployment benefit for this age group. These people have to exist on $36 a week. The young unemployed have found it increasingly difficult to survive on $36 a week. However, the suggestion has been floated recently that it would not be a bad idea to cut out the unemployment benefit altogether for this group. What a novel situation this is; what a novel solution this is. If there were no unemployment benefit then there would be no arguments as to whether its level was appropriate or not. It is of no concern that these young people have to clothe themselves well in order to present themselves in the best possible light when they appear before a prospective employer. Apparently there is no concern that these young people have to find money for fares and telephone calls as they search for work. They need some unemployment benefit to be able to get out and seek work-work which is scarce and difficult for them to find.

What was the reason given for suggesting that perhaps unemployment benefit for this age group should be discontinued? The suggestion was that unemployment benefits may act as a disincentive for people to continue formal education or training or to seeking work. As my colleague Senator Grimes said, what young person in his or her right mind would opt to go on unemployment benefit at $36 a week when he or she could earn three times that amount if he or she gets a job. In relation to the argument that it might be a disincentive to get work I hear thousands of young people saying: 'What work?' How right they are. Most young people receiving unemployment benefit are unemployed because there are not enough jobs for them, not because they are stupid or lazy and not because the education system has failed them. There are simply not enough jobs. What the Government needs to do is to provide the stimulation which will create more jobs. If it simply drives youngsters back to school or retains them longer than it normally would the main effect will be to disguise the extent of unemployment in Australia and to produce a better educated and better qualified class of jobless young people.

I want to address my remarks to the second half of the matter of public importance raised by Senator Grimes. It concerns the failure of the Government to provide comprehensive youth employment and youth support policies. What programs are available in Australia at the moment? There are five major manpower programs. Only one of these really creates work. I am not being critical of these schemes themselves but I am critical of the lack of emphasis of work creation programs. The National Employment and Training System, or NEAT, as we often call it, concentrates on helping disadvantaged members of the work force to gain training and employment.

Perhaps that is a commendable aim, but it is not directed specifically at young people and it will not help young people get jobs. The Special Youth Employment Training Program is another program for young people. It pays a subsidy to employers to take on young people who have fulfilled certain conditions-they have to have been unemployed for a certain period- but there is no guarantee of permanent employment for these people.

Too often people have come to me and said that they have been taken on for a period under the Special Youth Employment Training Program, but at the end of their contract with the employer they are out of work. They are again seeking work and are back in the position they were in four months previously. This program may help for a certain period, it may give people some confidence for the little while that they are in work, but we do not have any real program to keep them in work once they have undertaken such a scheme.

Another scheme I wish to deal with is the Community Youth Support Scheme. One cannot say that that scheme helps young people to get jobs. It provides activities to keep unemployed youth occupied while they are looking for a job. That in itself is commendable, but it does not create the jobs we want for young people in Australia. The Education Program for Unemployed Youth, or EPUY, helps to provide some skills, but it does not create work. This program has directed itself mainly to providing literacy and numeracy skills for those who find it difficult to obtain work because of the lack of those skills. Again, within this framework, such a scheme does have some commendable aspects, but can we really expect that in six months or so we can provide young people with the necessary skills to go out into the work force if they have not developed those skills in 10 years at school? The real problem is that when these people go out looking for jobs, the jobs are not there. I refer now to the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training scheme, or CRAFT. I like the concept of this scheme. It could be quite useful in helping to provide jobs for youth. However, when we look at the number of apprentices in training at the moment, we find that there are fewer than there were three years ago. Something is wrong if CRAFT, whose aim is to provide apprenticeship opportunities, is not giving us the apprentices we need and if the number of apprentices in training is declining.

Last year, prior to the election campaign, the Australian Labor Party proposed a positive program to get young people working. We outlined a proposal for a community service corps which each year would create 50,000 jobs at the junior level. We outlined an apprenticeship scheme which would boost the apprentice intake by 20,000 a year. We also looked at the prospect of using the private sector to provide employment and training for young people. During that election campaign we outlined what we called a private sector employment and training scheme which would replace SYETP and employ 30,000 people in a full year. There is no reason why a resource-rich nation such as Australia cannot provide jobs for all young people.

I spoke last evening to a person who is not associated with this Parliament or with any particular political party. He put it to me that there are probably hundreds of thousands of jobs available in Australia for young people, and if we look around we will see that he is probably correct. He said: 'Why can we not put those people to work? Why do we have to be hidebound by a monetary policy that will prevent young people from entering occupations and taking up jobs just because the money is not available. Of all the resources we have in Australia, the monetary supply is probably the only man-made one, the only one we try to regulate, and at the moment we are regulating it in an inefficient way. He is probably correct. As I said, this person is not associated with a political party. He is not an economist or a person who usually looks at this area, but he is as concerned as I am about the lack of jobs for young people in Australia. He could see that if we used our initiative we might be able to ensure that those hundreds of thousands of jobs were available for young people. We should not, by doing nothing, create a system which breeds a generation of urban desperadoes. We must make sure that jobs are available for young people, and show them that we care about their future and are anxious that they take their rightful place in society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Colston and Senator Grimes, when speaking today, I believe quite deliberately misrepresented the Government's proposed review. Their approach to the problem of youth unemployment typified the way in which they attempt to exploit many of the serious issues. It is quite clear that they and many of their Australian Labor Party colleagues make a political football of the young. Some time ago the Australian Financial Review summed up the approach of the ALP spokesmen when it suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: There are more political points to be made by exploiting the fact of youth unemployment than trying to do anything about it.
It went on to suggest-

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't create youth unemployment.
—I will come to that point later, and we will see who created it. The statement in the Australian Financial Review went on:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is any issue on which calm reflection and a degree of bipartisanship is called for, it is the welfare and future of the young people of this Country.

We have not had that attitude in the debate in this chamber today. We have been told that the Labor Party did not create unemployment. Let me refer to its record. In 1974 we were told by the Labor Party, which was then in Government, that there was overemployment, to use the exact words, and it decided to do something about that situation. It was advised that its across the board tariff cuts would create unemployment, but it said: 'No worries. We have got overemployment!' The Labor Government fixed that situation in one year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the Labor Party, was it?

—It fixed that situation in one year. In January 1974 unemployment was 2.1 per cent of the work force. One year later, in January 1975, unemployment was 5.2 per cent of the work force. In other words, in one year the Labor Party fixed overemployment. In one year unemployment rose by 3.1 per cent, from 2.1 per cent to 5.2 per cent. The Labor Party fixed its problem of overemployment and created the worst unemployment this country had seen for several generations.
—Tell us about Maggie Thatcher.

—Opposition senators do not like what I am telling them. They say: 'Tell us about Margaret Thatcher'. What has Margaret Thatcher to do with their unemployment problem or, as it was described in 1974, their problem of overemployment? They created a problem that is now a legacy from the Government that we succeeded? When this Government came to office in 1975 Australia had an unemployment rate of 5.2 per cent. The latest month's figure available is 6.3 per cent. That is the lowest figure for that month we have seen for three years. What was the Labor Party's answer to its creation of that tremendous unemployment in one year? It decided to do something about it. It created the Regional Employment Development Scheme.
—Which you wrecked.

—The honourable senator said that the Government wrecked it. I have before me a statement made by the then Senator James McClelland. He said: 'No more money is to be given to the RED Scheme. It has to be phased out'. That was in 1975. Before this Government came to office Senator James McClelland said that the RED Scheme had to be phased out, yet the Labor Party is still trying to put across that we abandoned the RED Scheme. Never at any stage did this Government abandon the RED Scheme. The previous Labor Government introduced it and it abandoned it in 1975 before we came to office. Senator James McClelland stated that it was to be abandoned. That was the Labor Party's answer to the unemployment problem that it created in one year.

SPEECH.PARA: What is this Government's answer to the problem? I will come to that in a few moments. We have decided against introducing any band-aid system such as the RED Scheme. We have gone for permanent employment. Let us look at the employment figures obtained by the Bureau of Statistics in its labour force surveys. This Government was elected in December 1975. In August 1975, when the Labor Party was in power, employment dropped by 0.2 per cent in comparison with the previous 12 months. That was the legacy with which we were left when we came to office a couple of months later. Let us look at the figures for August 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it since then?

—I will tell Senator Gietzelt what we have done about it. In August last year, instead of a decrease in employment of 0.2 per cent, there was an increase of 3.4 per cent. Let us look at the figures. In August 1975, just before this Government came to office, employment fell by 0.2 per cent and last year there was an increase of 3.4 per cent. I do not think Senator Gietzelt should ask who created the situation. He knows darn well who created it. We have now achieved the best increase in employment that has occurred since 1970, or-I do not know the relevant figures-certainly before the Labor Government came to power.

SPEECH.PARA: By January 1981 total teenage employment had grown by 23,300-an increase of 3.4 per cent. Total teenage unemployment fell by 5,900-a decrease of 3.4 per cent. So the teenage employment problem is gradually being coped with. There is not a simple answer. I could quote many sources. I shall pick just a few. Professor Peter Karmel said:
. . . there are other factors which have conspired against job opportunities for the young. These include the high level of juvenile wage rates compared to adult rates, the level of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, here we go again.
—I am quoting Professor Karmel, who is the Chairman of the Tertiary Education Commission. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a significant number of young workers partly through lack of skills and partly through attitudes to work, the increasing participation of women in the workforce, the high level of costs of on-the-job training for young workers, and the changing job structure whereby the proportion of unskilled and semi-skilled jobs has been steadily falling. These structural factors all make employers less willing to employ young and inexperienced workers.
Many people point to the same thing-the level of the junior wage. The Myers report states:

The inescapable fact is that the principle of equal pay, together with a decreasing gap between the award wages of adults and juniors, results in a strong preference by employers for people with work experience. While this condition and high unemployment continue to exist, intending new entrants to the workforce will continue to be a large proportion of the unemployed.
All these people are saying the same thing. The Schools Commission blames the schools to a large extent. In its report 'Schooling for 15 and 16-year olds' in November 1980, it states:
Secondary schools seem preoccupied with preparation for tertiary study, a future for only 15 per cent of students--
Only 15 per cent will be able to use that preparation. It continues:
Many students, a substantial minority, think they are unsuited to schools and leave early or passively endure their sentences.

It is a complicated matter. As a mother, I would not like my child to go on unemployment benefit. I would much prefer my child to get some additional education that will benefit him and make him more acceptable to an employer. The Opposition tells us so frequently that the system followed in Sweden is the answer to a socialist country's prayers, that Sweden has the answer to all the problems of socialism. An article in the Times educational supplement states:

New legislation in Sweden has placed the responsibility for all under-18's, whether they are in school or not, firmly in the hands of the school system. If a young person doesn't find a job he shouldn't be considered unemployed, but be seen as a pupil. An education that fits his needs must be designed for him.

That is what this Government is all about. Yet the Opposition says that Sweden is wrong. For the first time, that I can recall, it says that Sweden is wrong. It usually tells us how good Sweden is, but it does not like this aspect so it is ignoring it. This Government has said to the mothers and fathers of this country: 'If your 15, 16 and 17-year old children cannot get a job upon leaving school, the Government is prepared to re-educate them to make sure-as is the case in Sweden-that an education that fits his needs is designed for him'. The Opposition has misinterpreted the whole scheme. It has said purely that the Government is wanting to save money and that the Government is trying to cut down the employment benefit for the under 18-year-olds. The Government is prepared to spend additional money on training and educating these people so that-as Sweden advocates-they will receive education to fit their needs.

Members of the Opposition are saying to the young unemployed: 'Look, if you are at technical college or somewhere like that, look at your mates. They are getting money in their hands. You are learning and being educated, but you do not have money in your hand at the moment. You should think of the short term; do not think of the long term. Do not think that when you have this extra training you may be fit for a job. Just think of the moment'. I have had young boys come to me and say: 'You know, I am thinking twice about the technical college course I am doing. I am at college and I am studying. I know Joe, Jim and Bill and they have money in their hands. They have their $36 a week and they can go and enjoy themselves while their parents support them'.

It is a temptation for those young people to go away from the education system and accept unemployment benefit. This Government realises that that is a temptation and I am ashamed to say that the Opposition is encouraging that thought amongst the young. I am disgusted that the Opposition is encouraging the young to think of the present moment, the $36 they could have in their hands, and not their future and the fact that they should have that additional education to fit them for their life and the career ahead of them. That is a summary of the supposed matter of public importance brought before this chamber today. The Opposition has deliberately misinterpreted the subject. Not one member of the Opposition has mentioned what the introduction of a 35-hour week would do. Not one of them has mentioned how that and strikes will effect unemployment. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have so moved today because the procedure is that only papers presented by Ministers are put on the list which is circulated to the honourable senators and, as this report was one to the Parliament, it did not appear on the list on Tuesday. Thus it slipped us by. It is an important report, as are all Auditor-General's reports. It gives us one of the few opportunities we have in this place to note outside assessments of the administration of many departments. It is a pity in many ways that this report and the major Auditor-General's report each year come into the Parliament without warning to anyone in the Opposition and almost without warning to people in the Government as to its contents so that a proper debate cannot be conducted at the time. The annual reports of most departments-I suppose like the annual reports of most companies-understandably tend to be self-congratulatory. Therefore, it is important that we have a report such as this issued to the Parliament.

The report, as usual, deals with the finding of financial deficiencies in various departments. This report looks at not only financial deficiencies but also the suitability of and the adherence to the various financial practices of the programs which it surveyed. The report actually tries to evaluate the programs in terms of their goals as well as their financial accountability. Again, this is an important aspect and something that we do far too little of in this Parliament. Therefore, I believe it is worthwhile generating a parliamentary discussion on this report.

For instance, the Auditor-General looks at the Community Youth Support Scheme-CYSS. The audit detailed in this report was done to see whether the practice was in line with the guidelines, financial regularity and legal compliance necessary under the legislation which set up the scheme. Of course, in any scheme run by people with a concern for unemployed youth there will not be a complete understanding of the reasons for all the rules. It seems that in all schemes such as this there will invariably be deficiencies in meeting the accountng and reporting demands of government. In reply to criticisms in the report-that reports on final projects have not always been submitted, that there has been a publicity budget overrun, inadequate monitoring of insurance cover and other matters-the Department of Employment and Youth Affairs has reassured the Auditor-General that everything is now under control. So I found the most interesting the comments from the Auditor-General on this section which stated that the action taken by the Department was an improvement. However the report continued:
No evidence could be found at a regional office level . . . that criteria had been established for evaluating the effectiveness of programs in meeting the principal objectives of the scheme.

I think this is a criticism of CYSS which has been made by many people in this Parliament and by many people who are involved in projects. It is important that a comment such as that has come from the Auditor-General. It may be that too much detailed administration work is required of people working in programs such as CYSS while the effectiveness and the applicability of the program to the goals which are established for that program are ignored. Maybe in a proper evaluation we should have more concern spent on the establishment of proper goals and on the evaluation of the body's ability to meet those goals rather than on the great detail we require on an administrative level.

I think one of the most interesting sections of the report is that which deals with the Department of Health. The first section worth looking at in the part of the report dealing with the Department of Health is that section which refers to the collapse of a registered Tasmanian health insurance fund, namely, the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund, and the implications for other collapsed or potentially collapsing funds. In the Senate Estimates committee which met at the time of the collapse and in later debate in this place we noted the problems which faced the Department in trying to monitor what was happening to a fund. I think it is worth while looking at what the Auditor-General had to say about this matter. He said:
The Department's comments were sought on the adequacy of procedures following the collapse of a registered fund in Tasmania.

The Department's Central Office advised that in monitoring the financial activities of medical and hospital benefits organisations it is heavily dependent upon the organisations providing timely information in a proper form. Only then is the Department able to make considered judgments regarding their solvency. In the particular case and despite considerable efforts, the organisation did not respond appropriately to requests by the Department for the provision of information and to the acceptance of advice offered. This attitude contrasts with that of other organisations. In addition the Department has recently instituted a more intensive monitoring program aimed at the early detection of organisations facing financial difficulties. A circular had been issued to all organisations advising of a more intensive program of reviews of the operation of funds and seeking their co-operation.

It seems to me-I am sure it seems to others who are involved in this unfortunate episode-that we are still in the situation where the Department is largely dependent on information from the funds to let it know how the funds are going. If an organisation such as Druids or a similar organisation in another State is unwilling to give proper information or, in fact, gives false information, it seems very likely that the Department would have no way of checking the information. We also have the problem of what the Government can do and what the Department can do when an organisation produces information which suggests that it might be in trouble. This is a dilemma which was faced and to which the Department addressed itself at the Estimates committee. From this report it seems that again the Department will be in that dilemma. If an organisation is going bad, does the Department warn the public? Does it warn the contributors and, therefore, be likely to cause a run on the fund? Whatever happens we have the situation that funds are in existence and are allowed to operate only when they are registered by the Commonwealth Department of Health. The responsibility is the Commonwealth Government's and we must ensure, I believe, that in future collapses of funds such as this do not hurt many people as, in fact, the collapse of this fund did the year before last.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking to the motion that I moved to take note of the Auditor-General's report on audits, examinations and inspections. I have pointed out that the report is useful in that it refers not only to the financial requirements of departments and various programs of government but also to the need to evaluate those programs in terms of their goals. I think it is important that the Senate take careful note of the report. I think it is significant that the Auditor-General, who is charged with looking at the financial responsibility of departments and programs, should have drawn our attention to the matters set out in his report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to two other short matters. One is that part of the report which deals with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme and the other is the section which deals with the lack of co-ordination which appears to have existed between the Department of Health and the Department of Social Security for some time. The report points out that the required cyclical examination of participating chemists' claims in Western Australia was not carried out. The reason given was staff ceilings. Given the high expenditure-more than $200m-on pharmaceutical benefits in this country, surely it is poor economy not to have experienced staff to watch these claims and not to have regular and proper reviews. In the same section the Auditor-General points out the other unsatisfactory features. The report states that as a result of a High Court challenge medical practitioners are not obliged to use the uniquely numbered prescription forms which do nothing more than facilitate the computer check of prescribing habits of doctors. We should examine the matter and see whether we can improve the efficiency of looking at one section of a department which expends some $200m of public funds each year.

Another matter I wish to talk about is the apparent lack of co-ordination over many years between the Department of Health and Department of Social Security. The report contains several references to this sort of problem. One such reference reads:

A common feature noted during audits of pharmaceutical benefits and of bulk-billing arrangements under the Commonwealth Medical Benefits scheme has been the fact that an appropriate system has not been implemented to validate the pensioner health benefit numbers quoted on pharmaceutical benefit and Commonwealth medical benefits bulk-billing claims.
The report goes on:

This office has been aware for some time of representations by the Department of Health to the Department of Social Security on the need for a system to enable the Department of Health to check the validity of pensioner health benefit numbers quoted on claims lodged under the two schemes. The confidentiality of Department of Social Security records had evidently made it difficult to introduce an effective system of checking.

We have no real effective method to check the validity of the claims and prescriptions made under a system providing for the expenditure of large sums of public money. No one would want to see the confidentiality of the records of the Department of Social Security being attacked in any way but, by the same token, we must have accountability for the public funds spent by this Department in such volumes. The Auditor-General, as he has in previous years, requests that such a sensible system be developed and expresses concern at the lack of such a system in view of the expenditure involved. One can only echo the words of the Auditor-General when he expresses concern in this area.

I believe that honourable senators who are interested in the various departments and who have their own pet interests in these matters should take a close look at the references throughout this important report and seek to improve the efficiency of departments and the scrutiny that we have over them. I believe that the Government should consider having a proper debate on the report when we have had time to review the words of the Auditor-General in what is a relatively thin volume. The Auditor-General's Office is very important. It is important in that it assists us to ensure that public funds are spent efficiently and effectively. It assists us to establish whether government programs have been evaluated properly and proper goals set, an aspect of planning which a report of a Senate standing committee made much of a couple of years ago. In the hope that the Government will bring on a further debate on this important report, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to give to members of the public rights of access to official documents of the Government of the Commonwealth and of its agencies.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Freedom of Information Bill is well known. It is described in clause 3 of the Bill as being to extend the right of the Australian community to access to official information in the possession of the Government of the Commonwealth. The Bill seeks to achieve this in two ways: firstly, by making available to the public information about the operations of departments and public authorities and, in particular, ensuring that the rules and practices affecting members of the public in their dealings with those departments and public authorities are readily available to those who are affected by those rules and practices; secondly, the Bill creates a general right of access to official information in documentary form in the possession of Ministers, departments and public authorities. This general right of access must, of course, be limited. The limitations are required for the protection of essential public interests, for the protection of the private and business affairs of persons in respect of whom information is collected and held by departments and public authorities, and for the proper conduct of public business by the Government.

Honourable senators will, of course, be familiar with the background of this Bill. I introduced a freedom of information Bill into the Senate on 9 June 1978. That Bill was subsequently referred by the Senate to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The Committee reported in November 1979, and last September I made a statement in the Senate setting out the Government's response to the recommendations made by the Committee both for changes in the Bill as introduced in 1978 and for a number of matters connected with the administration of the legislation. The present Bill has been drafted to give effect to the changes in the 1978 Bill which were described in my statement of last September. The Bill also incorporates some additional changes to the 1978 Bill which are designed to improve and clarify a number of provisions of that Bill. As well as the customary explanatory memorandum, a 'black-type' memorandum showing the differences between the Freedom of Information Bill 1978 and the Freedom of Information Bill 1981 will be distributed.

In introducing the 1978 Bill, I referred to the fact that the initiative taken by the Government in bringing forward the Bill was the first such initiative by a 'Westminster style' government. Since then, there has been considerable interest in the topic of freedom of information in countries which share that tradition. Two freedom of information Bills have been introduced into the Canadian Parliament. The first, which was introduced in 1979 by the then Canadian Government, lapsed when that Government was defeated. The second was introduced last year by the present Canadian Government. It has passed its second reading in the Canadian House of Commons and has been referred to a parliamentary committee for consideration. Two private members' Bills for freedom of information have been introduced into the United Kingdom Parliament. In New Zealand, the report of a committee established by the New Zealand Government to consider the question of freedom of information has now been published.

Each of the proposals I have mentioned has incorporated the same basic approach as is in the present Bill. There are, however, a number of differences in detail. The proposals in each country must be considered in the context in which they are intended to operate. Thus, the present Bill must be viewed in the context of the systems of administrative review which have already been established by this Parliament; namely, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the Federal Court of Australia operating under the powers conferred on it by the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. In addition, there are differences in the nature of the parliamentary institutions in each country, which affect the relationships between Ministers and the Parliament. In particular I draw attention to the practice of both Houses in this Parliament with regard to questions without notice. Thus what is appropriate, or may be appropriate, for one country is not necessarily appropriate for another.

This brings me to the contentious issue of the right of appeal against decisions to refuse access to documents. The Bill maintains the approach of the 1978 Bill that there should be no review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a decision of a Minister or Permanent Head to withhold documents on certain grounds. The grounds are those which affect the most sensitive areas of government, namely, defence, security, international relations, and Commonwealth-State relations. These are all vital national interests where the improper disclosure of sensitive information can do a great deal of harm. The Bill provides also, as did the 1978 Bill, that a certificate by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet or the Secretary to the Federal Executive Council is conclusive evidence that a document is a Cabinet document or an Executive Council document, as the case may be, and is therefore exempt from disclosure.

Likewise, the Bill provides that a decision to refuse access to an internal working document on the ground that disclosure of the document would be contrary to the public interest is not subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The category of internal working documents includes confidential communications between Ministers, between Ministers and officials, and between officials on matters of government policy. In respect of all of these matters, the Government does not consider that review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is empowered to substitute its own view of what the correct or preferable decision should be, is an appropriate form of review. The Government remains firmly of the opinion that the final decision on the substantive issues should remain with Ministers and with officials responsible to Ministers. Where a decision is taken by a Minister, or by an official who is responsible to him, the Minister is answerable in the Parliament for that decision and can be questioned on it in the forum.

I turn now to the question of access to documents which are already in the possession of agencies at the time the Bill comes into force. As I explained in the statement last September, the Government has maintained the view that the Bill should not give a general right of access to prior documents and that it should not include a firm commitment to do so after a certain time has elapsed. The extent of the demand which the legislation will make upon departmental resources is not predictable and the Government therefore believes that it is wise to adopt a cautious approach until there has been some experience of the operation of the legislation. The Government has given an undertaking that it will consider this matter again during the first major review of the legislation, which it sees as appropriate after the legislation has been in force for about three years.

The 1978 Bill provided that agencies might be exempt from its operation by means of regulations. Clause 6 of the present Bill, and the Schedule to the Bill, will have the effect that certain agencies are exempted by the Bill itself from its scope either wholly or as to specified functions. The Schedule is in two parts. The first part of the Schedule specifies those agencies which are totally exempt, that is, the freedom of information legislation does not apply to them at all. Part II of the Schedule lists those agencies which are exempt in respect of certain functions. The effect is that a request may not be made under the legislation for access to a document which relates to a function in respect of which an agency is exempt.

The intelligence agencies are to be exempt. Those that are separate bodies are listed in Part I of the Schedule. These are the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, the Australian Secret Intelligence Service and the Office of National Assessments. Those which are part of the Department of Defence are listed in Part II of the Schedule, namely, the Defence Signals Directorate and the Joint Intelligence Organisation.

Also included in Part I of the Schedule are a number of government agencies which are engaged in commercial enterprises. In addition, the Part includes a number of agencies which are there for special reasons-the Aboriginal land councils and land trusts, the Auditor-General's Office, the National Debt Commission and the National Labour Consultative Council. The greater number of agencies to be exempt in respect of particular documents under Part II of the Schedule are agencies which carry on competitive commercial activities as part of their functions. In addition, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Special Broadcasting Service are to be exempt in respect of program material. The Reserve Bank is to be exempt in respect of its banking functions and its exchange control functions.

The inclusion of the Schedule in the Bill represents the present view of the Government as to what agencies should be exempt, either wholly or as to certain functions. To take account of the creation of new agencies, or changes in circumstances as a result of experience under the legislation, clause 6 of the Bill continues to provide that further exemptions may be made by regulation.

Particular attention has been given in the redrafting of the Bill to the question of protecting confidential commercial information from disclosure. A number of private sector organisations have expressed concern to the Senate Committee at the possibility of disclosure of information of a commercial character which has been supplied to government. Ministers have given assurances that such information supplied by private sector organisations would not be subject to disclosure under the freedom of information legislation.

There are two relevant changes in the present Bill, compared with the 1978 Bill. First, as recommended by the Senate Committee, provision is made for consultation with the supplier of information before a decision is made on a request for access to a document which contains commercial information. The supplier is to be given a right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against a decision that the document is not an exempt document on the ground that it contains confidential commercial information. Secondly, the relevant clause of the Bill-clause 38-has been substantially redrafted to ensure that it does provide adequate protection for information of a confidential commercial character.

Some of the clauses of the Bill defining exempt documents have been redrafted, in some cases to give effect to recommendations of the Senate Committee and in other cases after considering comments by the Senate Committee. The Government has not, however, deleted any of the clauses which were contained in the 1978 Bill. These clauses will no doubt be considered in detail during the Committee stage of the debate and the nature of the changes which have been made can then be explained.

Clause 43 of the Bill contains a new exemption relating to documents arising out of the National Companies and Securities Scheme. As I explained in the statement I made last September, it is not appropriate that the administration of State company laws should be subject to Commonwealth freedom of information legislation merely because the administering agency is a Commonwealth body. The effect of clause 43 would be to exempt from mandatory disclosure records of the discussions and deliberations of the Ministerial Council on Companies and Securities, documents prepared by the States for the Ministerial Council and documents relating solely to the administration by the National Companies and Securities Commission of the laws of the States and the Northern Territory. Documents prepared by Commonwealth agencies including the National Companies and Securities Commission itself, for submission to the Ministerial Council and documents which involve a Commonwealth interest, such as the administration of the company law in the Australian Capital Territory, would not be covered by the exemption contained in clause 43. What should be the scope of the exemption is, however, still under discussion with the States. The present clause is, therefore, an interim measure and the Government will, if necessary, be proposing amendments to it to give effect to the agreement finally reached with the States.

The Senate Committee recommended that the Bill should make it possible to withhold information about the existence or non-existence of a document in circumstances where the disclosure of the existence or non-existence of a document would itself be prejudicial to a number of interests which the Bill would otherwise protect. In accordance with this recommendation, clause 24 of the Bill empowers the withholding of information as to the existence or non-existence of a document where disclosure of that information would be prejudicial to defence, security, international relations or Commonwealth-State relations. Such information may also be withheld where disclosure of the existence or non-existence of a document would prejudice the investigation of criminal offences or breaches of the taxation laws or the enforcement or proper administration of the law in a particular case, or would disclose the existence or identity of a confidential informant or would endanger the lives or physical safety of those engaged in law enforcement. To give full effect to the Senate Committee recommendations, some consequential changes have been made in respect of the giving of certificates under clauses 28, 29 and 30 of the Bill.

The Bill maintains the time limit of 60 days within which an agency must respond to a request for access. Clause 18 of the Bill provides, however, for the making of regulations which would shorten that time limit. This is in accordance with the undertaking contained in my statement last September that the question of time limits would be reviewed after experience of the operation of the legislation.

The authority of the Ombudsman to investigate complaints about decisions under the freedom of information legislation has been extended so that he is not precluded from investigating a matter on the ground that an appeal lies to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is achieved by clause 47 of the Bill, which is a new clause. Where a complaint is made to the Ombudsman, and the Ombudsman undertakes an investigation, the right to appeal to the Tribunal is postponed until the Ombudsman has completed his investigation. It is desirable that the Ombudsman and the Tribunal should not both be dealing with a matter at the same time.

The 1978 Bill provided that the giving of access to a document might be deferred until the happening of a particular event or until the expiration of a specified time where it was reasonable to do so in the public interest or having regard to normal or proper administrative practice. This provision is continued in clause 20 of the Bill. There has been added, however, a power to defer access pending the tabling of a document in the Parliament. The purpose of this change is to recognise the special interests of the Parliament in being first informed of matters which have a substantial public interest.

The Senate Committee recommended that the language of the exemption relating to defence, security and international relations should be brought into line with the language of the Protective Security Handbook. Consequent upon doing this, there has been a general revision of the language in other exemptions, to ensure consistency of approach.

Under the Bill, a person requesting access to documents is entitled to define the documents concerned by reference to their subject matter, so long as the identification and collation of those documents does not result in an unreasonable work load on the agency concerned. Under the 1978 Bill, it would have been necessary for an agency receiving such a request to consider each document covered by the request separately even though it was claimed that all of the documents would be exempt documents. This might result in the doing of a substantial amount of work for no benefit to the applicant. The Bill now provides, in sub-clause 23 (2), that a request may be refused without the agency having to search for and identify all of the documents covered by the request if it is plain that they would all be exempt documents and that in no case would it be practicable to delete exempt matter and make a copy of the document available with the exempt matter deleted. A decision under this sub-clause is, of course, subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Finally, I mention two new provisions relating to the objects of the legislation and its interpretation. Clause 3 of the Bill sets out the object of the Bill and contains an expression of parliamentary intention that its provision shall be interpreted so as to further that object. Clause 27 of the Bill is intended to make clear that each of the exemption provisions is to be interpreted separately and not read down by the inclusion of other exemption provisions.

Due to industrial problems in the Government Printing Office, it has not been possible to have printed for circulation today the explanatory memorandum and the comparative 'black-type' memorandum. It is expected that these will be available early next week. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Evans) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to the preservation and use of archival resources, and for related purposes.
Bill presented, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Archives Bill was introduced into the Senate on 9 June 1978 and was then referred, like the Freedom of Information Bill, to the Senate Committees on Education and the Arts and on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. The Archives Bill, now before the Senate, incorporates the response of the Government to the reports of those Committees. The Government's response was outlined to the Senate on 11 September 1980. The amendments incorporated in the present Bill appear clearly in the memorandum showing the differences between the Archives Bill 1978 and the Archives Bill 1981. I draw the attention of the Senate to the following clauses. There follows a bit of detail which I think is contained in the explanatory memorandum. I seek leave to incorporate that portion of the speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
clauses 10, 17 and 58 referring to the Advisory Council;
clause 21 referring to records of Cabinet and the Executive Council, and also of the Governor-General, the Parliament and the courts;
clause 33 (1) (h) ensures that exemption of the disclosure of methods of investigation which apply only where those methods are lawful;
clause 33 (2) dealing with legal privilege was included at the request of the Department of the Attorney-General;
clause 36 (4) (d) provision to ensure that the granting of access does not amount to breach of copyright;
clause 39 makes provision for denying access to law enforcement records without confirming or denying their existence;
clause 40 (6) (b) referring to the time within which decisions upon access must be made;
clauses 40 (7) and (8) and 45 dealing with the role of the Ombudsman;

clause 42 (4) (a) extends the period within which an application for review may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal from 28 to 60 days after a written decision is furnished to the applicant;
clause 43 (4) referring to the role of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in relation to exempt documents;
clause 47 protecting original authors against defamation charges and providing additional protection against actions for breach of copyright;
clause 61 referring to charges and fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also draw the attention of the Senate to the following matters dealt with in the present Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: Records of the Northern Territory Administration

The Bill was amended to take account of progress by the Territory towards self-government and to exempt from its operations records created by the Northern Territory since the proclamation of the Northern Territory Self-Government Act 1978 and former Commonwealth records which will pass to the Northern Territory as the successor administration. Appropriate amendments have been made to clauses 3 (1), 3 (2) (g) (iii), 25 (b), 33 (1) (b) and (c), 33 (4).
Commonwealth/State matters

Fears have been expressed by some States that the Commonwealth might require the return of Commonwealth records in the custody of State institutions under clauses 28 and 51 of the Act. These clauses are intended to apply only to Commonwealth records in the custody of a Commonwealth institution and no amendment to the original clauses was considered necessary by the Parliamentary Counsel to protect the States. However, the Government promised that immediately after the passage of legislation, the Australian Archives would seek to achieve administrative agreement with archival authorities of the States as to mutually acceptable procedures for the release of shared documents.

Clause 25 makes provision for giving effect by regulations to such agreements as they affect existing records and also in future cases where archival arrangements need to be made for records arising out of activities in which the Commonwealth is involved jointly with another government. It will be applied in particular to the agreement to be reached on archival arrangements between participants in the Co-operative Companies and Securities Industry Scheme. Legislation is not necessary to permit the Australian Archives to contribute to making available records under freedom of information legislation. This can be achieved by making manuals, indexes and other information concerning records available in Archives reading rooms, by providing the assistance of archives staff in explaining the administrative arrangements of the Commonwealth, and by the use of Archives reading rooms for the examination of records. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ryan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Durack) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Copyright Act 1968.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is consequential upon the Archives Bill 1981. Its purpose is to provide for the Australian Archives to be the depository of certain material under the Copyright Act. The Bill will amend the Copyright Act 1968 to enable broadcasting and television organisations to deposit with the Australian Archives the so-called ephemeral recordings which the Director-General of the Australian Archives certifies as being of exceptional documentary character. The present provisions of the Copyright Act provide for deposit of these recordings with the National Library.

An ephemeral recording is a recording-whether videotape, cinematograph film or sound recording-made by a radio or television broadcaster for the purposes of broadcasting a copyright work. The Copyright Act entitles a broadcaster, who has a licence to broadcast a copyright work, to make such a recording without further permission, so long as the recording is either destroyed within twelve months, or such longer period as is agreed to, or delivered to the National Library for archival retention. The Berne Copyright Convention requires the destruction of such recordings unless they are preserved in official archives on the ground of their exceptional documentary character. Now that the Archives is to be established on a statutory basis, with rights of access to be defined, it is appropriate that the Archives, rather than the National Library, be entitled to receive this material, and that its Director-General be responsible for its certification as material of exceptional documentary character.

Particulars of all ephemeral recordings received by the Archives will be kept, under the provisions of the Archives Bill, in the Australian National Register of Records established by that Bill. Recordings received from government-funded broadcasters will be kept as appropriate in one of the repositories maintained by the Archives around Australia. With the consent of the National Librarian, recordings received from private broadcasters will be lodged by the Archives, under the provisions of the Archives Bill, with the National Library of Australia where they will be kept together with like material deposited by non-governmental bodies. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill concerns arrangements for the taxation of dividend income payable to individuals and, to a less important degree, interest payments and royalties where those moneys are earned in one country but are remitted to and payable in another. The present legislation extends an agreement covering these matters to Malaysia and Sweden, which two countries are added to a list of, I think, 16 countries with which Australia already has what are commonly known as double taxation agreements. The arrangements made in this legislation for those two countries are not identical, nor is either of them identical with arrangements for the other countries; but they all follow a very similar pattern. Without international agreements of this type, a company which was operating, say, in Australia and which had foreign shareholders would be liable, in the first instance, to Australian company tax. Dividends paid to foreign shareholders could be liable, in the absence of such an agreement, to be taxed as individual income in Australia, the residue being fully taxable in the hands of the ultimate recipient abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: To overcome this problem there are basically two methods in these international agreements. One is an arrangement that the income will be taxed in one country only. The second and much more common arrangement is that the amount of tax which may be paid on such dividends will be limited in both countries. Usually, in agreements to which Australia is a party, taxation in Australia on dividends payable abroad is limited to 15 per cent; otherwise they could be taxed at very much higher rates. Therefore, some loss of revenue is entailed in what could be regarded as a concession to overseas shareholders.

Though it is impossible to quantify the net losses, it is conceivable that the losses from that source might be more than offset by the exchange of information on company business or the price of company products and profits between taxing authorities in the respective countries. That would make it more difficult for companies to indulge in transfer pricing activities; that is, working with related companies to arrange prices in such a way that profits are maximised in countries which have low levels of taxation, and little or no profit is recorded in countries which have higher levels of taxation. The information which the Australian Taxation Office can obtain from taxation offices of other countries with which we have agreements make it more difficult for transfer pricing arrangements to be used to evade tax on income which ought to be recorded and therefore payable in Australia.

It was shown in an action before the High Court earlier this year that the powers of section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which is intended to give the Commissioner power to levy tax in the circumstances in which unrealistic prices are charged by subsidiaries or are being recorded for exports by Australian subsidiaries of overseas corporations, are extremely limited. That section was interpreted by the High Court-ever eager, of course, to seize upon any loophole to provide some sort of spurious rationale for a judgment in favour of tax avoiders-to be inadequate for the purpose for which it was designed.

That is not entirely unexpected. I do not want to be seen to be excusing what was in this case an outrageous judgment by the High Court, but at least as far back as the Asprey Taxation Review Committee report of 1975 attention was drawn to the possibility of section 136 being inadequate for the purpose for which it was designed. To this stage, nothing has been done about amending section 136. If experience is any guide, one would not want to hold one's breath while waiting for the Government to do something about it now, even after the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation case.

Taxation on income due to Australian citizens from investments abroad is uncertain and is liable to evasion because of the interaction of section 23Q and section 46 of the present Act. I think it is worth noting and putting on the record that the possibility for tax evasion by Australian citizens, who have investments abroad and to whom dividends from those investments accrue, is likely to be related to the recent moves by six of Australia's major trading banks to establish branches in the Cayman Islands, which is, of course, a notorious haven for tax evasion. All of these branches have been established since 1978, and five of them were established only last year. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd led by establishing a branch in 1978, followed in 1980 by the Bank of New South Wales, the Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd, even the Commonwealth Trading Bank of Australia, I regret to say, the National Bank of Australasia Ltd and the Commercial Banking Co. of Sydney Ltd. All of those last five banks established branches in the Cayman Islands in 1980. Whilst I at least have no direct evidence of the reason for the banks establishing branches there, it is highly likely that the primary reason is to assist in anti-social tax avoidance activities by Australian citizens who have investments abroad and income due on those investments.

This potential for exploitation of what is morally theft was recognised as far back as June 1978 and was publicly acknowledged by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), who forecast legislation to deal with this rort. After an intensive campaign of lobbying by the would-be thieves, who of course wanted to continue their exploitation, the Treasurer, on behalf of the Government, was forced to repudiate his own forecast of four months earlier in October 1978 and he dropped the proposition to close those loopholes. We have heard nothing more since. It is yet another example of the propensity of this Government, as my colleague, Ralph Willis, pointed out in the House of Representatives, when faced with intense lobbying from vested anti-social interests, to cave in.

Other than the possibility of contributions to party funds-which, of course, is always a factor-I think the reason the Government is so vulnerable to this sort of pressure really goes deeper. Most members of the Government really do not see anything wrong with making arrangements to evade liability to pay taxation. An action which to many people-I suggest anyone who is not morally bankrupt-is tantamount to theft and which ought to be regarded as theft is not held in disdain by most of the members of the Government. They quite genuinely cannot see anything wrong with it. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), when questioned on the matter by the media a few years ago, revealed his belief. He said: 'Everybody has family trusts, don't they?' Fundamentally, members of the Government do not believe that tax avoidance is morally wrong. There are others who no doubt are much more cynical and who consider that it probably helps party coffers if the Government goes easy on some of these people and who probably are deeply into exploitation of the loopholes in a personal way.

The Opposition is not opposing this Bill, but yet again I want to place on record our disgust at the Government's tardiness to take action in the area of closing the loopholes in the taxation legislation and stopping tax avoidance, whether it has international connotations or purely domestic ones. It is not good enough for Government spokesmen to say, as Senator Carrick frequently says: 'The Labor Party did not do anything about it when it was in government'. I will not entirely defend the record of the Labor Government between 1973 and 1975 in this area. In some instances it was demonstrably negligent, although in mitigation I think one could say that at least from mid-1974 to the coup of November 1975 it was a government under siege. Under those circumstances, not surprisingly, it was more concerned with week to week survival than with long term planning. It also ought to be said in mitigation that at that stage, although there was tax avoidance, there was not tax avoidance on the scale which now exists, nor had it been known for so long that tax avoidance was so commonly practised. Indeed, I suppose it was the infamous Curran judgment of the High Court in 1974 which opened the floodgates and in effect declared open season for raids on the public purse. It is not good enough for members of this Government to criticise a previous government-now out of office for five and a half years-for having been to a limited degree negligent in this area. That does not excuse the gross negligence of the present Government in allowing taxation avoidance to deprive the revenue of at least a billion dollars a year, as it has done for a number of years, and taking no action against it.

In the sphere of remittances between countries, the action forecast almost three years ago by the Treasurer and repudiated four months later ought to be resurrected. Likewise, for domestic tax avoidance there is no reasonable doubt that a credible threat of retrospective legislation would deprive of clients those parasitic, anti-social lawyers and accountants who devise these schemes. What would-be tax avoider no matter how larcenous his intentions, would contemplate paying huge commissions to the parasites who organise tax avoidance schemes when he knew that ultimately he would have to pay his tax liability in any case?

The Opposition is not opposing the Bill. We implore the Government yet again to do something about tax avoidance, to take effective action against tax avoidance on a much larger scale than it has shown any willingness to do in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for supporting this measure and hope that it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ANTARCTIC MARINE LIVING RESOURCES CONSERVATION BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to allow Australia legally to implement the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources. The text of the Convention is provided as a schedule in the Bill. The Convention was drawn up within the Antarctic Treaty Forum and finalised at an international conference in Canberra in May 1980.
