The signatories include all the Antarctic Treaty consultative parties as well as a number of other nations, including the Federal Republic of Germany and the German Democratic Republic, which have recently entered the international Antarctic community.

Australia was honoured at the conference by being chosen both as official depository nation for the Convention, and as host nation for the headquarters of the new International Commission which is to be established to administer the Convention. The Convention comes into force when the 'eighth instrument of ratification' from a national government is lodged with Australia as depository nation. The passage of this Bill will facilitate ratification by Australia. The Government is also pleased to note that Hobart has been selected as the site for the Commission headquarters, and this will be an added boost to Hobart's role as the focal point of Australian Antarctic activity. This is a notable first for Australia as it will be the first international organisation based here.

The Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources is also a notable first. The Convention is based on a conservation standard which embodies an ecosystem approach to conservation; that is, it seeks to protect not only harvested species but also the entire ecosystem including species dependent on the harvested species. In this way it differs from traditional fisheries agreements which seek only to protect the target resource. The area of application of the Convention is the seas south of the Antarctic convergence, a natural physical boundary between the colder Antarctic waters and warmer oceans in temperate zones to the north. This is the first time an Antarctic agreement has had effect outside of the traditional Antarctic zone delineated by the 60 degrees south latitude.

This Convention is the third international agreement developed by the Antarctic Treaty nations in a series of agreements, designed to protect Antarctic wildlife and the Antarctic environment. The first was the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Seals which was finalised in 1972. The second was the 'Agreed Measures for the Conservation of Antarctic Fauna and Flora' which was given effect by the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980. The Treaty nations, including Australia, are currently working on the question of mineral rights and exploitation. It is likely that these discussions will lead to the development of another, fourth agreement.

The Commission provided for in Article 7 of the Convention is likely to be established in 1982 following a preparatory meeting to be held in Hobart later this year. The Commission will oversee the implementation of the Convention and will devise and recommend conservation measures for adoption by participating nations.

Conservation measures may take the form of catch limits or total bans on harvesting delicate or endangered species. Restrictions may be imposed on fishing in certain areas during periods of the year when the risk of permanent damage to the species is high. Conservation measures such as these are commonly used in the management of living resources in both the marine and terrestrial environment. The Commission will decide which ones are applicable to the management of the Southern Ocean ecosystem and make appropriate recommendations to member countries. The Convention also establishes a scientific committee. This scientific committee will undertake analyses of research related to the ecosystem and formulate advice on this for the Commission.

The Bill itself is quite straight forward and establishes a permit system for research and commercial fishing in the area south of the Antarctic convergence. It provides for the adoption of conservation measures recommended by the Commission. The permit system to be established under the Bill gives the Minister power to regulate organisations and individuals in respect of activities involving marine life, including harvesting and research, and provides for penalties for failure to comply with these. The Bill also allows the Minister to appoint inspectors-including every member of the Australian Federal Police or of the police force of a Territory-and specifies their duties and powers.

Australian sovereignty in the Australian Antarctic Territory is in no way prejudiced by the Convention. The Convention, like the Antarctic Treaty itself, safeguards all national sovereignty in the Antarctic. The Bill covers both the activities of Australians anywhere in the Convention area and the activities of any national in Australian territory.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon), of course, has primary responsibility for the regulation of fishing activity in the Australian fishing zone and he will be consulted in the application of the Bill. Australia's policy towards Antarctica is based on the premise that the region is an important one for Australia. Therefore Australia has had a history of involvement and a range of interests and potential interests to protect. It is Government policy to maintain and strengthen that role and ensure that Antarctica remains both a zone of peace and of international co-operation.

As a consequence, Australia has maintained an appropriate level of activity there and, as one of the 12 original signatories of the Antarctic Treaty has played a prominent role in international discussions of Antarctic issues. International agreement on the Convention on the Conservation of Antarctic Living Marine Resources is another important step in this process.

It will help conserve the Antarctic heritage for future generations. This Bill represents the culmination of extensive and carefully considered efforts by many nations, including Australia, and is an important step forward in the protection of the Antarctic environment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 April, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation extends the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Retirement and Redeployment) Act to cover employees of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. This Bill is not opposed by the Opposition. I understand that it was accepted, or even welcomed, by the employees of the Corporation, which is an ironic twist. The Bill has been portrayed by the Government which sponsored it and usually it would be accepted on these terms by the official Opposition and other opponents of the Bill, as a disciplinary measure which increases Commonwealth power to hire, fire and downgrade employees. No attention was paid to the increased options which the Bill made available to Commonwealth employees. If in fact the Bill had been adequately and accurately portrayed by the Government as something which increased its disciplinary powers over its employees we would expect employees to be unequivocally opposed to it, which has not been the case with its extension to include the employees of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation. The reason for that, of course, is that insufficient attention has been paid to the other provisions of the Bill which widen the options for employees.

SPEECH.PARA: This became apparent when it was revealed that the former head of the Department of Social Security-the person who we were told always advised Senator Guilfoyle when she was giving incorrect information to the Senate as Minister for Social Security-had used the provisions of the Commonwealth Employees (Retirement and Redeployment) Act to get out of the Public Service at age 56, I think it was, on an indexed pension of $20,000 a year for life. Being a man of considerable experience and expertise in the area of taxation, he is believed to be setting himself up in business as a tax evasion consultant, thereby doubly punishing all the taxpayers of Australia. Firstly, he is taking a huge pension at age 56 when obviously he is quite capable of continuing to work. Although it may be not suitable for him to continue to work in the office which he previously held, he is obviously quite capable of continuing to work in some capacity. However, at the age of 56 he is drawing from the public purse an indexed life time pension of $20,000 a year. Then, just to add insult to the fiscal injury, he is adding to his income, no doubt enormously, by setting up in business as a private consultant to assist a favoured few wealthy people in avoiding their liability to the taxes which are required to pay, among other things, of course, Mr Lanigan's premature and generous pension.

It is perhaps a pity, and indeed it is not generally recognised even yet, that some aspects of the Commonwealth Employees (Retirement and Redeployment) Act have not been readily grasped by the general public. It is a bit late in the day to start worrying about that now. The extension of the scope of the Commonwealth banking legislation is minor in content and agreed on, apparently, by both employees and management of the bank. The Bill is not opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Walsh for his remarks in favour of the Bill. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STAGING OF B52s THROUGH AUSTRALIA FOR SEA SURVEILLANCE IN THE INDIAN OCEAN AND FOR NAVIGATION TRAINING

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 March, on motion by Senator Carrick:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the ministerial statement on the staging of B52 bombers through Australia for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean and for navigation training; these B52 bombers, in fact, being staged at Darwin. This matter has been the source of considerable controversy in the last few weeks. Last night we heard a speech on this subject by Senator MacGibbon. I suggest that that speech should remind us that there are some things in this place and some things in this world that never change. Senator MacGibbon made what I believe to be an unfortunate speech in which he advocated, in fact, that the basis of the Australia-United States of America alliance should involve complete Australian compliance and complete Australian trust in everything said and done by the United States, in particular the United States State Department, in its dealings with Australia in its conduct of this alliance.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to show that we on this side of the House have every reason to wish that such an agreement should be based not on blind trust but that it should be a carefully thought-out partnership based on a carefully thought-out agreement so there is no room for the sorts of mistakes such as were made in the past. Senator MacGibbon, having made his point, proceeded to berate the Opposition and in particular, Senator Robertson, for suggesting that B52s may be used by the United States in raids in the Persian Gulf region. They may be used for such a purpose in view of the difficult situation existing in that area valuable to the oil supplies of the world. Senator MacGibbon's words were roughly to the effect that anyone who believed that the United States would use or intended to use B52s to bomb in the region of the Persian Gulf did not know what he was talking about and that it was a stupid concept. He suggested that persons who suggested that had no idea-in particular Senator Robertson-and really were quite ignorant of the problems.

I believe the first thing I should do in speaking this afternoon is to refer Senator MacGibbon to today's Age, to an article written by George Wilson of the Washington Post. It is an article written by a distinguished journalist from a journal known for its accuracy. George Wilson referred to the fact that B52 bomber crews at the Strategic Air Command base at Minot, North Dakota, near the Canadian border have a new mission; being ready to drop bombs in the Persian Gulf to protect oil supplies. He then quoted Brigadier-General John Shaud, commander of the 57th Air Division which includes the Strategic Projection Force, SPIF, B52 bombers. SPIF planners said that a B52 carrying a load of conventional 227-kilogram or 340-kilogram bombs could make the trip from North Dakota to the Gulf and back with only two mid-air refuellings and that this could also be done with nuclear weapons. The slogan of the Strategic Projection Force is 'Any time, Anywhere'. Training for Persian Gulf missions has reached the point where full-dress exercises will be conducted soon. The Brigadier-General said the force had the capability to launch a strike to the Persian Gulf out of North Dakota.

A Brigadier-General and senior officer in the American Air Force, George Wilson of the Washington Post, and obviously the State Department in America, apparently agree with Senator Robertson that it is perfectly feasible and perfectly likely and reasonable that B52 bombers would be used to bomb in the Persian Gulf region. I suggest that Senator MacGibbon is the only person in this place, or anywhere else, who believes that such a possibility is not on and that such a thing would not be considered by the United States Government or by the United States Air Force. To return to the statement, I believe we must consider it in the light of other statements made in the last few weeks to this Parliament. The first statement on B52s was made by the real Foreign Minister in this country, Mr Fraser. The second statement was made by the nominal Foreign Minister in this country, Mr Street. The Labor Party has expressed disquiet over this statement on B52s; first about the ambiguity and looseness in the wording of the formal Notes of Agreement exchanged between Mr Street and Mr Haig and tabled in this Parliament on 11 March, and secondly, disquiet about the loose agreed form of words later produced by Mr Street which, as he admitted, has no legal status.

Previous speakers on this side of the House have expressed justifiable concern about the apparent looseness of the arrangements and the lack of firm safeguards in the so-called agreement. I am sure that my legal colleague, Senator Evans, who will speak later in this debate, will go into more detail on the exact legal wording and the difficulties we find with that. Our apprehension and concern on this matter can only be heightened by the fact that the matter of staging B52s and their associated tankers was in fact produced out of the hat during the pre-election period when the Government tried to drum up a khaki election. It tried to go back to the days when the best way for conservatives to conduct elections in this country was to dream up foreign threats and drum up the security issue to have an election based on fear.

If the agreements are loose and lack clarity, as we assert, the apprehension expressed on this side of the House can only be heightened further by the previous track record of General Alexander Haig and also by the track record of the State Department in its dealings with Australia and the rest of her allies. We were misled years ago over the bombing in Cambodia and other incidents in the Vietnam war. We were not informed about previous red alerts in 1973 at United States installations in Australia although we were assured that we would be informed of such alerts. The United States has a history of misleading us on such issues as the Australian Government has also. Mr Menzies, who was then Prime Minister, quite clearly lied to the Australian people when he said that our involvement in Vietnam followed a request from South Vietnam. The Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) clearly misled this electorate when in the pre-election period they said that permission to stage the B52s in Australia was in response to a United States request. Our leader, Mr Hayden, in another place quoted from an article, by Frank Cranston of the Canberra Times who quoted Mr Killen as having said:
the matter was raised by the Prime Minister and I raised it . . . it has been put to them that it could well be of assistance if those aircraft were staged through Darwin.

Mr Killen replied with a typical, convoluted answer. He did not deny this fact and again quoted the Prime Minister as discussing ways in which we could help the United States. Quite clearly the approach was made and I do not believe anyone on the Government side has denied or can deny the fact that the approach to stage the B52s through Darwin was made by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence and not as a result of a request from the American Government, as was suggested in the pre-election period and in the lead-up to the statement in this place. Last week's foreign affairs speech, the other statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) at this time, was a clear illustration, when viewed in conjunction with this statement, of the double standards which the Government demonstrates in this matter. On the one hand Mr Street's speech advocates a sensible, middle power independence for Australia, but it is full of advice that this Government has not taken in the past and doubtless will not take in the future on our role in the alliance with the United States and, quite clearly, the Government will not take it as regards the staging of these B52s in Darwin. Mr Street says that Australia is a middle power and that we do not give sufficient attention to what such a status implies. He quite rightly states:
a middle power has more opportunites than a small power.
Again he states:

how seriously they are taken and what impact they have on events will depend largely on the quality of human performance, on the skill, knowledge, maturity, determination and imagination of those who formulate and implement their policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was probably written by Foreign Affairs.

—It is certainly written by Foreign Affairs, as Senator Sibraa says. It is certainly not written-not without tongue in cheek-by any Minister in this Government. These statements are true. They talk about the importance of a partnership. It is very sad that the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister do not fall into this category when they deal with our allies. Mr Street tells us that as a middle power we have an obligation to declare our position on all major issues-peace and war, freedom and oppression, racialism, development, poverty-because in some circumstances, he states, a middle power can be more effective than a great power. We have this Government doing what governments in this country in the past have done and that is to acquiesce completely with what is happening, despite what other countries say, to acquiesce completely with what happens for instance in El Salvador and to acquiesce completely with the present American Government's attitude to what should happen in the Middle East and the Indian Ocean. Why do we not attempt to put into practice, in our relationships with the United States in the American alliance, the principles which were laid out in this speech by Mr Street? Why do we not bring proper middle power, friendly pressure to bear on the Americans to modify their attitude on the Indian Ocean and the escalating arms race? Why do we not follow the example of western European allies of the United States and Canada to bring pressure to bear on the United States about its attitudes to the people and struggles in El Salvador? Mr Street admits:

SPEECH.PARA: for a middle power like Australia which is allied to a superpower, the management of that relationship constitutes a particularly important part of its diplomacy.

Surely that relationship should not be as consistently servile as it has become under this Government and previous conservative governments. Mr Street, in his speech, is prepared to acknowledge that Australia's national interests and those of the United States do not always coincide. I presume he refers to the occasions on which the senior partner in our most important alliance deems it inadvisable to inform the Australian Government or the Australian people of defence initiatives that may not appeal to us. I go back to the most striking example of that, which was the occasion when the North West Cape station was put on red alert in the 1973 Middle East crisis. Despite agreements that the Australian Government would be entitled to know of any such developments affecting a base on our soil, we were not told until after the event. America has treated other allies in this way; for instance, when Oman was used during the abortive and potentially disastrous rescue attempt of the United States hostages in Iran. The most shameful of the recent episodes was the bombing of Cambodia during the Vietnam war. We were not let into that sordid secret and the American people were not let into that sordid secret. One of the main protagonists of that attitude of treatment by the United States of its allies was, in fact, Alexander Haig, who is now United States Secretary of State. In his confirmation hearings, just a few weeks ago, he stated:
President Nixon's decision to bomb the sanctuaries of North Vietnamese troops along the Cambodian border and to keep that bombing secret, was made in March 1969.

I supported the President's decision to order those raids and I was involved in planning them. This operation was carried out as a secret military mission of the kind we have conducted historically and traditionally in time of conflict against enemy forces.
At the hearing he was asked whether these practices troubled him. At the time he replied:

No-one's perfect. No administration is impeccable and I don't suppose the Nixon administration was . . . But I also want to make it clear I didn't think it was either wrong or immoral, I'd be deceiving you if I suggested that.

This is the man with whom Mr Street has exchanged a form of words which purports to give an undertaking that the B52s will not carry nuclear arms. This is the man who drew up, with Mr Street, this exchange of notes which we understand are unsigned. This is the man who represents the Government that Senator MacGibbon and others claim we should trust implicitly, that we should not question and that we should have complete faith in because that is part of our agreement and part of our alliance. I just cannot believe the General, who was so deeply and personally involved in what was then the secret bombing in Cambodia, would think twice about breaking the very informal form of words that has been exchanged with Mr Street. Mr Street says that he gained the impression that the new American Administration means what it says. We can only hope that General Haig says what he means when he has confidential discussions with our Foreign Minister. The Labor Party is asking for a very firm form of words, a very firm agreement so that we can be absolutely sure that the B52s which will be staged through Darwin will not carry nuclear weapons. We must be sure and we must be able to make sure that we are told what is really happening. We ask no more than that. We can see nothing in the agreement drawn up by General Haig and Mr Street which gives us this feeling of safety.

Let me return to what the real possibilities are for Australia as a middle power, as Mr Street calls us, fortuitously placed between the Indian and Pacific Oceans. We are in a unique position to modify American views on the questions of escalation of big power rivalry and arms build-ups in the two regions. Mr Street dwells on the coincidental, shared concern of the Reagan Administration and the Australian Government on what he calls-I quote:

the grave implications of the remorseless military build-up by the Soviet Union and the need to maintain a military balance as a condition for stability and effective negotiations, about the need to improve consultation and co-ordination within the Western alliance.
Mr Street is adamant in his belief that-I quote:
The possession of adequate power is desirable precisely because it reduces the chances of armed conflict.
He says:
. . . preparedness and evident resolution diminish the prospect of war.

It is presumably this belief that has been and will be used to justify Australia's offer of the use of Australian bases to the United States to facilitate its deployment of forces in the Indian Ocean. It looks as though it is not going to stop at the proposition that B52 aircraft should use the Royal Australian Air Force base in Darwin. In the last week further evidence has come to light of the intentions of the United States in these regions where we so fortuitously find ourselves placed-the Indian Ocean, Asia and the Pacific. The United States Congress has been given an outline of the military umbrella proposed by the Reagan Administration for the region. It will involve an increasing obligation for Australia to toe the line. The Director of the United States Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs, Mr Richard Burt, told a House of Representatives sub-committee on international security that a United States presence in the area can provide the base for 'rapid response in many emergencies'. He suggested that allies with important military facilities and regional airfields and ports could 'provide access to permit deployments in times of crisis'. With obvious reference to Australia, Mr Burt said that the ability of the United States to deploy forces rapidly would depend on on-route facilities for refuelling and on overflight routes. He said:
Some positive results have been achieved but much greater effort is needed if we are to approach our requirements.
He went on to say that the State Department intended to hold a 'frank dialogue' with countries in the region and particularly to make it clear that:
. . . present arms control proposals for the Indian Ocean Area offer little prospect of enhancing security.

It is useful to know what the current thinking of the United States in relation to the Indian Ocean is. Australia, in the last decade, has taken a consistent line on the Indian Ocean in both the United Nations and the Commonwealth. This is an area in which, having a direct interest, we could usefully make our views known to the United States. We could actually make use of our unique position in the region and in the alliance by starting to practise what we preach. Since 1971 Australia has taken an attitude to the Indian Ocean which is recorded in our votes at the United Nations and, more recently, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting in New Delhi in September last year. It is worth remembering that only six months ago the Australian Prime Minister signed a communique which seems to have been negated by our latest agreement on the use of Darwin as a base for B52 aircraft. The communique, which was signed by the Prime Minister in September last year, and which will doubtless be reaffirmed by Australia at the forthcoming Commonwealth Government Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne-unless other CHOGM leaders dissociate themselves from Mr Fraser's double speak on our behalf-states:

Heads of Government noted with concern that, despite the expressed wishes of the littoral and hinterland States, great power military presence in the Indian Ocean has increased and that there has been a deterioration of peace and security in the Indian Ocean area.
They further noted with regret that recent events in the region, together with the worsening international situation, have caused a further build-up of great power military presence.

While regretting the suspension of the bilateral talks on arms limitation in the Indian Ocean between the Soviet Union and the United States and reaffirming their commitment to the ultimate establishment of a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean in accordance with the 1971 UN declaration, they called on the great powers to take active and effective steps to remove existing sources of tension in the area.

This, of course, was based on the United Nations declaration of 1971, which was also signed by Australia. This has been reaffirmed every year since, and I expect that it will be reaffirmed every year in the future. The declaration of the General Assembly calling for an Indian Ocean zone of peace states:
Calls upon the great powers in conformity with the Declaration, to enter into immediate consultations with the littoral States of the Indian Ocean with a view to:
(a) Halting the further escalation and expansionism of their military presence in the Indian Ocean;

(b) Eliminating from the Indian Ocean all bases, military installations and logistical supply facilities, the disposition of nuclear weapons and weapons of mass destruction and any manifestation of great power military presence in the Indian Ocean conceived in the context of great power rivalry.

Today we are faced with an escalation of that presence in the Indian Ocean. The Fraser Government has been voting at CHOGRM and the United Nations in favour of delimitarisation in the Indian Ocean, but at the same time it obviously has been actively encouraging our ally, the United States, to effect a further build-up here. In the light of the signing of these declarations we have invited the United States to use Darwin as a base for B52 aircraft and, what is more significant, for tanker aircraft-the KC135 aircraft. We know that the B52 aircraft is eminently suited to refuelling from such tankers, thus extending their range far across the Indian Ocean.

All we have is a loosely worded agreement. It is so loose that no one can take it seriously. The United States State Department now has the temerity, for the first time that anyone can remember, to warn the loyal Opposition in a democratic country to toe the line, to agree with United States policy in the area, to agree with the words of agreement which have been set down by General Haig and Mr Street. The United States State Department has the temerity to suggest that the Opposition in this country has no right to question the words in that agreement and to question whether that agreement provides sufficient safeguards for this country and particularly for the people of Darwin, and no right to make sure that in the future it is informed of what is being done in our own territory and in our own region by our own allies, of which we have not been informed in the past.

The Labor Party is asking that the agreement be made much tighter than it is now so that we can be sure that the use of this base and the deployment of these aeroplanes in Darwin by the United States is in agreement with our policy. We do not want to go back to the days to which Senator MacGibbon started to take us back. We do not want to go back to the days when Senator MacGibbon's predecessors were saying in this place that Australia was entering the war in Vietnam to prevent the downward thrust of China. We do not want to go back to the days when Australia was left in ignorance of the way in which that war was being conducted. Certainly, in relation to the deployment of these B52 aircraft, we do not want to go back to the days when we did not know what was happening on our own soil. We ask for a tighter agreement. We ask to be able to be absolutely certain that that base will not be used for nuclear weapons. The reassurances we have received have not been sufficient. The reassurance that Senator MacGibbon gave us yesterday, namely, that no one would seriously try to use B52 aircraft in the Persian Gulf, was answered today-the very next day-by a senior military officer in the United States.

We ask no more than that Australia be treated as an equal partner in the alliance, that Australia use its ability, knowledge and influence occasionally to voice its disagreement with the United States when it does disagree, and not just act as a servile partner which does as it is told. We do not enjoy any more than anybody else partisan differences such as this one in the area of foreign affairs or defence. But, as we were never consulted, as we were never asked about the situation, as this staging of B52 aircraft was obviously drummed up before the last election as an election gimmick, and as the people of this country were obviously misled into believing initially that United States defence personnel would be here at the request of the United States, we see no reason why we should have faith in the words of agreement put down by the present Foreign Minister or in any future agreement between that Foreign Minister and the present Secretary of State in the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was John Donne who said:

SPEECH.PARA: No man is an island, entire of itself; every man is a piece of the continent, a part of the main.

Australia is an island continent; but, if we take on John Donne's words, we cannot continue to exist as an island in the area of defence or in the area of trade. We have realised over the last few years that we have to make trade arrangements so that we can maintain our standard of living. I think that anybody in his right mind would realise that when it comes to defence we have to make similar arrangements.

If we looked into the future and tried to foretell the sorts of hostilities in which we might be involved we would realise that in any hostility other than a minor incursion on to our land we would have to be involved with a strong, reliable and powerful friend, and for that reason we make treaties. When Senator Hamer spoke to this paper he mentioned the treaties we have entered into. We know quite well that exercises take place regularly involving the defence forces of our nation and those of other nations with whom we have treaties. Indeed, a major exercise takes place every two years in the Shoalwater Bay area. Members of our Defence Force travel around the world to exercise with other forces, as do the ships of the Royal Australian Navy and the aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force.

Basically, what we are discussing, and this seems to have been lost in all the rhetoric of the debate, is surveillance and navigational exercises. The Opposition has said, and undoubtedly there would be some argument, that it was not consulted beforehand. Unfortunately, I am not in a position to say that we should or should not do that. However, members of the Opposition have made a case that if they had been told a little more about the matter beforehand maybe we would not have had the claims and counter-claims which have gone on in the media to this point of time. It is unfortunate that that has happened, but I still do not see that as an excuse for some of the wild exaggerations that have been taking place. Basically, we are dealing with navigational and surveillance exercises, and those matters are covered in the agreement. The two points which mention that state:
the B52 flights shall be for sea surveillance in the Indian Ocean area and for navigation training.
the agreement of the Australian Government would need to be obtained before the facilities at RAAF Base, Darwin could be used in support of any other category of operations.

In the debate that statement has been termed as the form of words, and we have been warned by Senator Grimes that Senator Evans, who I understand will follow me in this debate, will concentrate on that form of words.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not necessarily.

—Not necessarily, but perhaps to some extent. At least Senator Grimes has done us a service by warning us that Senator Evans will concentrate on this form of words. We know from experience that when the debate in this chamber turns to legal jargon and the legal brethren on both sides start to debate the form of words the rest of us switch off. At least we have been warned and we know part of the tack Senator Evans will take. It will be our own fault if we are caught sitting listening to him.
—Just wait and see. You will be pleasantly surprised.
—Really? Is that a threat or a promise? I make the point that the form of words used in the agreement states:

SPEECH.PARA: the agreement of the Australian Government would need to be obtained before the facilities at RAAF Base, Darwin could be used in support of any other category of operations.

The fact is that it is a surveillance and navigational exercise. The navigational part of that training is taking place over north Queensland, where low level navigational exercises are being carried out. Why on earth would these aircraft carry nuclear bombs or any other sorts of weapons on navigation and surveillance exercises? The reasons just escape me. We are worried about the capability of the B52 aircraft to carry nuclear weapons, but we do not seem to be worried about any other sort of aircraft. As I have mentioned, we take part in various exercises. Other aircraft which transit across Australia are quite capable of carrying nuclear weapons, yet to date we do not seem to have had any hassle about those aircraft.

I refer also to the cruise missiles coming on stream. I have read articles in the ordinary Press without reading any that are confidential, about the possibility of being able to carry on and deploy cruise missiles from the ordinary civilian aircraft which transit our airspace and use our air fields numerous times on any day of the week. To return to the aspect I was discussing, why would these aircraft carry nuclear weapons on surveillance and navigational flights?

The final B52 aircraft-the H model-was delivered in June 1962. That makes the youngest B52 almost 19 years old; there is nothing new about it. All the manuals have been written on its ability to carry bombs and on crew training. Obviously, every so often as new crews come on stream, the training of the crews would have to be updated and the planes would doubtedly carry a weapons load to simulate the weight involved, the fuel burn, and so forth. There would be no necessity to do that over Australia. It could be done over the ocean where nobody is worried. So there is nothing new about the B52s ability to carry bombs. All that has been done before.

Mention has been made of accidents involving aircraft carrying nuclear weapons, and indeed, that is a cause for concern. I think Senator Robertson mentioned that matter in his speech. Recently an article appeared in one of the national newspapers tabulating accidents involving aircraft carrying nuclear weapons. The significant thing about that article was that in not one case did the nuclear component of the bomb detonate. There were explosions of the high-explosive trigger, but I dare say if an aircraft carrying high explosive iron bombs had been involved a far worse situation would have developed. I suppose it is reasonably easy to sketch the main principles of a nuclear bomb, but a rather intricate device is required to cause the implosion which is necessary to cause the explosion. Thus we find that there have been minor explosions in all these accidents. Of course in the explosion of the detonating high-explosive material there has been a release of radioactive material, because that is what the bomb is all about. Nevertheless, because of the very nature of the radioactive material the explosion has been confined to a very small area and contained with no great problem and, as I have said, with not nearly the problems that would have occurred in the crash of an aircraft carrying high-explosive, large, normal, iron bombs.

It is quite significant that not once in this debate has it been mentioned that we now know that the Russian forces are deploying backfire aircraft at Cam Ranh Bay. Forgetting the missile part of it, that puts Australia well within range-I think almost without refuelling, but perhaps with one refuelling-of the backfire bomber deployed at Cam Ranh Bay which is capable of carrying nuclear weapons. That puts Australian targets well within the range of a normal, manned aircraft deployed by the Russian air force.

Much has been said about prime targets, and Pine Gap, the North West Cape and Darwin Airport have been mentioned. These are relatively small targets, and I suppose that in the event of a war, if politicians had a hand in running it, we would probably try to do something on a cost effective basis. I think it is rather ludicrous to take out a target with a missile or a weapon which costs far more than the target which is being taken out. Although we know that there are too many nuclear weapons in the world today, they certainly are not being manufactured like lollies in a factory which are manufactured in the hundreds every day. If a country decided to use nuclear weapons it certainly would want to pick its targets, and a nuclear weapon certainly would not be needed to render inoperative a place such as Pine Gap or the North West Cape. It would be absolutely ludicrous to suggest that Darwin Airport could suddenly become a nuclear target.

We realise that any airport that is capable of taking defence aircraft obviously would be marked on the maps of the world powers as a possible target. We have to go back only as far as the Israeli wars to realise what can be done. Even if our own common sense does not tell us we can see that it certainly does not need a nuclear weapon to make an airport inoperative. The Israelis proved that just a few small well-placed iron bombs can render an airport quite inoperative without causing any large-scale destruction. It would be ridiculous to state that all of a sudden Darwin has become a nuclear target.

If hostilities broke out-it would be the unanimous opinion of honourable senators that they would not be looking forward to that day-what would we see as the role of the B52s which were carrying nuclear or normal ordnance? We know quite well that the aircraft are capable of being refuelled in the air. They are a long-range aircraft. This is one of the reasons why they have been slotted into the US Air Force for use as surveillance aircraft. The aircraft do have a tremendously long range, as Senator MacGibbon mentioned in his speech. With their normal look-down radar capability for targeting for normal bombing raids they have a tremendous capability for surveillance and keeping check on what the Russian naval forces are doing in the Indian and Pacific oceans.

If hostilities broke out and there were a need to deploy the bombers as a nuclear force why would the Americans want to use Darwin anyhow? It becomes a whole new ball game. As it is, Darwin is currently being used for rest and recreation-mainly rest. Senator MacGibbon mentioned the fact that Darwin is more suitable than many other airports because the runways are wide enough to take the outriggers. Can honourable senators imagine the scenario of an operational crew about to take off on a real bombing mission from Guam and, upon entering the operation room, the captain saying: 'Well, fellows, what do you say if we take off half an hour early and drop in at Darwin for tea and bikkies'? The whole thing becomes absolutely ridiculous. That is the sort of thing we are talking about. There is no way in the world that the bomber crews would be dropping in at Darwin for tea and bikkies which is what they are doing now. The crews rest there now so that they can go on a rather longer mission out over the Indian Ocean. Using the aerial tankers which have been mentioned, the bombers would obviously fly straight to the target.

I find that the whole argument has become ludicrous. As I said at the beginning of my speech, the B52s are being used basically for surveillance missions and navigational exercises. America is a friendly power. It is using our facilities. I, for one, welcome the Americans and congratulate the Government. I welcome the agreement which helps cement the relationship and the friendship which we have with the people of the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the degree of love, trust, affection, friendship or respect one has for the United States, everyone at least seems to be agreed about one thing, and that is that nobody in Australia wants to see, at present or in the reasonably foreseeable strategic future, US B52 bombers or other aircraft flying over or touching down in Australia while carrying nuclear weapons. Certainly that is the position of some 62 per cent of all Australians as indicated by the latest gallup poll which was taken in February and published in the Sydney Sun of 13 March. Certainly it is the position of the Australian Labor Party, as has been articulated by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, the Deputy Leader, Mr Lionel Bowen, and every one of the speakers from the Opposition in both chambers who have entered the debate on the subject. Certainly it is also the position of the Australian Democrats as that position has been articulated by Senator Mason in this place. It seems, on the face of it, also to be the position of the Australian Government, but whether it is, or not, I suggest, requires a little closer examination. I will come back to this aspect in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for that general attitude, if it is a general attitude, are clear enough. They hardly need to be spelt out in elaborate detail. In general strategic terms all of us, I think, would like to see Australia, the South Pacific area and the Indian Ocean remaining, as long as humanly possible, nuclear-free zones. That is the basis upon which we signed the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We simply do not want to be dragged into the world-wide network of nuclear attack and counter-attack forces. We do not want to do anything which, as some people have said, will 'up the ante' in strategic terms. We do not want to create in Australia any new nuclear targets, especially in or near a major city. This, of course, is exactly what will happen when Darwin becomes a base for the use of long-range nuclear bombers or the tankers that can refuel them in mid-flight.

We are all concerned about the possibility of nuclear accidents, the possibility of which is obviously much enhanced with overflights of planes carrying nuclear weapons. I imagine that I scarcely need to remind this audience of the famous crash of a B52 back in January 1961 in Goldsborough, North Carolina, when a 24 megaton bomb was splashed all over the countryside and five of the six interlocking triggers on the bomb failed. Even if everyone's general position is as I have outlined, three important questions arise for us to look at as a result of the signing of this agreement. The first big question is whether the views that I have outlined are in fact shared by the present Australian Government. Is it the case that this Government does not now or in the reasonably foreseeable strategic future want to see B52s carrying nuclear weapons over, out of or through Australia? On the face of it that may seem to be the case but I, for one, am not so sure. I ask honourable senators to look at the terms of the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) which remains the first, and indeed still almost the last, word from the Government on the subject. The Prime Minister said:

. . . it has been agreed between the Foreign Minister and the Secretary of State that the aircraft staging through Darwin under the arrangements now agreed for surveillance flights and navigation training will be unarmed and will carry no bombs.
I am referring to the famous Street-Haig unsigned, unheaded piece of paper in the Washington safe. The Prime Minister then made a further statement to the following effect:
The Australian Government has a firm policy that aircraft carrying nuclear weapons will not be allowed to fly over or stage through Australia without its prior . . . agreement.

It may be that at first blush that seems to be clear enough, but when we look at the statement we find that all it is really doing is saying that as a procedural matter we will have to agree before such flights are made. It does not say that we will not agree. It does not say that by the time the first flights come in we will not have agreed. It does not address itself to that question. It does not say that we will not agree if we happen to be asked by the United States about particular flights or flights generally in a year's time, a month's time, a week's time or even a day's time. The point is that there is no expression of concern at the implications of nuclear-armed bombers flying in or over Australia, an expression of concern that might have been expected in the Prime Minister's statement if the present Government really were opposed, absolutely and unequivocally, to this kind of development. All that has been made in the statement is the purely formal point that we will have to agree in the future if these flights are to be made. For all that we and the Australian public know, such agreement might already have been made or something in the nature of a contingent agreement might already have been made by this Government.

The surrounding circumstances of this whole affair, I suggest, give some weight to the possibilities I have mentioned. For a start, the Australian Government, it must be said, has been desperately anxious-puppy dog anxious in fact-to offer its support to the United States as the United States evolves its plans to establish a major new military umbrella across the whole Pacific and especially the Indian Ocean area. Of course, those plans are evolving with much greater rapidity with the new set of cowboys, green berets and Strangeloves that now are occupying the United States White House.

Last year we were falling over ourselves to offer home-porting facilities for the United States fleet in Western Australia. Indeed, there is some evidence of frustration on our part that the Pentagon in the United States clearly is not falling over itself in that respect, nor is the State Department. As was effectively admitted by the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, in his answer to a question without notice from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, on 12 March, we are now falling over ourselves not to respond to a United States request to aid B52 flights, but rather to invite the United States to make a request of us in this matter. It is an exact repetition, which cannot help but be noticed, of the circumstances in which, as now has been amply documented, we were drawn inexorably into the Vietnam war.

It simply cannot be assumed that this Government, any more than any of its conservative predecessors, is in the habit of telling the truth concerning key elements of our relationship with the United States. It certainly cannot be assumed that the overt terms of treaties, agreements and statements can be left to speak for themselves. There has been almost a tradition of secret agreements and undertakings on key issues. Let me give some examples of that. One famous one was in 1963 at the time of the establishment of the North West Cape base when all sorts of public noises were made by the then Prime Minister about the maintenance of Australian sovereignty in the use of that facility, whereas in fact at the same time there was an extraordinary exchange of letters between the then Minister for External Affairs, Mr Barwick, and the United States Ambassador, Mr Battle, agreeing to what was in effect a complete abdication of Australian interests in the operation and conduct of that base. That exchange of letters-the Barwick-Battle correspondence-was revealed only in 1973 when the Labor Government renegotiated the terms of that agreement.

That correspondence and that historical example become particularly relevant because of the reference to consultation in paragraph (VII) of the present B52 agreement, it being remembered that the key expression in issue in the Barwick-Battle correspondence was just that same word. Barwick, on behalf of Australian interests, made it perfectly clear that he regarded consultation as requiring nothing in the nature of Australian control or second-guessing of anything the United States might do or might be minded to do in the operation of that facility.

Another example, a particularly clear one, emerges from Booker's volume The Last Domino, supplemented by a review by the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, in the Australian Financial Review of 24 August 1979. That related to the situation at the time of konfrontasi between Indonesia and its neighbours, when Barwick returned from the United States and announced that the United States would support us if our ships were attacked in any way by Indonesia as a result of the escalating conflict or likely conflict in our immediate neighbourhood. Barwick reported that he had received an assurance to that effect-again, lodged in a Washington embassy safe-from the then Secretary of State.

That arrangement or agreement, such as it was, subsequently was countermanded by President Kennedy with no equivalent publicity being given to that subsequent development on the basis that the ANZUS treaty contained no specific obligation to come to our aid in the circumstances contemplated. In fact, not only was no publicity given to that countermanding by President Kennedy, but also at least three times Barwick made public announcements that the United States would in fact come to our assistance. I am referring to these matters as examples of the impossibility of relying on public expressions of good faith about the kinds of agreements which are entered into by our conservative governments and our United States allies.

A third example of exactly the same sort of situation was, as I have mentioned already in passing, the highly secret series of steps by which we came to be involved up to our ears in the Vietnam war, with the Australian public being systematically deceived in the process about who was requesting whom to do what. That was an exercise which now has been amply documented in a number of books, most recently, for example, in Alan Renouf's book The Frightened Country. It may be that I am exaggerating these concerns. It may be that the Government presently is committed-indeed, firmly committed- to keeping nuclear weapons out of Australia unless and until a major international strategic crisis of a kind that cannot presently be at all foreseen erupts.

I say to Senator Puplick, who is attempting to interject, that if that is the case I, the Opposition and the Australian public would welcome an obsolutely unequivocal assurance to that effect from the Australian Government, an assurance which simply has not been forthcoming in anything that has been said by any Government spokesman on this issue so far. There is a large gulf between saying, on the one hand, that we will have to agree before any such thing happens and, on the other hand, that we will not agree. It is that latter step that no Government pronouncement has been prepared to take.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you foresee any possible circumstance in which agreement might be given?

—Let those contingencies or possibilities be laid down. Let the Government refer to the kind of strategic circumstance, presently unforeseen, that might justify it. I am not saying necessarily that it would be appropriate for there to be an absolute, negative, binding statement for the future; I am saying only that it is very appropriate to say something that is a little more satisfactory in substantive terms as to the situation at the moment than is the statement that agreement will be necessary. I want the Government to come right out and say: 'We have not agreed on an absolute or a contingent basis so far and we will not agree in the present and reasonably foreseeable strategic circumstances'. But not even that small step has been taken. That is one of the reasons for the Opposition's concern about the terms of the agreement. But there are other problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The second big issue I raise for discussion and express concern about is this: If we do not agree with nuclear-armed flights and if we are unlikely to do so in the reasonably foreseeable future, why is that not included in the terms of the treaty? It should be made absolutely clear to everyone who looks at the agreement, but the formal treaty, the treaty that is constituted by the exchange of notes-the only documentation that is enforceable as a matter of international law-is quite silent on that. The only reference to the question of whether B52s will carry nuclear weapons and, if so, under what circumstances is contained in the famous unsigned, unheaded piece of paper dictated to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, by Mr Haig, as representing appropriate language to go into the statement by the Prime Minister on the issue. Legally speaking and in every other way, one is reminded of Sam Goldwyn's famous statement about oral contracts: 'They are not worth the paper they are written on'. Neither is that document worth the paper it is written on. The agreement, if anything, specifically contemplates that in fact nuclear-armed flights will fly over or operate out of Australia in some circumstances.

Despite Senator Collard's dire prognostications, this is the only time I want to refer-I will do so very briefly-to the actual text of the agreement in order to make my point. On just looking at paragraph (I) of the agreement-I will not even bother to read it out-it is obvious that it refers only to flights using Darwin facilities. It states that those flights shall be for sea surveillance and navigational purposes only, with the agreement of the Australian Government being required before they are used for any other purpose. But there are several things to note about that paragraph. In the first place, it makes no reference to other flights over Australia being only for surveillance and navigational training. The only explicit reference to the limited purpose of flights is made in paragraph (I) and it is concerned only with flights operating in and out of Darwin. It does not refer to other flights over Australian territory. If we look at the second sentence, and even if we give it its full and unambiguous literal force, it means only that the agreement of the Australian Government must be obtained before Darwin can be used for other purposes. It does not say that this agreement itself, the documentary agreement constituted by the exchange of notes, must be renegotiated before that can happen.

The second sub-paragraph to which I refer to support this proposition that the treaty itself does anticipate that nuclear flights will in fact occur is sub-paragraph (VII), the language of which very clearly indeed contemplates that nuclear flights are envisaged. The language used is that of strategic developments, which, as I understand it, is a diplomatic term in common parlance as a reference to nuclear developments. Further, the language of sub-paragraph (VII), referring as it does to 'consultations' and 'full and timely information', could not be more reminiscent of the language that was central to the Barwick-Battle correspondence about the North West Cape base in 1963 to which I have referred. I am not saying, as I think some people rather too briskly have said, that sub-paragraph (VII) overrides sub-paragraph (I). I am only saying that the reference to consultations being conducted would be unnecessary if sub-paragraph (I) was far-reaching and covered the field to the extent that the Government proponents claim it does.

The other sub-paragraph to which I refer is sub-paragraph (VIII), the language of which again gives the game away, relating as it does to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty-a reference which only makes sense on the assumption that what is being contemplated is something like the transit of nuclear weapons on or over Australia, which may in fact amount to a breach of that treaty.

Despite Senator Collard's predictions, I do not make too much of the linguistic points about the different sub-paragraphs of the treaty, about possible inconsistencies or ambiguities in its language. What I am concerned to do rather is to emphasise that its literal language, at face value, does clearly contemplate that, without there being any amendment of the specific terms of this formal treaty there will at some time be armed nuclear flights operating either out of Darwin or by way of overflying the country and not going near Darwin. All that is necessary for the literal terms of this treaty to apply is for the Australian Government to agree to the use of Darwin for nuclear flight facilities. The agreement of the Australian Government is not even necessary when it is overflights not involving Darwin that are being contemplated. That is what the literal terms of the agreement amount to. That is why we are unhappy with the literal terms of that agreement.

The nub of the whole criticism then comes back to this: If the Government does not want, as Senator Puplick and others on his side of the chamber seem to be claiming, armed B52 flights and if it is not going to agree to armed B52 flights in the immediately foreseeable future, why did the Australian Government not insist on the insertion of a formal clause to this effect? It is just no answer to say that because we trust the Americans it is unnecessary, because if we trust them to that extent then surely we do not need formal agreements at all. If oral arrangements or semi-blank pieces of paper are enough, because of the nature of the trust, confidence, friendship and affection which subsist between our two countries, why do we have this formal treaty at all?

If we have some of the things in the treaty why do we not have the lot? If we felt that the treaty was necessary to formalise part of the agreement, why was it not necessary to formalise the whole of the agreement? Why is that one key passage which everyone has been looking for, which the Prime Minister has been asserting and which the United States has been asserting in non-treaty language been left out of the treaty itself? There are two possible explanations. One is that the Australian Government did not seek the incorporation of such a paragraph or put up any kind of a fight to secure it; that is, we did not mind, on this view, being in a position where we do not have to be consulted at all with respect to nuclear overflights and we can agree at a moment's notice without the agreement itself being renegotiated in respect of flights out of Darwin. That is consistent enough with the supine posture that we have adopted in terms of our relationships with great and powerful friends in the past and it may well be the explanation for the present absence of that paragraph.

The other alternative which has been mooted is that the United States Government was asked to insert such a paragraph but flatly refused to do so, either because it had no intention of honouring it, or perhaps more likely because difficulties would have arisen with those other countries, especially Japan and West Germany, where there are very vague agreements, not explicit on these matters, which are thought to be in everyone's interest. In Japan, because it is undoubtedly the case that all domestic political hell would break loose if it was known that the American ships and aircraft were carrying nuclear weapons, treaties are silent on these matters and the questions are simply not asked. But it is obvious that either way, whatever the explanation is and despite what credibility can be given to that latter explanation of the absence of such a paragraph, the situation is still thoroughly unsatisfactory from Australia's point of view. A lot better explanation has to be given for that omission than the nonsense which is being peddled about by the Government at the moment, not explicitly addressing itself to this omission, not even acknowledging overtly that there is a problem but simply repeating ad nauseam that we have to trust our great and powerful ally.

The third and final big question that I raise for consideration is that even if the agreement, read literally, does require Australian agreement in turn before nuclear flights are staged through Darwin and even if, beyond the literal terms of that agreement, the United States Government is making, as it seems to have been doing in the last day or so, statements amounting to assurances of that kind, can the literal text of that agreement or can the literal text of that statement or those assurances be relied upon? Is there not a potential that we will be exposed to straight-out deception by the United States? That is not a question which I ask lightly because I do have a profound respect for Americans and most things American and I do believe it is right, proper and in Australia's best interests to have a general relationship of alliance with the United States.

There are a number of considerations which demand that that very sensitive question be asked nonetheless. The first such consideration is the sheer incredibility of the notion, despite what Senator Hamer, Senator Collard and other people on the other side of this chamber have been saying, that B52s will not be employed at some time for the purpose for which they were expressly designed; that is, long-range nuclear bombing. Certainly they do have and certainly they are capable of performing a surveillance function, quite effectively and efficiently in large tracts such as the southern Indian Ocean, but there are other effective means of surveillance such as satellites and mid-air refuel surveillance aircraft and there are certainly a number of other more specifically purpose-designed aircraft available for that purpose. If it is surveillance that we are talking about it may be an explanation, but can it possibly be the only explanation. If it is the only explanation why do we have six KC135 refuelling aircraft lined up on the tarmac, as is proposed, in Darwin servicing only three B52s coming in and out when, as it is apparently well known to people who know about these things, one such tanker aircraft can in fact service the mid-flight refuelling needs of two B52 aircraft? It seems that there is a substantial over-abundance of tanker flight facilities for the kind of surveillance function that is here being contemplated.

They are only questions. I do not have the answers for those questions, but they are questions which are certainly brought to mind by the facts so far made available to us. Similarly, one simply makes the observation that it is a hell of a long way to be flying simply for training purposes, even in the context of the Cape York type of exercises which are already a familiar part of our military relationship. It may be that the B52s are to be used to carry, if not nuclear arms, then at least, as has been suggested in recent Press reports, long range multipurpose non-nuclear missiles. That too raises very significant strategic questions for Australia because it involves the use of these aircraft in an explicitly military role-something very different from the non-military or non-hostile surveillance and training purposes we have been told about so far.

There is simply no doubt in all these respects that the United States is rapidly developing plans for the extension of its military umbrella into the whole Indian Ocean-Pacific Ocean area. Bryan Boswell's article in the Australian on 25 March made it very clear, on the basis of United States information on the public record, that this was so. It is being anticipated in the United States by senior military planning personnel that Australia will play a crucial role in these kinds of developments. For all these reasons, there is a simple incredibility for me and for the Opposition about the notion that the B52s are simply some kind of glorified Orion being used for surveillance and training purposes, with no thought whatsoever being given to their more hostile potential in projecting military force into the Indian Ocean.

Another consideration that has to be acknowledged when one is addressing oneself to the question of whether there might be deception now or contemplated in the language of the United States assurances, the language of this treaty, is that whether or not one likes it, United States administrations in the past have not always dealt kindly with the truth in military and foreign affairs matters. Some of the best known illustrations that should be mentioned in this respect are, of course, the 1964 Gulf of Tongkin resolution sponsored by President Johnson to give him the war powers he needed in Vietnam. That resolution was premised on a denial by Mr McNamara, the then Defense Secretary, to Congress that the United States had any part in the operations which precipitated the North Vietnamese attack on the United States destroyer in question. That was a classic case of deliberate deception by the United States Government of its own public and its own Congress. Again in 1966 there was the famous example of Dean Rusk telling the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the South East Asia Treaty Organisation committed the United States to its course of action in South Vietnam-a straightforward deceit of the United States Congress and the United States public. Another very famous example was the systematic deception in 1969 and 1970 of the American people by President Nixon and his Secretary of State Kissinger in relation to the secret bombing of Cambodia-one of the most appalling series of instances of such behaviour in modern military and diplomatic history. That sequence of events was brilliantly documented by William Shawcross in this book Sideshow: Kissinger, Nixon and the Destruction of Cambodia. If that is the way United States administrations in the past have been capable of dealing with their Congress and with their people, it takes a fairly large jump of faith to believe that they would have any serious scruples about deceiving a middle power of middling to minor significance in the United States view of the world, especially when that middle power has a government which has no mind of its own and which is generally pathetically anxious to please.

I have sought to identify a series of major questions on this whole B52 issue to which simply insufficient answers or no answers at all have been given by the present Government. If this Government wants, as the Prime Minister has claimed he wants, a genuinely bipartisan policy on these matters, it will simply have to take the Opposition into its confidence while such arrangements are still being negotiated and not just demand obeisance or treat acceptance by us of these arrangements after the event, after the negotiations are complete, as something to be taken for granted. The failure of the Government to take the Opposition into its confidence on this occasion and the failure to give satisfactory answers to the kinds of questions which I and the Opposition have been raising leave one able to reach no other conclusion than that this Government has something to hide over the whole B52 question. The Government had better rethink its position rather quickly on these matters, because if one thing is clear it is that the Australian public is now much too well informed and has a much too acute sense of history to allow an escalation of military involvement of the kind that has happened in the past. The Government had better get it all right because this is simply an issue which will not go away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak briefly on this issue while at the same time wondering just what is the point of speaking at this stage of such a debate. The fact is that the Australian people have been presented with a fait accompli, and all the talking in the world will not alter it. We can talk here until the proverbial cows come home and the result will be exactly the same. Like my colleague Senator Evans, who has just resumed his seat, I am perturbed at some of the ambiguities, some of the double-talk, some of the gobbledegook in the document that the Australian Government is supposed to have agreed to. An example of such ambiguities is given in an article in this morning's Melbourne Age by Russell Skelton. He referred to a United States Government document approved by both the State and Defence departments and sent to the United States Ambassador in Canberra. According to Skelton, the document says that these aircraft will be unarmed; yet further on we are told that the aircraft will be equipped with a gun. How hypocritical can one be? How much double-talk can we hear. An unarmed aircraft armed with a gun! Quite frankly, it appears to me from this article by Skelton that the whole agreement is full of such gobbledegook. According to Skelton, the document also says that the agreement specifies that Australian Government approval be obtained before B52 missions are changed from reconnaisance and training, and before the facilities are used for any other category of operations. Skelton wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, it remains the policy of this Government neither to confirm or deny the presence of nuclear weapons on particular missions.

Does that mean that the Australian Government will not be told when these aircraft are equipped with nuclear weapons, or does it just mean that the Australian people will not be told? That is one of the reasons why I am particularly concerned about the way this matter has been treated. It seems to me that Mr Street was sold the proverbial pig in a poke while he was in Washington discussing the matter with the United States military. It is noticeable, as Senator Evans recalled, that we seem to have walked into this one in very much the same manner as we sent our first troops into Vietnam-lies, lies, lies all the way. It was not until some years later, after the death of some 400 young Australians, that we found out the facts.

The Government is to be congratulated on its handling of the debate on this matter because it played its cards fairly well. The statement was introduced in both Houses on 11 March. The other House was off the air and the Senate was on the air. My Leader, Senator Button, had the document in his hand for a few short minutes, and he and Senator Robertson were the only two senators permitted to speak that evening while the Senate was on the air. Both Senator Chipp and I were looking for the call when Senator Messner moved for the adjournment of the debate. I guess that it was part of the Government's intention to hide the debate from the Australian public as well as it could.

Basically, I do not want to talk too much about B52 bombers, but I do want to draw some analogies between the current situation with regard to B52 bombers and Australian history. I recall the history in this way: For many years the people and the governments of this nation perceived that if ever we were in trouble a foreign power would come to our aid. That foreign power, of course, was England-the mother country, as she was referred to in days of yore. Because of that belief the flower of Australian youth was sent to Gallipoli, to Egypt and to the fields of Flanders, and approximately 60,000 of them, largely under the command of incompetent English field-marshals and other officers, were slaughtered or massacred. Those officers had very little-if any-knowledge of the trials and tribulations of the men in the fields of Flanders or in Gallipoli, the horror of war, the mud, the slush, the snow and the rain. So Australia, as insurance against the day when we might be attacked, was prepared to lay down the lives of 60,000 young men and tens of thousands of men were wounded and mentally and psychologically crippled. They returned to Australia to take up their role in life as best they could.

That was the price which Australia was prepared to pay on the supposition that some day England would come to our aid. What happened? Of course we all know that in 1939 when the British Government declared war it was immediately followed by the Australian Government. As quickly as we could in Australia we rounded up tens of thousands of young Australians, some of whom had never worked because of the Great Depression which the capitalist system had forced on this country at that stage of the game, and marched them off to war. Many thousands of them had a one-way ticket. They were sent to England and to the Middle East and they were sent to Canada to train as air force crews. There was hardly an area of the early conflict in the 1939-45 war in which Australians were not in the field in some capacity.

Men were thrown into battle, because of the haste with which the operation was orchestrated, with very little training, very poor equipment and with little or no air support. There was early glee-I suppose one could say-back home when we were shown films of one Australian digger rounding up and marching off what appeared to be thousands of Italian prisoners of war. I think those films gave us all a fairly false impression. We had the impression that the Australian soldiers were as good as Australian soldiers had ever been and that they were well equipped. The Italians were the most cunning and perhaps the gamest people of the lot because when war came in 1940 they took the very wise decision of voting with their feet. Thousands of them spent the war in prisoner of war camps in Australia, but at least they went home alive. They had a two-way ticket to the war, unlike thousands of Australians who opposed them.

Then the war became fair dinkum and the Australians were put against the highly organised, highly mechanised troops of General Rommel. My colleague, Senator McAuliffe, was one of those troops. He now laughingly refers to himself as one of the Benghazi harriers because for the first time for a long time Australians were put to flight and many an Australian ended his one-way ticket trip to the Middle East at that stage. That was as far as some got in the war. I repeat: This is because this country and the Government believed that some great foreign power would come to our aid if ever we were attacked. Of course, it did not happen. When the chips were down in 1942 and Japan made her thrust southward-Senator Carrick will recall this as vividly as I do-the Australian Government called upon the English Government for help, and it was not there. So every Australian who laid down his or her life in war from the time this colony was founded until that day had in fact laid down his or her life in vain. Australia and its people had paid a premium and when the demand was made on the policy, the insurer was broke. The insurer was bankrupt in that regard. The Australian Government of the day, as we well recalled, had to go to another foreign power to seek assistance.

Churchill said at the time: 'I am very sorry, but if Australia goes down, so be it. We will resurrect Australia after we clean up the mess in Europe.' Had it not been for the gall of the Prime Minister of the day, John Curtin, Australian troops would never have been allowed to leave the Middle East. Many of them hurried back home in an attempt to thwart the Japanese thrust towards this continent. As far as England and Churchill were concerned, they were prepared to allow Australia to go under. That was the best we could get, with approximately 70,000 to 80,000 Australians dead in colonial wars, after paying that premium on a policy which was never honoured. Of course, those of us who are old enough well recall the joy and the pleasure which we had when the announcement was made that America was coming to our aid.
