We all well recall the pride which we had in seeing American troops on Australian soil.

Quite frankly-I do not deride any soldier-I suggest to the Senate and to Australia that if those American troops had been put to the test in the first few months they were in Australia they would not have been able to fight their way out of the proverbial wet paper bag because they were as green as leeks. That is no reflection on them because every soldier has to go through a period of training. Despite that, it did the Australian people's hearts no end of good to know that at least America thought something of us. Regretfully, it seems to me that we have lived under the false premise that because America came to our aid in 1942, she will always come to our aid and because of that we have this need to bend our knee, to dip our cap to America. On the same basis, Greece, Crete and the people of France and Belgium and goodness knows who would be forever and a day genuflecting and dipping their lids to Australians. But we do not expect that and I do not know why we take the opposite point of view in regard to America.

Let us be perfectly honest about this; America came to the aid of Australia in 1942 not because we were white Anglo-Saxons, or nice people or because we belonged to the British Empire. The American Government decided to send troops to Australia purely and simply out of a military consideration. The motivation was military. The motivation was that Australia was an ideal base from which to prepare for the day to roll back the Japanese tide to Tokyo. Let us be perfectly honest about that and not be caught in high-faluting nonsense about it or be carried away with rhetoric and all of the bull dust that has emanated surrounding the battle of the Coral Sea and 101 other silly damn celebrations which have been carried on in this country from that day on.

America sent army, navy and airforce troops to Australia in 1942 out of purely military considerations. Had Australia not been in this geographical position the Americans, in all probability, would have sent those troops somewhere else where it would have been to its advantage so to do. As I said, because of this false premise which we have lived under, this propaganda which has been pushed about by Prime Ministers and by governments in the intervening years, somehow some people in this country feel that we still owe a great debt to America. I do not think I am the last Australian nationalist, but it does irk me to find the Government of the country to which I belong continually genuflecting to a foreign power and I do not give a tuppenny dam whether it is Russia, China, England or any other power. I believe it is totally wrong. This silly damn, nonsense, pardon my French, has gone on to the point that Australian pride, Australian integrity and Australian ability to act independently have been submerged and in fact virtually suffocated by the Australian body politic.

The same sort of nonsense that was pushed around for all those years was one reason this nation was able to be slipped so easily in the ANZUS Treaty, the Pacific security treaty. I think Senator Evans had something to say about the ANZUS Treaty. It is not worth the paper it is written on, like all treaties. Those of us who are old enough will recall the way Adolf Hitler signed treaties, then tore them up like confetti as his armies raped central Europe in 1938, 1939 and 1940. Treaties were nothing to him. He realised what they were-pieces of paper-white paper, black words, two or more signatures, not worth a tuppenny dam, not worth the paper they were written on. To prove my point let me read Article I of the Pacific security treaty between Australia, New Zealand and the United States which came into force on 29 April 1952. The Article states:

The Parties undertake, as set forth in the Chapter of the United Nations, to settle any international disputes in which they may be involved by peaceful means in such a manner that international peace and security and justice are not endangered and to refrain in their international relations from the threat or use of force in any manner inconsistent with the purposes of the United Nations.

Put that statement alongside our actions and America's actions in both Korea and Vietnam. Surely it proves that document is not worth the paper it is written on because in both those instances, just to cite two examples, the Treaty was broken. If America wants to come to Australia to defend us it will do so if it perceives such action to be in its interests so to do, not because we have a treaty. If it perceives such action not to be in its interests all the treaties in the world will be torn up or shot through with legal words by some clever lawyer in the Pentagon. He will say 'It really does not mean that at all; we are very sorry Australia' like Churchill said in 1942. He said: 'You can go under; we have got other fish to fry'. I do not know why Australian Governments continue with this cock and bull story about this great and powerful ally on the other side of the Pacific. Sure, it is a great and powerful ally but why has not this nation learned? We have been let down once. There is the old adage that I learned on my mother's knee-once caught, twice shy. Everybody learns that very early in life as I am sure you did, Mr Acting Deputy President. The first time one of your schoolmasters did you for a marble or an ice-cream you learned the lesson-once caught, twice shy. It seems to me that this nation does not want to learn that lesson. Let down by one big foreign power in 1942 we are prepared to carry on ad infinitum and put ourselves into a situation in which we could well be let down again. We have failed to learn the lesson.

Let me continue my speech about these B52 bombers with this theme. I have already said that we genuflect, we dip our lid to these people in America, to the Pentagon. I have a good deal of time for the people of America. There are times when, I suppose because one does not express oneself as clearly as one should, people are able to take a rise at, have a shot at or brand one as anti-American. Let me say that I served alongside American troops during World War II and I have a good deal of respect for them as I have for American people. I have no respect whatsoever for the Pentagon because of the lies which have been told-this was referred to by my colleague Senator Evans-and which have come out of that office in the last 15 or 20 years. Let us also be mindful of the fact that at the present time America is governed by a President who obtained only 27 per cent or 28 per cent of the voting public. That is his majority. Only 27 per cent or 28 per cent of the voting public of America voted Republican. I suggest in a situation like that it could be unwise to put down all one's cards in favour of a man who was able to get only that sort of vote. For that reason I am doubly sceptical of the way that we tie ourselves to this foreign power.

I wish to paint a scenario as I see it. We, that is, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street)-I should not use the word 'we' because there are thousands of Australians who are just as concerned as I am about the deal that has been done; I guess I should say Australians; the Prime Minister and the Government are in charge-have tied ourselves to this situation in which there is a possibility, as I read the document, of American nuclear armed B52s landing on or passing over Australian soil. Without full knowledge of what the document I referred to earlier means, I would say that it is hard to know what might happen. Surely any Australian government that thinks any military commander, be he Russian, Chinese, British, Australian, American or whatever, is going to notify another power of the weapons which his machines of war are carrying, that he is going to telegraph his punches, really did come down in the last shower.

The other point I want to make is this: With the refuelling aircraft based in Darwin, really there is no need for the B52s to come within Australian territorial waters. Let us envisage a situation in which there is some sort of scare. I say this without any qualms whatsoever. There is one very regretful fault, in my view, that the American people have and that is a tendency to panic. We have seen that happen. I have seen it happen many times in my life. They have a great tendency to panic. Let us suppose that something does happen-there have been some very near misses-and that they believe the balloon has gone up. The B52s would leave Guam loaded with nuclear missiles, nuclear bombs or whatever-as I have already said, there is no way any military commander will notify the Prime Minister of Australia of that fact-and head towards Darwin; at the appropriate time the refuelling aircraft leave Darwin and meet the B52s outside Australian territorial waters; the refuellers return to Darwin, refuel at the ground depot and stand in readiness for the B52s which have gone on with their mission to goodness where; the B52s are refuelled on their return, if need be, again outside Australian territorial waters. Surely that puts Australia in the position of being an accessory either before, after, or both before and after the act. As I have already said, in my view there is no reason why any military commander would notify us that those planes were carrying bombs.

I am utterly saddened to see the way in which my country has been sold out particularly by governments of Liberal and Country Party nature in the post-World War II period. We are now in a situation where we are the host or haven for military and intelligence gathering installations of all types and sizes, many about which we do not know as much as we should know. I put it to the Senate in this way: There would not be one red-blooded American who would allow a foreign base on American territorial soil; yet American governments and the Pentagon seem to expect Australians to acquiesce in every blasted, gimmicky death-threatening device they want to plant on our soil.

Where is Australian pride? Where are the Australians who would once stand up and say to America what they should do. I was going to use a derogatory term, Mr President, for which you may well pull me up. There are other terms for it. Such Australians would say something to the effect: 'Get back home to America. America, we owe you nothing. We paid the price in World War II; we fed you, we fought alongside you. No longer do we need to kowtow to you or to any other foreign power. Pack up your B52s, all your bases and take them back home and do what you goddamn well like with them but get them out of my country.'

I believe that any Australian government that had the guts to stand up and say just that would win the accolades of the vast bulk of the people of Australia. I believe that future generations of Australians would lift the skies in praise. I believe that we would strike that nationalistic note which this government is trying to drum up with all sorts of expenditure, flag waving and jingoistic slogans of 'Come on, Aussie, come on' and all the other bulldust which really only puts money in the hands of television station proprietors and nothing else.

Somewhere some day some Australian Government will have to stand up and say to every foreign power: 'Get back home. Australia is our country. We will run it the way we like. We want to be free to do the things we want to do. We refuse to have our hands tied in foreign, defence and economic policies by people who are not responsible to the government of this country. I believe that the day we do that, as I said earlier, we can forget about the jingoism of 'Come on, Aussie, come on', and every Australian in this country once again will be proud to be Australian.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Motion (by Senator Carrick) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a first time.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
(Quorum formed).
Consideration resumed from 11 March.
Item 5. Estimates Committees
Item 5(iii)-Appearance of House of Representatives Ministers before Estimates Committees.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is discussing item 5(iii) concerning the appearance of House of Representatives Ministers before Estimates Committees. Senator Martin has moved an amendment to the motion to take note of item 5(iii), namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: At end of motion add 'and this Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present to the Senate during this Session an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable House of Representatives Ministers to appear before and give evidence to Senate Estimates Committees'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved my amendment on 11 March. It is now 2 April. The words in my motion 'during this session' may be unreasonable under those circumstances. Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance procedurally. I would like to take those words out of my amendment so that it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add 'and this Committee requests the Standing Orders Committee to prepare and present to the Senate an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable House of Representatives Ministers to appear before and give evidence to Senate Estimates Committees'.

I seek leave to change the wording of my motion by removing the words 'during this session' on the ground that although it might have been a reasonable request on 11 March I do not think it is quite so reasonable now. I am uncertain whether it is.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the amendment moved by Senator Martin. I read the reasons the Senate Standing Orders Committee gave for believing that the proposal for House of Representatives Ministers appearing before Senate Estimates committees could not proceed. I cannot say that I thought the reasons had a great deal of weight. The Standing Orders Committee report states that there would be serious practical difficulties in arranging times suitable to Ministers. I would have thought of that as just one of the problems we already have. We have problems already with Senate Ministers appearing before Estimates committees. Arrangements would just have to be made, and I think they could be made satisfactorily. It may be that Estimates committees will take a little longer to conclude their hearings if, in fact, we have to schedule meetings to suit the convenience of House of Representatives Ministers. However they would be getting much more accurate information from the responsible Minister than they would get from another Minister not familiar with the matter in question.

SPEECH.PARA: The report states that there would also be difficulty in predicting when particular departments would be examined by Estimates committees. I know that that is a problem already. In fact departments are taken in a certain order and no doubt they can keep in touch with Ministers. The report mentions a third difficulty in predicting in advance whether questions to be asked during the hearings were such as to require the attention of the Minister concerned. I should have thought that the Minister would want to attend-perhaps some of the questions would not concern him-to hear matters which arose during the consideration of his Department's estimates. The report further states:

The proposal also raises larger questions which go to the fundamentals of the bicameral system, for example, whether Ministers should appear before both Houses for the purposes of answering questions and presenting legislation.

I regard that objection as quite absurd. There is nothing fundamental in the bicameral system which prevents Ministers from meeting people from the other chamber. They constantly do this at party meetings. Ministers have been known to give evidence and supply submissions to Senate committees dealing with various matters. There seems to be no reason for thinking that this has anything to do with the fundamentals of the bicameral system. I believe that this measure would improve the Estimates process in this House and is one that should be persisted with. I think that Senator Martin's proposal that something along these lines be drafted and tried is worth while.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be voluntary, not mandatory.

—Yes, of course it would. I cannot imagine dragging a Minister from the House of Representatives before the Bar of the Senate for having failed to come here, but I think that Ministers would find it very unwise not to be here if they could.
—Bring them over in chains.

—It is a long way across the hall from one place to another. I do not think that Ministers are fearful of appearing before the Senate. I think that they would be able to give a reasonable account of themselves and that it would only improve the standard of the Senate's determination and consideration of Estimates committees if they were present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not object to Senator Martin's motion. I think it would be a good thing for this area to be investigated. There are some observations about the general issues I would like to put before the Standing Orders Committee. I make it clear that I am all for the responsible Ministers appearing appropriately before the Senate and Senate committees. I would like to see the development of a system where they appeared here at Question Time, and I would certainly like them to appear before Senate legislative and general purpose committees when legislation affecting that Minister is being considered, and I hope they will do a lot more of that. I am far from impressed with the effectiveness and usefulness of the Estimates committees as at present constituted by this chamber. My concern is that Estimates committees were originally established as a device by the Executive to head off the establishment of the legislative and general purpose committees. In my view, they should have been subsumed long ago into the legislative and general purpose committees.

SPEECH.PARA: When Estimates committees or legislative and general purpose committees consider the Estimates, their role is very limited. Unlike a committee of the American Senate, for instance, there is no chance of the estimates being altered. There is no feeling that the people appearing before the Committee have to justify their program for fear that it will be totally rejected. All that is happening is that it is providing a place where senators, particularly Opposition senators, can establish facts on issues that concern them and also persuade and perhaps force public servants to justify their expenditure a little better, but it does not ultimately affect much of the expenditure. We have to recognise that what is done by Estimates committees is, in fact, very limited. We must ensure that we do not set up too elaborate a machinery to achieve a relatively small objective. We took on this role because it was being grossly neglected by the House of Representatives, which I think constitutionally should have the primary financial responsibility. It was totally neglecting its responsibilities in this area, although it has now taken steps to set up Estimates committees. In the light of the establishment of the House of Representatives Estimates committees, we should look at the continuing role of our committees which I hope will be merged into the legislative and general purpose committees before too long.

While both Houses have Estimates committees, we have a rather elaborate machinery for a fairly small objective. I am not in favour of setting up a joint committee to examine the Estimates. I think that that would be constitutionally awkward and adminstratively very difficult. However I think we should look at some rationalisation procedure. Perhaps it would be sensible to have a system whereby Senate committees question Senate Ministers-that is their responsibility to the Parliament-and House of Representatives Ministers are questioned by committees of the House of Representatives. In view of the very limited value which I believe is achieved by Estimates committees, I think that that would be appropriate and effective machinery. Each House would have the responsibility for questioning the Ministers who are responsible to it. I think that that would be appropriate machinery for us to establish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not seek to extend the debate to any extent because we have been debating the Standing Orders Committee report for a long time. However, I would like to comment on a couple of points that have been mentioned in the debate, particularly one which was made recently by Senator Hamer. We all have views on how Estimates committees might be changed and improved, but this motion does not involve a question of change. It is a question of how to improve the present system, not what other system might be better. For example, at another time I would seek to debate with Senator Hamer whether the Senate should question only Senate Ministers in Estimates committees and the House of Representatives should question only House of Representatives Ministers in Estimates committees. I would not like to feel that senators were cut out of what is a valuable process of questioning and information seeking just by the chance of the portfolios Senate Ministers happen to hold. Senator Hamer raised some alternatives, and I think that they are alternatives all of us could canvass. The question of what might happen to Estimates committees has been canvassed before in debate in the Senate. I emphasise that my motion has nothing to do with a new system of Estimates committees. It is looking at the present system, not saying that it is perfect, and asking how we can make this system work a little better.

SPEECH.PARA: When we debated this matter on 11 March I outlined at some length my reasons for moving the motion now before the Senate and I do not intend to recanvass those points. However, other points were raised by honourable senators during the debate, and I will comment briefly on a couple of them. It was suggested that it was not appropriate to have House of Representatives Ministers come to Senate committees, for example, that there was something a little strange in the notion that a Senate Estimates committee could call the Prime Minister to give evidence on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Senator Withers, by interjection when Senator Missen was speaking a few minutes ago, raised the question of whether there would be any compulsion to attend. At present there is no compulsion that I am aware of for Senate Ministers to appear before Senate Estimates committees. I am not proposing that if for some reason a House of Representatives Minister chose not to come there would be any compulsion. Perhaps that is another issue the Senate might want to address itself to, but it is not one that I sought to raise.

TALK.START.PARA: —He could send the Minister assisting, couldn't he?

—Yes, he could send the Minister assisting. I assume that some Minister would appear before the committee to save the Government. I could not see the Government allowing Estimates committees to operate without a Minister being present at the committee to speak on behalf of the Government's Budget and Estimates. I would expect somebody to be there, and I would expect that many House of Representatives Ministers would choose to come to Estimates committees. It may be that, for some good and proper reason, the Prime Minister may not appear before an Estimates committee. It may be that he does appear. I think a good, strong argument exists for saying that it is in the interest of the Ministers to come to Estimates committees and not to be represented by someone else, but that is another issue. As I said, Senator Withers raised that question by way of interjection while Senator Missen spoke, and it is a valid point. We are simply asking the Standing Orders Committee to present to the Senate an amendment to the Standing Orders to enable this to happen. The proof of its worth would depend on the way it worked.

SPEECH.PARA: The essence of the debate on this area of the Standing Orders Committee report is the quality of evidence that is given to Senate Estimates committees. I do not think any one would debate that it is highly variable. In my opinion Senate Ministers who appear before the committees to represent their own portfolios give good evidence. They know the detail and they can answer quite detailed questions. The quality of evidence from Senate Ministers representing the portfolio of another Minister, and who rarely answer many of the questions personally-most of them are directed to the officers-is highly variable. It varies very much from department to department.

I sat on a committee which took evidence from the Department of Foreign Affairs. I said at the committee-it is on record in the Hansard and I do not mind saying it again-that it is a pleasure to go through the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs because of the promptness of delivery and detail of the evidence that is given to the committee. Good witnesses are sent to the committee. That Estimates committee rarely has to ask for additional information. Most questions are capable of being answered in some detail at the committee at the time they are asked. That is welcomed. We seek an improvement in the quality of evidence, given promptly on the spot, with the opportunity for honourable senators to follow up immediately an answer given in a committee and to probe further for more detail where they feel it is warranted. I suggest that my motion would lead to a refinement of the Estimates committees which would be in the interests of advancing their present operations.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be added to the motion 'That Item 5 (iii) be noted' be added.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Item 6 noted.
Item 7-Television.
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That Item 7 be noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this item the Standing Orders Committee does not make a recommendation but makes an appeal for advice, for the views of the Senate. I think it would be wrong to let the item be noted without hearing the views of members. The issue is whether the televising of proceedings should be permitted. It makes no difference to me as I will not be here if and when proceedings are televised. I think the Committee wishes to get the Senate's advice. Personally, I am against the televising of committee meetings. I do not know whether television crews would be anxious to attend, other than at the first one or two meetings, once the novelty had worn off. I think the publicity given to an Estimates committee would take the committee out of itself and would see itself as more glamorous. I just raise the matter now to carry out the committee's wish to have an expression of the views of the Senate on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps a member of the Standing Orders Committee should speak on behalf of the Committee which stated in its report:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee intends to consider this matter further and to seek further information from the Australian Broadcasting Commission and other sources.

I think we can take it that honourable senators do not wish to make a contribution about this item at the moment but, rather, are awaiting some further and more considered recommendations from the Standing Orders Committee. I take it that this item is simply noted on the basis that the Standing Orders Committee will report in detail in due course and that the Senate will then debate the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —After Senator Rae's remarks I feel that one should comment about this item. There is an interest in it. I do not rise just for the sake of speaking. This is a matter on which I have written recently to the President and which I have raised with chairmen of the Senate standing committees. We know there are some moves in the House of Representatives, which had been strongly supported by Mr Speaker, to take steps to have televised at least the proceedings of the House of Representatives. I think it would be a great mistake for the Senate to put itself in the position where it suddenly found that one House of the Parliament and not the other was to be televised.
—They could have the Australian Broadcasting Commission and we could have Kerry Packer.
—Senator Harradine can have Kerry Packer if he likes. I am inclined to think that the dignity of the Senate is more fitted to the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
—Or vice versa.

—Perhaps. I think there is a lot to be said for the improvement that would be effected to the Parliament by the televising of its proceedings. I agree that there must be reservations in regard to the televising of Senate committee proceedings. We do not want to see the development of something like the McCarthyite trials in the United States which were no doubt very popular and have very big audiences, but which I think did a great deal of damage to the standing of the United States Congress in that era. However, I believe that much could be done by televising the Parliament. If one goes to Japan one sees the people sitting on the railway stations watching Question Time in the Diet. They may do so because they have to wait a long time for trains; I am not sure.
—There might be no other programs.

—That might be so. I think that is an unfair reflection on the Japanese. I got the impression that, inscrutable as many of the people of Japan are, they seemed to be quite animated when it came to watching on television the activities of Question Time in the Diet. I believe that the televising of Parliament is working in that country. From what I have read, it is also working in Canada, where the material produced is controlled in the Parliament and made available to the commercial and other television channels for their use. It is true that some of them may use it at midnight and that it is not always shown at prime time, but I gather that is quite a lot of the--
—But it gets to the masses, doesn't it?

—It does get to them. There are problems with the talking face. The camera may have to stray around the chamber and it may record, for example, the posture of senators, like that of those on the front bench opposite who have their legs up in the air. It would be unfortunate if that were televised. Therefore, the behaviour of members of parliament might have to improve. We have to act as we had to act during the Joint Sitting in 1974. Senator Martin will remember, much to her cost--
—Horror.
—And to her horror, that during that period members and senators had to watch what they were doing.
—Or to whom they were talking.

—Or to whom they were talking. We were all expected to be in the chamber. We were told that blank rows or lots of empty seats must not be seen in the chamber. It was a rather excruciating performance for us in the early days of our parliamentary careers. Despite that fact, I think the televising of parliamentary sessions would be worthwhile. I think this chamber must be very careful not to fall behind in this area. I trust that while it merely notes this item it goes along with an initiative substantially of the House of Representatives, and will ensure that something will be done soon towards the televising of parliament. I hope that we will not fall too far behind such countries as Japan and Canada. I have a particular concern that we should not be too far behind Canada which seems to lead so much these days in other democratic areas. I would not like to think that this Parliament did not have the ability to put on a good performance also in this area. I hope that whilst the item is merely noted at this stage, it will be pushed on with some vigour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek some further advice because the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee intends to consider this matter further-
That is, the televising of the Senate-
and to seek further information from the Australian Broadcasting Commission and other sources.

We are left somewhat in the dark as to how far that matter has progressed. It is unfortunate that no members of the Opposition who are on the Senate Standing Orders Committee are in the chamber but three Government members of the Committee are. Perhaps we can be told what sort of information the Committee is seeking and what sort of information it has received to this point of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Orders Committee has sought technical advice from the Australian Broadcasting Commission and Telecom Australia on this matter of televising the proceedings of the Senate. Provision is made in the Standing Orders for the televising of committees subject to rules and regulations being drawn up. There are many technical difficulties. A large amount of information has been given to us thus far by the ABC. However, we still have difficulty in respect of certain aspects of the ability to televise properly committees or proceedings of this chamber. I will be going to Canada soon to attend a conference of Presiding Officers and I propose to see at first hand the televising arrangements in the Parliament of Canada. There have been delays. I regret that we have got no further than we have to this point. Lighting, general acoustics and many other matters come into consideration. They do not hit a layman until the experts and those who are engaged in television production advise us. This matter is not being overlooked; nor do I want this place to be behind any other place in respect of the televising of the main body of the Senate. Much background work has been done which is of value to us and we are continuing with those investigations. That is all I can report at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Missen were not such a good friend I might seek to make a personal explanation.
—Let's hear it.

—Senator Harradine should have been here. I know there has been much debate about the televising of Parliament. I have a view that if Parliament is to be televised the telecast should be extremely limited. My view is based on my experience during the Joint Sitting of the Parliament. I am not referring necessarily to the occasion when, during a division, about four of us were enjoying a joke-anything to enliven the deadly dullness of a division-and on the closed circuit television in Parliament House it looked as though something very different was going on, such is the power of the television camera at a certain angle. That is in the archives for all time. I say to Senator Harradine that I am not sure whether the film is available for commercial or private screening, but those who were in the House saw it and commented on it at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the televising of Parliament has to be treated with great discretion if it is to happen at all. I am not persuaded that it is necessary. I accept the view that members of the Australian public have a right to be informed. I am yet to be persuaded that they want to be that informed if, indeed, informed is what they would be as a result of seeing Parliament on television. Those are just a couple of matters which I mention briefly. I hope that the Senate Standing Orders Committee, if it is seriously addressing itself to something specific such as the televising of Question Time, will make sure that that is done on the same basis as are the radio rebroadcasts of Question Time-that is, that certain things that happen during Question Time which are ruled out of order are not rebroadcast. I think those who are not happy about having television in the parliamentary chamber are concerned that it could indeed change the nature of the way the Parliament operates at certain times when cameras are filming. Senator Grimes scowls at me furiously.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no.
—Oh, good. He is just hard of hearing.
—He is getting ready for television.

—He is just practising. I think that a real objection to television-I do not think it would be going too far to say this-is that this chamber has been known to behave differently when the proceedings were being broadcast than it behaves on days when the proceedings were not being broadcast. I do not think that is good for the Parliament. All those constraints should be taken into account. The only reason people seem to suggest the televising of Question Time over and over again is that it is the time with potentially the greatest entertainment value or, conversely, it is the time of Parliament with the least boredom factor; so it is the one time that could safely be shown on a television screen. That is a reflection, I think, on the workings of Parliament-the fact that it is not meant to be public entertainment or television-style entertainment anyway. I hope that the Committee in its deliberations will bear in mind that there are many senators and members who do not support the televising of Parliament or who, if Parliament is to be televised, only support it on a very limited basis. I also hope that simply because some people who hold positions of prestige in this Parliament support the televising of Parliament that does not mean it has to happen.

—I want to use the occasion to ask the President or somebody else on the Senate Standing Orders Committee a question. What is the position with the televising of Senate committees at the moment? Recently I was quite surprised. I arrived only a few minutes late for a meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in Sydney and the proceedings of the Committee were being televised. All the questions being asked and all the conversation that was going on were replayed later that night on Channel 0. I can imagine why it was reasonably interesting to Channel 0. We were taking evidence from the Indo-China Refugee Association. Therefore, my understanding of the situation was that all that was needed was for the Committee to decide beforehand that the proceedings could be televised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under Standing Order 36AA paragraph (21.) the present position is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Standing Committees may authorise the televising of public hearings of the Committees, at the discretion of each such Committee, and under such rules as the Senate may adopt.

The Senate has not adopted any rules. My understanding of the normal procedure is that there is no authorisation for the televising of committee proceedings to include sound and that only the film of the proceedings without the direct reproduction of the spoken word could be televised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deaf people could understand it.
—Senator Martin points out that if people can read lips they can understand what is being said. Presumably, that is correct. I was just answering the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter and to assure Senator Martin that I was not scowling at her. I was concentrating on her words, as I always do. I think much is said about the televising of Parliament which is misconceived because of our lack of experience in this area and particularly because of our experience during the Joint Sitting when, as Senator Missen said, we had the crazy situation that we were forced to turn up at certain times to pretend that we were all very interested. In the Canadian House of Commons and in some of the provincial parliaments in Canada the proceedings are telecast. I believe the problems Senator Martin sees are largely overcome in Canada by the camera being fixed on the speaker and no one else so, if we did that, we could not have cameramen panning around the chamber catching Senator Withers doing things he might not like to be seen doing. That gets over the situation of people putting on a turn in the chamber in an effort to get on television. Similarly, in parliaments such as the West German Parliament where each speaker speaks from a dias, a fixed position, that problem is overcome by the cameras being confined to the speaker and not panning around the chamber, filming all the skylarking.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1981 it seems to me to be more appropriate to televise the Parliament than to tie up one radio station all day every day that Parliament is sitting, thus preventing me on some days from listening to some music programs I want to listen to. Sometimes we broadcast proceedings such as debates on the Standing Orders about which no one outside the Parliament has a clue what we are talking about or the procedures for the introduction of Bills which occurs endlessly throughout some days. We know that governments-this Government included-deliberately so arrange the program on broadcasting days that nothing controversial or unfavourable to the Government will be broadcast. Frequently there will be only very boring things to broadcast.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's soothing, like listening to the cricket.

—It may be soothing for the honourable senator but, as someone once said, watching cricket is like watching grass grow. It is a bit like listening to Parliament. I agree with the honourable senator. I believe that in 1981-in the days of modern communication-it would probably be more appropriate to televise proceedings than to tie up a radio network around Australia at enormous cost when the number of listeners cannot be detected in any rating survey. I think we should seriously look at our priorities and decide the compulsory broadcast of the proceedings of this Parliament is justified or whether televised proceedings would be more sensible in this modern age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only comment I want to make relates to how we can slot in the televising of the Senate at prime viewing time. Sometimes football and hockey teams are reduced in size to seven members. A similar approach could be applied in televising selected debates in this chamber. Excellent dramatic senators could then appear at their most aggressive best, say in the adjournment debate. We could pick the issues we wanted televised. I would be prepared to let an effective television producer pick a segment from the three nights the Senate sits each week. We have had some magnificent nights here. Some honourable senators could assume the role of Clint Eastwood. Perhaps Senator Martin and Senator Melzer could emulate Jane Fonda at her best in their across the chamber attacks.

SPEECH.PARA: Whatever people may say, I do not think that an honourable senator who speaks on the adjournment debate is other than imbued with somebody's cause. Senator Grimes would get a maximum billing from the Greek community if he pursued, to the considerable embarrassment of the Government, the alleged social security frauds saga. I think his raising of that matter has paid excellent dividends. I know of many other incidents that would be of great interest. I recall one or two lurid interludes I had with people in the Democratic Labor Party who are no longer members of the chamber. Working with the media we could choose segments on particular issues for televising to the voting public. I think that is a very fertile idea. I am sure the President has caught on to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I have to disagree with my good friend Senator Mulvihill and agree with Senator Grimes, which is rather a change. My stance might make Senator Grimes rethink his statement and have another look at what he said. When I heard what Senator Grimes said I had to rethink my views too. I still came to the conclusion that he is right. I believe that televising the proceedings of this chamber would be disastrous. I believe this place has a totally different atmosphere on broadcasting days as it is. I believe that debate on Wednesday, broadcast day, is totally different from debate on Tuesday or Thursday. On broadcast day honourable senators try to speak at certain times. A tremendous amount of grandstanding goes on. On non-broadcast day we can have a very good debate. It nearly breaks my heart to see the difference between broadcast day and Tuesday and Thursday. Last Thursday we had an excellent debate in this place involving Senator Cavanagh and, I think, Senator Rae.
—I thought we were being televised.

—I believe that had the proceedings been televised the debate would not have gone as it did on that occasion. It breaks my heart that people cannot see the reasonable debate that goes on in this place when the proceedings are not being broadcast. I am very much opposed to introducing a further chance for actors in this place to perform their acting duties as they see them.
—If the proceedings of Parliament are to be televised I suggest that no warning should be given to honourable senators as to when the cameras would be switched on.
—We would make you wear a tie.

—I am quite happy with my rig. I am reminded of a prank by Jim Killen some years ago. A colleague-I will not mention names-wore the same suit of clothes for three days. He was expecting some publicity people to interview him. That might be the case with televised proceedings. Honourable senators may not be able to go, at a moment's notice, and put on their war paint.
—What about those shorts?

—We might be able to wear shorts in the Senate. Senator Missen and Senator Martin spoke about the televising of proceedings at the Joint Sitting which was held in the other place. I am reminded that if that Joint Sitting had not taken place we would now not have the problem of arranging for another joint sitting-and deciding whether it should be televised-to fill an Australian Capital Territory Senate vacancy because we would not have had any senators representing the Territories. The Joint Sitting gave the Territories representation in this chamber. Now we are faced with the problem of another Joint Sitting to elect a replacement senator. If we can believe what we read in the newspapers, there is some dispute as to where the Joint Sitting will be held. This report of the Senate Standing Orders Committee was brought down in this chamber in March last year. I hope that the Committee has given some consideration to whether television cameras will be allowed in this chamber, where I expect the forthcoming Joint Sitting to be held. In my view the Joint Sitting should be held here. Perhaps the President can inform us of the preparations which have been made for the televising of the Joint Sitting which I expect will take place in this chamber to elect a senator to replace our departed colleague Senator Knight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Discussions are being held at present in respect of the venue of the Joint Sitting and the proceedings to be followed. I have not yet discussed arrangements for the televising of proceedings. I am discussing other matters at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 8. Display of State Arms or Insignia in the Senate Chamber
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That Item 8 be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman-
—You are not supporting banners in the chamber, are you?
—The item does not relate to banners. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Display of State Arms or insignias in the Senate chamber.
I have read the paragraph of the report under this item and am at a loss with some of the sentiments that are expressed. I refer to the sentence which reads:
It has been pointed out that the Senate Chamber possesses a dignified simplicity--
I think there are many ways to describe the chamber; I think it would be more accurate to describe it as an inexpensive example of Australian public building architecture of the 1920s.

TALK.START.PARA: —That paragraph is referring to some of the senators.

—I see. I was about to say that the chamber is actually drab and boring. Perhaps there is a message there that I had not realised had reached me. I am grateful to Senator Evans for his assistance. The sentence continues:

SPEECH.PARA: and many senators are opposed to altering its present appearance. Some senators consider that a further discreet display of the Commonwealth Arms would be appropriate.
I take it that the carving behind the President's chair and the Sovereign's chair is considered to be a discreet display.

TALK.START.PARA: —But neon lights would be different.

—Yes. The carving is discreet. I would not say that it is a display. I have nothing against the insignia, but I do not think it adds very much to the Senate chamber. I am of the view that adding State Arms in an appropriate fashion, and there is room for them, would be something that would not only improve the appearance but also have some meaning in the chamber, given that we are elected on a particular basis related to the States. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Senators who favour the display of State Arms or insignia have stressed that this would need to be done with great discretion to avoid cluttering the Chamber.

There seems to be an obsession with discretion. I want to make it very clear that I am not opposed to discretion, just as I am not opposed to motherhood. On the other hand, in this context and particularly in this chamber, discretion does seem to mean drabness. I cannot imagine how a display of State insignia would clutter the chamber. It might brighten the chamber a little. It might provide something of interest on which members of the public who throng in their thousands to the public galleries every day might focus when the speeches are particularly boring and tedious. The report states:
The Committee makes no recommendation on the matter, but the Senate will be asked to give its consideration to the subject.

What is not clear is whether we now are being asked to give consideration to the subject. If that is so, I just indicate that I think it is a good idea. I make the suggestion that, as a number of honourable senators clearly think it is a good idea, perhaps the Presiding Officers, particularly the President, may be able to obtain examples of what might be done or seek suggestions from honourable senators on what might be done and make those suggestions available to all honourable senators. We could then make a decision or could give advice to the President on the basis of something that actually had been shown to us. From one of Senator Evans's interjections and also from the reference in the report to 'cluttering the Chamber' I get the impression that there is thought of having banners fluttering from the ceiling. That is one possibility. I do not think it would be favoured. There are other possibilities which I think would enhance this chamber, and perhaps they could be put to us in a specific and detailed way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Laucke Sen The Hon Sir C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have insignia, the coats of arms for the States, which I propose to display in the Whips' offices. This was discussed with the late Senator Knight when he was Government Whip, but it seems that it has not been followed through.
—Could they be displayed in the party rooms?

—They could be displayed in the party rooms or in some other convenient place. We now have them for display so that they can be seen by honourable senators and consideration can be given by them to the question of whether the display of the insignia in the chamber is desirable. Within our Committee we have not had unanimity on whether we should display either flags or the State coats of arms. The thought has been that we could display the State coats of arms on the panels above the public galleries if honourable senators were agreeable to their being displayed in this chamber. I repeat that within the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders there was no unanimity concerning the display of either flags or insignia or coats of arms. We will display the insignia right away.

—I oppose the suggestion about insignia and banners, not on aesthetic grounds but on moral, intellectual and constitutional grounds. This place is not and never has been a States' House, in the way we vote and make decisions or in any other way. I regard any such suggestion as no more than a fiendish Tory plot to recreate the nonsense we went through in 1975, which I hope we never again hear a word of. I regard this as a symbolic attempt to create an absolutely indefensible view of ourselves and our role. I will not have a bar of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I could have written for Senator Evans the speech we have just heard without any of the words being far out of place.
—You wouldn't agree with it, would you?

—I would not agree with his claims but I would agree his speech was totally predictable. His speech indicates a view which has been expressed in the chamber previously, and I think it is useful to have it on record as the opposing view. The only point I make about this matter is that, in case some honourable senators have forgotten, it arose from what amounted to a petition, signed by I think 28 honourable senators from both sides of the chamber, which was sent to the President. The matter has since been discussed by the Senate Standing Committee on Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: A very good mock-up had been prepared of what the chamber would look like if the insignia were displayed in the way in which the President described. I suggest that the matter might be debated further after honourable senators have had a chance to see what the chamber would look like . I hope that that mock-up will be made as publicly available as possible. I suggested, by way of interjection, that the party rooms might be used for display purposes I do not think that is appropriate. It maybe that there is a committee room in which it could be displayed to ensure that all honourable senators and anybody else who is interested have an opportunity to see it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have different reasons for opposing the idea. I think that Senator Martin and Senator Rae have gone out of their minds at the suggestion.
—I haven't supported it.
—Is that so? The honourable senator is promoting the suggestion, though, and I think that it is a very bad idea to promote it, but not for the reasons Senator Evans gave.
—Since when has promotion been a form of consent?

—It can be. Senator Evans opposed the suggestion on what were, I suppose, political grounds. It is only natural that honourable senators express State sentiments. Every now and then we will have a debate related to South Australia or Tasmania during which tribal war will break out, but I do not really think that we need to display the State insignia and flags on the walls to promote that; it will happen without such a display.
—We could have a spotlight.

—That is right. The honourable senator will have a Tasmanian spotlight today. There are already enough hazards in life. Quite recently, accompanied by a State member, I endeavoured to present an Australian flag to one of our schools. Unfortunately, quite accidently the State member made a switch and I presented a Victorian flag to the school. I can see our displaying all the State flags -
—I would not assume that was accidental.

—I am more charitable than that; I assume it was an accident. I think we will have this place looking something like the President's hunting lodge if we follow this line. Perhaps bottles of the President's wine would be even more appropriate.
—What do you think it looks like now?

—I think it is excellent now. I think it is dignified and simple and it ought to remain that way. To my mind, it will take away from the dignity of this chamber to have the State insignia and flags, which will soon become tatty, and to have other things hanging from the walls to indicate the States from which we come. I think the dignity of this chamber is important. I know that the words 'discreet', 'discretion' and so forth are emphasised in the report. It is realised that something about the proposal is not very dignified and discreet. It would turn this place into something which looked like a glorified scout hall. A certain amount of dignity, form, robes and so forth is fine, but to hang on the walls insignia of the different States-I see it might even include flags-to my mind would be a backward step. For different reasons from those of Senator Evans, I put on record that I would regard such a display as aesthetically, culturally, and in every respect an abomination.

—Senator Evans has quite rightly pointed out that we would mislead the public who visit this place if we were to display insignia here. As Senator Evans said, this definitely is not a States' House, it is a party House. If honourable senators agree that they want this chamber adorned with flags, I suggest that we should hang our party flags here. The Australian Labor Party has a very good flag, which displays the Australian flag as well as a symbol of the Australian Labor Party, of which everyone is proud. I would be quite happy to sit here and have that hanging above my head. If we were to hang the party flags here we would not mislead any person who visited this place. They would quite rightly see that this was a party House which always votes on party lines. As I have said on many occasions in this place, if the Labor Party is in government in the other place and the Liberals have the numbers here, it is impossible to govern the country, and if the Liberals have the numbers in both Houses this place is only a rubber stamp. Therefore this is not a States' House. Do not let us mislead ourselves into ever believing that it is.

—I have not noticed Senator McLaren not rising to his feet whenever a South Australian issue is at hand. We hear him expounding on the beauties of South Australia or criticising the South Australian Government at any opportunity. Murray Bridge seems to have a tremendous place in this chamber.
—And Mount Gambier, Bordertown--

—He mentions Murray Bridge at the drop of a hat and it seems to me that he is contradicting the statement he has just made. Senator Missen tried to help our imagination by talking about things hanging from walls and ceilings. That was not what I imagined. I ask Senator Missen whether he has seen the coats of arms of the various States in the High Court.
—Yes.

—Well, they are beautifully done, tastefully done and, I believe, a great asset to the High Court. That is the sort of thing that I envisaged and I am sure the President was talking along those lines. They would be aesthetically complimentary to the chamber as they are to the High Court. As such, I feel that this would be the best thing, but I would, as Senator Rae has suggested, wait until we have a look at them and then perhaps be able to debate the matter more fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should think that the new carpet in the parliamentary dining rooms is a good example of the risks and perils of making any of these decisions in a committee. As has been pointed out, we ought to look at the options. I really cannot understand the rage that has erupted on the other side of the chamber in this debate. Perhaps it was meant to be amusing because something has to liven up the place. I point out that we have the State insignia in that very discreet carving of the coat of arms.
—They are already in the chamber.

—They are already in the chamber as part of the Australian coat of arms. Nobody has suggested we tear that down. There are republicans in this place who would probably like to have that symbol of the Crown removed too. But that is not the point. I think if we can look at something which is specific instead of setting up straw men in order to blow them over we would get a little further. There have been suggestions of banners and all sorts of things. We do not know what the proposal is and I think the point is simply that we need to look at the proposal and not go off on ludicrous tangents about 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Item 9. Reflections upon the Judiciary.
Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That Item 9 be noted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say in respect of this item, as one of the alleged offenders in this respect in the past, that I accept the force of this recommendation on the basis that we have a slightly better class of members of the judiciary these days, at least on the High Court, and it may not be quite so necessary in the future to cast reflections upon them.

—Whilst I recognise the necessity for some protection, I often wonder whether we do not over-protect at times. We find ourselves in the position where what everyone can say privately was a bad decision by a judge or a biased decision by a judge or that there was some ulterior motive in the judge's decision, we cannot say that in Parliament although we are seen to believe it. Therefore, we are restricted somewhat in expressing our opinion of the judiciary which, after all, the Government appoints. That judge is then simply protected for the rest of his career without our having the right to condemn him publicly because the Standing Orders of this Parliament prohibit our doing so. I wonder whether there is anything amiss, anything wrong, in our saying that we think that the Chief Justice gave a frightful decision, or a decision which was influenced by his political motivation rather than the whole question of law. No one could ever say that there was justification for not permitting discussion and criticism of the Chief Justice's decision in the Webster case. No one can say that there was not justification for permitting the right to criticise the judge who made a decision in the case involving a member from Western Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: General Business taking precedence of Government Business at 8 p.m.

DEBATE.TITLE: MATTERS RELATING TO NATIONAL RESOURCES AND ENERGY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Ranger Uranium Project-Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority-Snowy Mountains Council-Department of National Development and Energy-Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation-International Fuel Cycle Evaluation Program-Pipeline Authority-River Murray Commission-

PROCTEXT.PARA: Australian Water Resources Council
Debate resumed from 27 November 1980, 2 December 1980, 4 December 1980 and 3 March 1981 on motions:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: — In taking advantage of the new method of dealing with reports, I intend to speak not at great length to at least four of the reports that the Senate is considering tonight. The four reports are all interwoven. I want to say at the outset that it was through the foresight of a Labor government in 1949 that the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority first came into being. Although our opponents often say during elections that the fate of this country could not be placed in the hands of the Australian Labor Party, when we look at most of the major public works projects in this country we find that they were all initiated by the Australian Labor Party. One of them was the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. Prior to that there was the construction of the east-west railway. I instance also the Pipeline Authority which was brought into being by my late colleague, Rex Connor. That Authority certainly came in for a lot of criticism at the time of its establishment, but is now proving to be a very worthwhile project. Even the people of Canberra will soon be benefiting from the natural gas which will come to this city as a result of the foresight of our late colleague, Rex Connor.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the reports I want to speak to tonight -the annual report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, the annual report of the Snowy Mountains Council, the annual report of the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the annual report of the River Murray Commission - are, I suppose, offspring of the initial piece of legislation which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 25 May 1949 by Mr Lemmon, the then Minister for Works and Housing in the Federal Labor Government of that time. I was able to get today from the Senate Records office a copy of the first annual report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority. I want to quote some comments from it. It was delivered to Mr Casey, as he then was. I do not know what his portfolio was, but it does not matter. He was the responsible Minister at that time because the Labor Party had been defeated in 1949 on petrol rationing-an issue similar to one which could well bring about the defeat of this Government. Mr Menzies, as he then was, went to the people on the promise to lift petrol rationing, which Mr Chifley could quite easily have done if he had been prepared to sell out the nation and to buy very dear petrol. The wheel could well come full circle and the Fraser Government too could well go out of office on the issue of petrol, more than 30 years after the Labor Party was thrown out of office on the issue of petrol rationing. That disturbed me very greatly at the time because many of the people who voted Mr Menzies into office on his promise to abolish petrol rationing did not own a motor car. That is how easily the people of this country can be fooled. But I am not going to deal with that tonight. I want to deal with some of the remarks made in the first annual report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, for the year ended 30 June 1950, nearly 31 years ago. In the introduction the report stated:

In the early and middle twenties there were other proposals concerned primarily with the supply of water to Sydney and other country towns. In 1937, the former hydro-electric scheme of 1915-1918 was reviewed and further investigated by the New South Wales Government. The estimated capacity of this proposal was approximately 250,000 kilowatts . . .
As I will point out later, that capacity has been vastly increased. That 250,000 kilowatts of electricity was about one-tenth of the capacity of the Snowy Mountains project. I continue:
These proposals were all limited to regional interests rather than full utilisation of the water resources of the area in the interests of the Nation as a whole.

I should go back in time and say that it was not the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority which was generating 250,000 kilowatts; it was a project which had been proposed by the New South Wales Government of the day. I continue:

Later, in 1944, a Special Committee appointed by the New South Wales Government carried out further investigations into the possible use of the waters of the Snowy River and stressed the need to divert the water inland to the Murrumbidgee for irrigation. However, the Commonwealth had certain rights conferred by the Seat of Government Legislation of the Commonwealth and of the State of New South Wales. Victoria also was concerned in the proposals because the lower reaches of the Snowy River are in Eastern Victoria.
Effective action was taken for the first time in 1946 . . .
We must bear in mind that we had a Federal Labor government at that time, just 12 months after the cessation of hostilities in World War II. I continue:

Effective action was taken for the first time in 1946, when Ministers of the Commonwealth and the Premiers of New South Wales and Victoria, with their technical advisers, met to discuss the utilisation of the Snowy River waters. As a result of this Conference it was agreed that an investigation should be made to determine the practicability of a proposal to divert the Snowy waters into the Murray Valley and whether such a proposal justified a complete examination. This investigation was carried out by the Department of Works and Housing in regard to engineering matters and by the Department of Post War Reconstruction in regard to agricultural and economic aspects. Experts of the two State Governments collaborated with the Commonwealth representatives.

A report on this investigation was considered at a Premiers Conference in 1947 and it was agreed that further investigations were fully justified. A Technical Committee with representatives from the Commonwealth, New South Wales and Victoria, under the Chairmanship of Dr L. F. Loder, Director-General of Works and Housing, was set up for this purpose.

This Committee in a report of November, 1948, recommended a broader approach to the development of the area than was embraced by either the Snowy-Murrumbidgee proposal or the Snowy-Murray proposal and put forward a scheme for the diversion of the Snowy River waters and their use in combination with the waters of the Upper Murrumbidgee, Tumut and Upper Murray Rivers and their tributaries.

A conference of Ministers representing the Commonwealth and States of New South Wales and Victoria in February, 1949, considered this Report and generally agreed with the recommendations. The Conference also decided that the Committee should continue investigations.

That was in 1946 when the then Labor Government, in discussions with the Premiers of New South Wales and Victoria, first talked about a major scheme in the Snowy Mountains and about water supply. I understand from my reading that after the defeat of the then Labor Government, Mr Menzies boycotted the opening of the Snowy Mountains scheme because he said it would be a white elephant. We all know what a great benefit it has been to this country. It is a great tribute to the foresight of the then Prime Minister, Ben Chifley. If we cast our minds a little further afield, we find that it took 23 years before anything constructive was done by a Federal government about the quality and quantity of the River Murray water.

When I was speaking earlier this week on the first reading of a money Bill I gave credit to Dr Moss Cass who, when he was the Federal Labor Minister for the Environment and Conservation, set up a series of discussions and brought down a policy-I referred to it the other night-on the quantity and the quality of water in the River Murray. He set up the River Murray working parties. It can be clearly seen that the Federal Labor Government was cognisant of the need to do something to safeguard the River Murray water in the three States through which it flows and to do something about water storage. So never let it be said again that a Federal Labor government has not any foresight, cannot govern this country properly and never seems able to cater for the needs of the community. We must bear in mind that the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act came into being just 12 months after the cessation of hostilities in World War II. While a Labor government was left to carry out the war effort, it never lost sight of the fact that when the war finished there would be many things to be done on the local scene; and it set about doing them. As I said, on 25 May 1949, after that conference of Ministers representing the Commonwealth and the States of New South Wales and Victoria, Mr Lemmon introduced a Bill entitled the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Bill. In his second reading speech of 26 May 1949 he stated that the potential power from this system would be 1,720,000 kilowatts. At the end of his second reading speech-I think this is something which we ought to bear in mind-he said:

I believe that this scheme will be one of the greatest single factors that will make it possible for this country to carry a greatly increased population. It will also be one of the greatest factors to bring about a permanent and effective policy of decentralisation. Because of the great quantity of water that will be made available for irrigation, and the cheap power that will be generated, there is no reason why we should not see, in our time, inland cities in the Murray Valley and the Murrumbidgee Valley that should carry a population of 1,000,000 people. The Government faces this task of construction in the knowledge that it will encounter many problems. No doubt, at times, we shall meet with some disappointments, and the work will have many critics. However, those critics, in the main, will be people who have little faith. This Government has faith in its engineers, its people and the future of Australia.

They were the words of Mr Lemmon in 1949, and those words were true. Those of use who travel between here and South Australia through the Riverina witness the great productivity in the Murrumbidgee Irrigation Area, and that has been made possible only by the construction of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Scheme and all that goes with it.

If honourable senators look at the 31st annual report of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority 1979-80 they will find that the total generating capacity now of the hydro-electric scheme is 3,740,000 kilowatts and that through diversion, regulation and control of the rivers an additional enormous amount of water is available not only for irrigation areas but also for domestic use. If it were not for this scheme many people in South Australia would not be able to use the Murray River and the people who live at Port Pirie, Port Augusta, and Whyalla and many people in Adelaide would not have an adequate water supply. The 1979-80 report of the Snowy Mountain's Hydro-electric Authority states:

The Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949 established the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority which is constituted by a Commissioner as a corporation sole with perpetual succession. Under the Act the Authority is empowered to construct, maintain, operate, protect, manage and control works for the collection, diversion and storage of water and for the generation of electricity in the Snowy Mountains Area.
The Snowy Mountains Scheme is a dual purpose hydro-electric and irrigation complex located in South-Eastern Australia.

It is one of the major wonders of the world today. When I read through some of the speeches made in the other place and some public statements made by opponents of this scheme, it amazes me that every Labor government-whether back in those days or even between 1972 and 1975- has come under severe criticism from our opponents to the effect that we are not capable of governing the country.

One of the other reports with which we are dealing tonight is the Pipeline Authority annual report. The Authority will be a perpetual monument to our late colleague, Mr Rex Connor, who with his vision and foresight was able to pilot that legislation but he had difficulties with it. If it had not been for a Joint Sitting of both Houses of Parliament after the 1974 double dissolution we might not have had that pipeline authority operating today and the people in Sydney might not have been availing themselves of natural gas from the Moomba fields.

These things should be put on the record and should be repeatedly talked about to remind people that Labor was capable in office during the war years and was capable from 1972 to 1975. It will be capable again of bringing in legislation which will be of great benefit not only to the people who support our party but, in the main, to the people who oppose it. One of the other great things which was brought about by the Labor Government was Trans-Australia Airlines. We now find that the Government is in the process of trying to hand it over to private enterprise. Where will we be then? The Government will hand it over to Murdoch. He eventually will get his hands on it because he is a very strong supporter of the Government. Through various and devious means if this Government keeps its promise to turn TAA into a public company it will throw the baby out the window with the bath water and offer a great reward to its wealthy mates for services rendered.

I think that my colleague, Senator Mulvihill, who has had a deep involvement in the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority and who had great pride some months ago in taking part in a ceremony which paid tribute to people of many nations who worked on that project, will have a few words to say on this matter tonight. We in the Labor Party are proud not only of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority but also of the Snowy Mountains Council, whose report is tabled here for discussion tonight. We are proud at the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation which is another offshoot of the vision of a Labor government, but of course it is an old venture with a new name brought about by this Government. Because we are not carrying out any major government construction works in Australia today, we have lost the expertise of the people in the corporation. They have to go overseas to carry out work. We should be using them here and the Government should make more money available to carry out the necessary major works of which these people are capable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to deal with two reports tonight. The first one is the River Murray Commission annual report for 1980. Many South Australians on both sides of the chamber have expressed their concern on numerous occasions regarding the quality of water in the River Murray and the future quality and supply of water in the River Murray. Senator McLaren, who is a South Australian, has had quite a deal to say about this matter. He and I do not see eye to eye with regard to the way in which we perhaps can overcome some of the problems. Nevertheless I think it is significant in this place that South Australians, generally, irrespective of their parties, have continually expressed concern, not just during this session but over a period of years, with regard to the River Murray system. Dealing with waste discharges, under the heading 'Australian Newsprint Mills-Albury', the report refers to the need for some quality control. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of items regarding the treatment facilities of the Mill--
That is at Albury-
which are still subject to discussion and await resolution.

They are very good words and perhaps give us a lot of encouragement, coming from a responsible body. But the matter which concerns me is that the River Murray Commission is made up of representatives of three States and the Commonwealth. The Commission virtually has no control whatsoever with regard to water quality. It has control with regard to quantity-there is a quota system for the three States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia-but no real control over water quality. The constitution of the River Murray Commission spells out very clearly that whilst the Commission can make recom- mendations-recommendations, I might add, are not directions-it must do so by a unanimous decision. So we have a situation which perhaps could be described on some occasions as farcical. In real terms, one of those representatives of the Commission would have to sit in judgment upon himself and the State.

This is the concern I expressed with regard to the proposed newsprint mill at Albury. I have expressed this opinion before in this place. The River Murray Commission has no control whatsoever over any of the feed systems of the River Murray. Let me make that clear. It has no control over any of the tributaries or feed systems whatsoever but, if there is agreement, it can make recommendations or suggestions.
