Discussions are being held at the present time to give this toothless tiger, if I may describe it in that way, some teeth in regard to water quality control. Let me make it clear that the Commission has done an excellent job in the areas in which it has power to do things, but as far as water quality is concerned it is virtually a toothless tiger because its powers are restricted. I hope that serious consideration will be given to extending the powers of the Commission so that a majority decision will rule and directions can be given in reality. South Australia, and Victoria for that matter, particularly in the irrigation regions, and Senator McLaren is very conscious of the problem because he also is very interested in the River Murray--

TALK.START.PARA: —I live on it.

—I am referring to the irrigation areas. In South Australia and over the border into Victoria many people are involved in irrigation in the huge horticultural industry. The future of those people will be in jeopardy if the quality of the River Murray water is not looked after. The situation in respect of salinity is a grave one, and a good deal of work is being done in that area. I commend the governments concerned, including the Federal Government, and the River Murray Commission for what is happening. If I may refer to the salinity mitigation works at Barr Creek in Victoria, the work on salt disposal has meant that instead of the salt flowing into the River Murray it is being fed back into dry pools. From Barr Creek alone some 42,700 tonnes of salt has been kept out of the River Murray. From Lake Hawthorn some 17,600 tonnes of salt has been turned back. It is evident that a good deal of work is being done in this area by the River Murray Commission, with the agreement of the States. I come back to the point on which I started my speech. Until such time as somebody has authority to control the quality of the water in the River Murray we will have problems, and as time goes on the problems will become greater.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the Darling River area, which was discussed in this place the other night. There is genuine concern in South Australia about the proposal to increase the area of irrigation in New South Wales. Having said that, I hasten to state that it is the right of New South Wales to increase its irrigation if it wishes, but it is also our right to express our genuine concern, which we hope will be noted by the other States, and particularly the State of New South Wales. Because of the dry seasons, this year the River Murray is not flowing in real terms. In fact, it has been stated that the sand bar at the entrance to the sea is closing up the River Murray at the present time. If there is excessive drainage from the River Murray, a situation could arise in which there will be a slowing down of the river flow. When the river flow slows down we finish up with salt slugs in the river, which has disastrous effects in the lower reaches, and I refer to such large irrigation areas as Mildura, Renmark, Barmera, and Waikerie in South Australia.

I hope that the State Ministers and the Federal Government through its representatives will show genuine concern and treat the River Murray system not so much as a system that runs through the three States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia but as a national system. This river system supplies national industries with their life blood, that is, water. It is no use supplying poor quality water because that would only destroy what I call a national industry.

While I have the opportunity to speak briefly about this area, as a South Australian I do not want to appear to be parochial but I do want to express concern about the quantity of water that will flow in the longer term down the River Murray. It is correct that at the present time South Australia is able to obtain its water quota, but it may not be known to many people that the city of Adelaide and the northern areas of South Australia are dependent to a great extent on the waters of the River Murray, and I refer not only to water quality but also to the quantity of water available. We have been fortunate, and we hope that will continue, but my concern is that as South Australia continues to expand, unless technology comes to the fore with some other method to supply fresh water, be it through desalination or in some other way, South Australia will become more and more dependent on the waters of the River Murray to supply its urban and industrial needs. Hence there is a genuine concern for both the quality and quantity, but in particular the quality, of the water from the River Murray.

Having spoken very briefly on this matter, and one could expand much more the argument on the need for water quality control in the River Murray, I turn now to the annual report for 1979-80 of the Department of National Development and Energy. In particular I wish to speak on the great expansion that is taking place today in oil exploration in Australia. This Government can take much of the credit for what is being done, but I must concede that it cannot take all of the credit. The Whitlam Government introduced and supported not so much import parity pricing but a system whereby incentives would be given for oil exploration in Australia, and I admit that. However, this Government has stuck to its guns all the way through in introducing, defending, supporting and continuing import parity pricing for crude oil, which has had a big bearing upon the level of oil exploration that is taking place today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't we know.

—There have been interjections in the chamber tonight from Opposition Senators criticising the Government's policy on import parity. Import parity pricing, which was introduced in 1978, is one of the best things this Government has done in energy conservation. The need for energy conservation is not peculiar to Australia. It is international concern, a growing concern, and a concern that will continue to grow. Australia is playing its part in the conservation of energy.

SPEECH.PARA: If we had not done something about fuel conservation in Australia, we could have found ourselves in a very invidious position in the mid-1980s. In the mid-1970s many people estimated that whilst at that stage Australia was 70 per cent self-sufficient in oil, by the mid-1980s our indigenous supplies would be less than 40 per cent of requirements. Such a situation would adversely affect our balance of payments and also perhaps place us in the rather risky position of being dependant upon overseas supplies. As we have seen in the last couple of years, at times they can be very insecure. One only has to remember the bubbly situation in the Middle East to appreciate fully the insecurity of supplies of crude oil. Australia has avoided this rundown in its reserves because of the increased exploration that has taken place. It has been estimated in some quarters that if at present we were buying all of our crude oil from overseas our annual payment would be in the vicinity of $4,500m, which of course would have an adverse effect upon our balance of payments and our balance of trade. Over and above that the Government would also be losing something like $3,096m in revenue which it has from the oil levy at present.

One only has to stop and think of what is happening in regard to our economy today. We have withstood the international pressures of great increases in interest rates. I agree that interest rates have risen in Australia, but there is a marked difference between interest rates in this country and interest rates in the major trading and manufacturing countries overseas. There has been a vast difference in inflation and in regard to deficits. Australia is reducing its deficit whilst many countries overseas have increased deficits. So we come back to the contribution that import parity has made to the stability of the economy of this country. I repeat: If we were running down reserves at present and becoming more dependent on overseas supplies we would have an adverse balance of payments and, of course, without import parity we would have had some $3,000m less revenue. One can see the benefits. Import parity pricing imposes what I call a progressive tax. It has made petrol dearer-we all appreciate this fact-but the person who can afford and who wishes to drive a big car, a luxury car, is using more litres per kilometre-we have to speak in metrics-and therefore is making a greater contribution because of import parity pricing than the person driving a smaller car.

Let us look at the comparative prices in Australia and overseas. I will cite recent figures relating to the period between October 1980 and January of this year. For example, in Italy the price of petrol is 73c a litre; Japan, 68c a litre; Norway, 65c a litre; France, 64c a litre; Greece, 63c a litre; Austria 56c a litre; West Germany, 50c a litre and the United Kingdom, 60c a litre. On the average, Australians have been paying about 33c a litre. Yes, we have been paying more for petrol with import parity pricing but let us be honest, for too long our petrol has been too cheap. I can only say that it was a completely wasted resource.

The reasons why the Government introduced import parity pricing are contained under the heading of 'Energy Policy' in the annual report of the Department of National Development and Energy. The first reason is to ensure conservation of liquid fuels. We can see that this is what has happened since petrol went up in price. Petroleum sales dropped by almost one per cent in 1980 compared with a 2 per cent increase in 1979. There has been 3 per cent difference in consumption in that area. The policy of fuel substitution has had its effect; it has conserved crude oil. In 1980 there was a rather substantial reduction in sales of heating oil. Sales were down by some 47 per cent; sales of lighting kerosene were down by 23 per cent; sales of industrial diesel decreased by 18 per cent and sales of fuel oil were down by 17 per cent. In 1980 the production of natural gas increased by 14 per cent and the sales of liquefied petroleum gas were also up by 9 per cent. These commodities previously were hardly ever used but today their use is on the increase. I have not been able to obtain the 1981 figures for consumption but I am certain that when we get further down the line, later in 1981, we will find the same indicators going in the same direction as in 1980.

In industry generally we find, for example, in Sydney in 1979 that industrial conversion from furnace oil to gas saved some 2 million barrels of oil. That is about one per cent of Australia's total liquid production. One can clearly see that in the field of conservation and substitution the Government policy is definitely working.

I turn now to the area of exploration. I think this is perhaps one of the most interesting areas of all. In 1972 the total number of wells drilled in Australia was some 101. There was a gradual decline until 1975 when the number of wells drilled totalled 23. Because of the exodus of drilling rigs from Australia and the lack of capacity and ability to do any drilling it took quite some years for the situation to recover. From 101 wells drilled in 1972 the figure declined to 23 wells in 1975, 21 wells in 1976 and 21 wells in 1977. By that time confidence was returning to the oil exploration industry. Also with the Government backing the policy of import parity which encouraged companies to explore for oil-a very costly exercise-there was an upturn in oil exploration. In 1978, the year of introduction of import parity pricing, 52 wells were drilled. In 1979, 59 wells were drilled and in 1980 some 86 wells were drilled.

This year the situation is even better. I will cite some figures from the APEA bulletin, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Assocation publication, which provides figures direct from industry, not from government. This year it is stated that over $400m will be spent on what is called wildcat exploration where companies, not knowing whether oil is present, drill structures in the hope of striking oil or gas. Over $1,000m will be spent on the development of oil fields that have already been proven. Here is the return of confidence to the industry which is a result of the backing of policies in this country. The expenditure of $1,400m will fund the drilling of 137 exploration wells in Australia. That is very different from 21 wells. In 1981 up to 130 exploration wildcat wells will be drilled and some 86 developmental wells will be drilled in Australia. This gives a total of some 220 wells. The figure given of 20 off-shore wells may be slightly lower because of the problem at present of getting exploration rigs. Having said that, there is confidence in the industry and the only limitation upon exploration of off-shore areas at present, as I said, is the limitation in the availability of rigs.

Oil exploration is very expensive. It is estimated that in Bass Strait it costs something like $10m to drill a well. At the Exmouth plateau the cost of drilling varies between $15m and $25m for one hole-win, lose or draw. When one talks about that sort of cost and distance away from the market place or refinery it can clearly be seen that there needs to be a sufficient guaranteed price for oil to make worth while the risks and to show companies they can make a profit. If this is not the case companies will not look for oil in remote areas. The North Sea was a shining example, in its initial stages, of what companies will do when the incentive is there to look.

I refer to a statement made in the Press a couple of days ago in which it was stated by a senior Canadian oil man that there will be much more Canadian investment and expertise coming into this country because of the adverse policies and disincentives of the Canadian Government at present. This is not the sort of thing we want to see happen in this country. There is a need to find more oil in Australia. Every incentive and every encouragement is being given to companies to explore. I am delighted to see that the response of the oil industry is such that it is prepared to pour in something like $1,400m in the current year purely in the area of oil exploration and development for a commodity that is so scarce throughout the world. If it can be found beneath our waters or on our mainland it will give us security, the sort of security we will need in today's energy-hungry world in which people are prepared to enter high-risk ventures.

The other thing that import parity has done-I do not have time to deal with it tonight because many other people wish to speak-is also in the area of substitute fuels. I refer to coal liquefaction. At the present time many overseas experts and technocrats are coming to Australia to assist in the research and, we hope, development of coal liquefaction which can take advantage of the huge coal reserves that we have in this country. This will be done only because of the fact that crude oil will continue to increase in price. The increase in price will mean that the stage will be reached where it will be economical to convert coal to liquids. If we did not have that increase in price then these gentlemen would not be here and the research would not go on. The same consideration also applies to our huge reserves of shale oil in Australia. I think the Government can be very pleased with the response that it has had to its policy which has been criticised. So many people in the country today are becoming more conscious of the fact that the right decisions were made. I am certain that in a few years time they will commend the Government for the stand it took and the courage, the wisdom and foresight it showed in its policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to devote most of my relatively short comments in supplementation of what Senator McLaren referred to, namely, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority annual report. Firstly I am prompted to make a few cautious observations on the remarks of Senator Young. I notice that his theme was the encouragement of oil exploration. He referred to the influx of exploration in Australia. I think he has to face up to the fact that one of the reasons the big oil corporations have turned to Australia is because there are so many areas of turbulence in the world where, in theory, they would have liked to explore. It could be Indonesia or different areas in the Middle East. When a new government comes to power the companies are expatriated. There is a certain amount of fear. I think we have to look at this situation in a more realistic form. They know on what side their bread is buttered.

SPEECH.PARA: Maybe Mr Trudeau has a conflict with various provincial governments in Canada. I do not think it matters whether it is the Ottawa or the Canberra government which wants to have the major say. Long before the Allende regime in Chile a Christian Democratic Party member named Frei was President. He is still around. I suppose he was a centrist. He was fairly progressive in some aspects of economic policy. In his book he gave some illuminating ideas about the Standard Oil Co. of New Jersey. Of course it had a big stake in Chile and Mr Frei found out that there had been no adjustment in royalties for 15 years. He told the oil companies that they could do better and they did. As Senator Cavanagh would appreciate, President Frei said: 'Look, I am not a leftist; I am a Christian Democrat'. The company said: 'It is our policy never to consider raising royalties unless the government pressures us'. I throw in that point because, as good as some of these oil companies appear to be, they try to get away with things. I read all their annual reports. I lay it on the line. I have no shares in any oil company.

I deal now with the conservation aspect. BP Australia Ltd brought Harry Butler to Barrow Island and now the habitat for wallabies has considerably improved. I think some other oil companies might emulate BP's policy and put back something in the field of conservation. Louisana in the United States has a very elaborate system in regard to conservation. I have my own views on this matter and I will not argue too much tonight about the role of State governments as against the role of the Federal Government on off-shore oil drilling. Recently I told one major oil group at a function that I hoped it would in some way emulate BP and do something for conservation. I make the same criticism of woodchip operators and people in our fishing industries as I do of oil exploration. The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has recommended a levy on woodchip exports. I would like to see a specific levy on oil exploration so that we reach the target of about $150,000 per annum which Dr Harry Frith wants for a beefed-up massive research into wildlife to combat certain ailments, whether it be an eye complaint with possums or something of that nature. This involves only a small cost to industry. Whether it be oil exploration or the woodchip industry generally. I believe the Federal Government and, in some instances, the State governments have to hint to the companies about a levy and let them come to the party.

I return to the remarks made by Senator McLaren. It is true that six or seven Saturdays ago I was very fortunate to participate in a function when at long last we unveiled a plaque in honour of 123 men who lost their lives in industrial accidents on that major project, the Snowy Mountains scheme. It was a very effective function. Unfortunately a very illustrious Premier, Sir William McKell, could not be present, but people of the calibre of a retired justice, Stan Taylor, Mr Charlie Oliver, a dominant figure in the Australian Workers Union, and a host of other people were present. Mr Oliver made a major contribution to the ceremony. I believe, now the plaque has been unveiled and homage has been paid to those who made that supreme sacrifice in the industrial field, the authority should see that adequate publicity is given to the long-delayed tribute to people from many lands. The tribute could be linked with the Department of Foreign Affairs. People could see in the Press through publicity, via our embassies, that we have paid some small tribute to these people who came from probably 30 different nations.

At the termination of the official proceedings Radio Yugoslavia was present and a number of Slovenes who spearheaded the agitation for this plaque were interviewed. They conveyed to Yugoslavia that the Australian Government, aided by the trade union movement and ethnic communities generally, had finally brought this recognition to fruition. I believe the matter should not end there. I think the authorities-the cost may be debited to the Department of Foreign Affairs-should see that this plaque and its tribute are projected overseas. I spoke to relatives of people who came here from the United States, Ireland, Yugoslavia which I mentioned earlier, and Italy. I think this tribute should be projected further afield.

The message that Senator McLaren conveyed was that there is nothing unclean or repugnant about centralised government from Canberra. The idealogical terminology 'democratic centralism' could have been used but I prefer to think the term 'defence powers' was hinted at. There is no question about it. After World War II there was a clamour for everyone to do his own thing. People have individual rights. If a nation is to be great, there must be some determination, some drive from Canberra. When the late President Kennedy was inaugurated he said that it was not a question of what America would do for people but what people would do for the United States. The same situation applies in relation to this project. It may be conceded that most of the States had enlightened Premiers, but if we did not have the necessary thrust from Canberra and hints that we may have had to use defence powers, we may not have got the project under way. There is no question about that.

I know that we are talking about mineral exploration. It is true that we cannot ignore its vital role at the moment. The most precious jewel in Australia has always been adequate water. I refer to that famous stanza 'I Love a Sunburnt Country'. The process of evaporation has always been a hidden enemy. That is why adequate water storage is of paramount importance. I have said again and again that the Federal Government constantly has to be in the vanguard with these sorts of projects. I think of the magnitude of the achievement in the Snowy Mountains. The dilution of central government in favour of State rights is bad for Australia. We cannot afford the luxury of it.

I was in the Northern Territory recently. Members of the Northern Territory administration were implying that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service rangers are foreigners. These suggestions always amaze me. If one applies that criterion, the bulk of people in high places in the Northern Territory are foreigners themselves. As the Senate would know, one of my prime targets is the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Paul Everingham. Let us look at Paul Everingham's history. He was educated at a college in Brisbane. He is a Queenslander. I do not hold it against any senator for being from Queensland-far from it. At the same time, I think we ought to face up to the fact that we are not Queenslanders, Victorians or New South Welshmen; we are Australians. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service rangers tell us how people ostracise them because they put the value of Australia ahead of some of the greedy mining companies for which Paul Everingham would sell his soul. There is no other way to put it. Paul Everingham is one of those people who genuflects in front of mining companies every week. I have before me a lovely letter from him. In fiendish delight he told me that he had personally dictated it. I do not mind. I have dictated letters to him which are just as vicious.

I make this point quite seriously. When I travel with Senate committees to this new frontier of the Northern Territory it jars me to see how Paul Everingham and his Ministers, his offsiders-I will not use the word 'lackeys'-look at us southerners and treat us with suspicion. I think that when we put our patriotism on the line, anybody who has served in this national Parliament can look any of his State counterparts in the eye and assure him that he is not a Benedict Arnold. I can see Senator Grimes nodding his head. I have grave doubts about some of the people who constitute the Northern Territory Parliament. Judging from some of the queer statements they make, they are almost on a par with one or two of the backwoodsmen in the Queensland Parliament who used to wage a vendetta against our colleage, Senator Georges. I regret-I do not want to discuss this in his absence-that the Senate's own venerable President has fallen over backwards at times to protect our detractors by preventing us from speaking in the same vein in the Senate. I think that the patience of most of us wears thin when we read the comments of some of the parliamentarians in Darwin. Of course I am talking about Paul Everingham and his crew, but the attitude of one or two Federal National Country Party parliamentarians from north Queensland is not much better. The way in which they go on is a disgrace to the parliamentary system. I think I have that target--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask the honourable senator to observe the Standing Orders. I am not quite sure how far they permit him to go.
—I think the reference to Paul Everingham being born in Queensland was a breach of Standing Order 418.
—I interpreted it in more or less that way myself. I ask Senator Mulvihill to continue.

—I say in reply to Senator Peter Baume's helpful interjection that I believe in brinkmanship. During my last visit to the Northern Territory-I am easily offended in these matters-I was appalled by one or two little incidents.

SPEECH.PARA: To wind up, the tocsin was sounded tonight by Senator McLaren in relation to the Federal Government becoming involved in more and bigger activities. The embarkation by the Federal Government on more of these national projects would not be in any way murky or unsavoury. There should be more of them. I repeat that the Snowy Mountains Authority brought together the best of a reasonable Australian nationalism. We did not aspire to anyone else's territory. With the bonanza that may occur in relation to off-shore oil drilling-with all respect to Senator Young-Canberra has to keep its eye on the wheeler-dealers. We have to see that we get a fair share of the taxation revenue. We have to see that we get royalties to put into our conservation schemes, our wildlife projects and these sorts of things.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always listen with a great amount of interest to Senator Mulvihill's contributions in the Senate. I know that he is motivated by a genuine concern about development in Australia and the possible consequences for our environment. But I suggest that the use of the words 'greedy mining companies' is not quite appropriate.
—I exempted BP.

—I will get to that. I applaud Senator Mulvihill for what he has said, but I suggest that we have to remember that exploration in Australia is a very costly venture. I think the words 'greedy mining companies' are not appropriate in this context. We have to remember that mining companies provide jobs for many Australians. Many trade unionists depend upon these companies to develop the industry in which they are interested.
—They are most philanthropic organisations.

—There is nothing wrong with profit. It is only by making profits that we can provide further job opportunities for the trade unionists of Australia. I believe that that is what we ought to be thinking about at present. I certainly agree with Senator Mulvihill that mining companies must have due regard to the need to restore the environment and to provide some assistance for research into the effects on wildlife of their particular operations. I support Senator Mulvihill on that matter, but I do not think that continually referring to these companies as 'greedy mining companies', would encourage them. I suggest that the use of that description is psychologically wrong and that it would be more appropriate to couch phrases in a way that would encourage the mining companies to achieve the results that Senator Mulvihill and I would like them to achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal with the papers relating to the Ranger uranium project. Having been in that part of Australia on four separate occasions, I think I am in a position to recognise the problems as well as the progress that is being made in developing uranium in the Northern Territory. The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, of which I am chairman, determined to examine the area before mining commenced at Ranger and after mining was completed at Nabarlek. Recently we returned to examine the situation after the processing of ore had commenced at Nabarlek and when the processing plant was being constructed at Ranger. Even before that, some committee members visited the Australian Atomic Energy Commission at Lucas Heights to obtain from people who are experienced in those areas of scientific knowledge information on the environmental aspects of the region. I was pleased to learn that the Atomic Energy Commission had done basic studies on that area for about eight years and to a degree had established baselines upon which it could judge the impact of future mining in the area. I was pleased to note that the mining companies concerned are very conscious of the need to respect the environment.

In the Nabarlek area there is a small, very rich, ore body, and the processing period will last for only about eight years. In spite of that, the companies are very conscious of the need to monitor the environmental impact on the waters surrounding the area. In concert, and under the supervision of the Supervising Scientist I believe they are making a credible attempt to monitor their activities. The Ranger proposition, of course, is far greater in extent because its ore body is far larger. In fact, the latest resource estimates for Nabarlek are 7,000 tonnes of ore, with a planned initial production capacity of 830 tonnes per annum. The latest resource estimates for Ranger are 77,200 tonnes of uranium with a planned initial production capacity of 2,300 tonnes. So the two projects are vastly different. In regard to Ranger, I was interested to learn that in the 1980 annual report of Peko-Wallsend Ltd it is stated:

On 8 September 1980, an Agreement was entered into by E.R.A., Peko and EZ with a number of German and Japanese organisations, principally being power utilities, for those organisations to participate as shareholders in E.R.A. In addition, those overseas organisations, or interests related to them entered into sales contracts with E.R.A. to purchase 30,648 tonnes of uranium concentrates over the period 1982 to 1996. Adding to this the 6,320 tonnes of concentrates already sold by Peko and EZ and the 1,011 tonnes of concentrate previously borrowed by Peko and EZ from the Government stockpile and due to be returned to it, approximately 84 per cent of the initial designed capacity of the Ranger project has now been sold or otherwise committed.

I was also interested to learn that the initial planned stages of this project will last for about 15 years but that the whole project is contemplated as being a 30-year development program. In regard to Ranger, a laboratory costing $1.3m has been completed at Jabiru. This laboratory is currently manned by a staff of nine scientists and laboratory assistants, who are continually monitoring the environmental aspects of the mining area, including water quality tests and the effect of mining on birds and feral animals. This staff is headed by a scientist who spent a number of years with the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The number of staff will be increased ultimately to, I think, about 14 people, and it is costing the company about $1m a year to service and run the operation.

When I was at Jabiru I was impressed by what the scientist in charge told me. He said that he believes that, to his knowledge, the environmental laboratory is the best in Australia and probably one of the best in the southern hemisphere. That indicates that the companies concerned have quite a regard for the need to manage their operations properly and to ensure that whatever they do is not to the detriment of the environment of the area. While I was there I was interested also in a proposition being contemplated to build a laboratory, at an estimated cost of over $5m, which can be used jointly by the Commonwealth Government and the Government of the Northern Territory. The laboratory is planned to be constructed in the Ranger area. I think this proposal is very important because it will bring together in one building the scientific expertise of both the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. Of course, the cost of construction will be shared between the Commonwealth Government and the Northern Territory Government.

I believe this is a very important matter that must be given priority by the Government in the forthcoming Budget, and I am sure that all members of my Committee would agree with that concept. I notice that Senator Mulvihill is nodding, and I am sure that Senator Melzer would appreciate the value of bringing together this scientific expertise to ensure that we maximise our surveillance, under the office of the Supervising Scientist, of the operations being carried out in that very significant developmental area of Australia. I imagine that within a fairly short time the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment will have more to say about that matter. Senator Mulvihill made a very important point which must be borne in mind. In any development which goes on in this country, whether it be oil exploration, oil development, or gas development, there must be some element to look after the conservation of our wildlife and our natural environment.

The other point on which I will touch briefly is the matter of nuclear fuel. In spite of what is said these days by many people in the community, there is no question in my mind that nuclear fuel, nuclear power, is less damaging to the environment in general terms than any other fuel. I say that because in December I visited the Hinkley Point B nuclear power station in Devon in the United Kingdom, and I was most impressed by the conducted tour I had. The engineers certainly have a very great regard for the environment surrounding that power station. In fact, they conduct regular tests on animals within a radius of about 10, 15 or 20 kilometres of that power station. They do regular checks on the milk of the cows in the area, the vegetation, and so on to ensure that there is no elevation in the level of natural radiation that persists in the surrounding countryside. I was quite happy that they were monitoring their operations with infinite care. The following day I spent talking with officials of the Department of the Environment in the United Kingdom. They are extremely relaxed about storage technology for radioactive waste. At present about 20,000 tonnes of radioactive waste are stored in what they regard to be perfectly satisfactory and secure conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—The honourable senator knows very well. The waste is stored in secure areas. It is stored in concrete and stainless steel containers. The United Kingdom is employing the vitrification technology which is well known or should be well known to honourable senators. The waste is monitored regularly to ensure that the radioactivity is within the prescribed limits.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention one significant aspect. That source of energy will be available very soon. United Kingdom nuclear technology is at a stage where the waste will be able to be utilised as fuel with absolutely minimal residual environmental effects. It will provide the same amount of energy that 48 million tonnes of coal would generate. Such coal generation would have absolutely disastrous consequences on the environment because of the proliferation of CO2 and SO2 and is a far greater problem than the generation of nuclear power. The 20,000 tonnes of radioactive waste would also generate the same amount of power that would be generated from the use of 27 million tonnes of oil which would last the United Kingdom for 750 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are they going ahead with the reprocessing plant?

—No doubt we will see energy policies emerge. I imagine that in the future we will learn a lot from the developments in the United Kingdom. One aspect of the United Kingdom's conservation policy worries me in particular and also the Department of the Environment. People are encouraged to insulate their homes. Many homes in Yorkshire, Scotland and other parts of the United Kingdom are built of granite. Horror of horrors! Granite happens to be radioactive. At present, uninsulated, a granite house will experience an air exchange about five times in an hour. Over the centuries there has been no statistical evidence of any increase in the presence of cancer in people who live in those areas--
—You cannot say that. There is no information on which you can base that.

—Just a moment. I have discussed this matter. Knowing Senator Melzer's paranoia I wanted to be able to assure her that no statistical evidence in England gathered over the years shows any increase in cancer in areas containing granite houses compared with other areas where people are living in non-radioactive houses. I am concerned-Senator Melzer should also be concerned-about what happens when the granite radioactive houses are insulated. When these houses are insulated the air exchange will be reduced to once or twice per hour. I am worried about that. I am worried about Parliament House in Adelaide, which is radioactive. It is built of granite. I am worried because the radioactivity of Parliament House in Adelaide is far greater than the radiation that was emitted from the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories at Thebarton. We do not worry about that radiation; that is acceptable. We do not worry about eating, for example, brazil nuts which happen to be the most radioactive substance we can eat.
—You are talking a lot of rubbish. You are not even reading the right reports.
—I am using scientific fact which the honourable senator would not understand.
—Who proved the facts?

—It is fact. Medical science can show that even the honourable senator is radioactive. We are all radioactive. Let us forget about the emotional nonsense that is evident in Australia at present. We have to start worrying about other sources of energy. Coal development is responsible for hundreds and thousands of deaths and God knows how many cases of emphysema and lung disease. How many people are suffering from radiation as a result of coal mining, which is far more hazardous than uranium mining?
—You have read only pro-uranium literature. You have not read articles from both sides.

—My mind is open. I have a certain amount of scientific background to my knowledge. I do not react, as Senator Coleman does, in an emotive uneducated way at all. What I have said is based on scientific fact. The sooner the people of Australia and the world recognise the facts the better. I attended a conference on science and technology policy in Ottawa. Canadians are extremely concerned at the burning of fossil fuels in America. The prevailing winds takes the sulphur dioxides and the carbon dioxides over the border. The acid rain which falls on the lakes of Canada creates tremendous environmental problems. Fish, wildlife and trees are dying in the vicinity of the industries. The sooner people recognise that that is a far greater hazard to the world than nuclear power the better. I suggest that we start thinking very seriously about these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The last matter I would like to deal with in the spirit of friendliness and co-operation that exists in this chamber relates to the River Murray Commission and the River Murray. This matter has been the subject of incredible interest. (Quorum formed). I thank Senator McLaren for attracting an audience for me. I was about to speak on water and water resources, a subject which I believe is quite important nationally. I was about to mention the annual report of the River Murray Commission and the fact that in recent times that report has attracted a lot of attention, as well it should. It reports on matters of vital significance not only to Australia as a nation but also to South Australia in particular. Over a great number of years, probably 10 years-significantly, since the presentation of the report of the Davidson Committee, as Senator Mulvihill often calls the Senate Select Committee on Water Pollution-we have heard a lot about and we have dealt with, I suppose in a tiresome way, water pollution.

Subsequent reports have been presented, drawing the attention of the Federal Government and the State governments to the need to establish a national water authority to deal with the problem of water pollution in a constructive, proper and co-ordinated way. Our Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, in its report dealing with the continuing scrutiny of water pollution in the River Murray system, supported the contention that that ought to happen. We suggested that the River Murray Commission ought to be given the teeth required to enable it to supervise water quality. I am glad to say that in recent times the necessity for that appears to have been recognised by the Federal Government and the State governments concerned. I think the Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator Carrick, said the other day that he hoped that that aspect of the activities of the River Murray Commission would be dealt with this session. I hope that that happens because many of us, on both sides of the House, believe that that is a critically important aspect of the management of the River Murray system.

Our Committee went further: We stated that the River Murray Commission ought to have the teeth and authority to deal with flood plain management, recreational activities along the river banks, industrial development and so on. I know that that is a difficult task because we have the Commonwealth-State problem; but I cannot see anything wrong with the River Murray Commission being given the authority to determine the parameters for the types of activities that ought to be carried out along that important river.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Commission deal with problems which emanate from salt coming from Queensland and so forth?

—That is exactly the point. Senator Thomas is the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, which conducted an inquiry into water. Senator McLaren is a member of that Committee and I have indicated already how much Senator Thomas appreciates his input on that Committee. Senator Thomas has demonstrated that that issue has to be dealt with. We need a national water authority. I suggest that within that authority there ought to be a special centre of excellence to deal with salinity and other pollutants associated with the rivers of Australia. Very little research has been done on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it was Senator McLaren who the other day said something about the record of New South Wales and said that we should not worry too much about the increasing numbers of licences being granted along the tributaries of the Darling River, Yanco Creek and, I think, the Macquarie River. But that really worries me. I have some figures dealing with the sodium levels in the River Murray. I have also some information on the effect of elevated sodium levels in public drinking water as a contributor to elevated blood pressure levels in members of the community. I will read an abstract from a paper I have which was written by Robert Tuthill, Ph.D., and Edward Calabrese, Ph.D., of the Division of Public Health, School of Health Sciences, at the University of Massachusetts. The paper states:

Further statistical analyses of previously reported preliminary data upheld results showing elevated levels of sodium in drinking water may exert an adverse health effect on normal, healthy persons. High school sophomores residing in a community with elevated levels of sodium in the drinking water(107 mg/l) exhibited a marked upward shift in blood pressure distribution patterns in systolic and diastolic pressure, when compared with students in an approximately matched community (8 mg/l). Females exhibited a blood pressure distribution pattern characteristic of persons 10 yr older, while for the males the upshift was similar to that of a group approximately 2 yr older.

That was compiled in late 1979. Subsequently, doubt was cast on those claims in a survey conducted by the University of Western Australia. That seems to me to indicate that more research on that health matter is required in Australia. I also have figures that demonstrate the following for South Australia: At Morgan the average sodium content of a litre of water is 90 milligrams, with a maximum of 159 milligrams; at Mannum the average is 88 milligrams, with a maximum of 165 milligrams; and at Murray Bridge the average is 80 miligrams, with a maximum of 187 milligrams. That might explain why occasionally Senator McLaren becomes very excited about matters raised in this place. I suggest that drinking water with a sodium content of 187 milligrams a litre would give Senator McLaren cause for serious concern. In interstate terms, the Jack Club syndrome prevails. I will demonstrate that. People in New South Wales do not worry very much about the salinity problem because the sodium content of their water is 13 milligrams a litre. In Melbourne it is about 5 milligrams a litre. So the Jack Club membership in Melbourne and Sydney is pretty strong. It appears that to them it does not matter very much what happens downstream, although I know that some honourable senators would not subscribe to that view.

I have said before and other senators have said here tonight that water is our most important and vital national resource. We take it for granted. We waste it. We recklessly pour it on gardens. I remember that when I was a boy my father always told me to turn off the taps. Why did he do that in those days? He did it simply because he could not afford to pay for water. My father taught, as I hope a lot of people in Australia today are doing, the value of water. My father taught me also the value of turning off lights, which is of paramount importance today. In those days we turned off the taps and the lights because my dad could not afford to pay the bills. We had to keep the costs down. We had to conserve for a different reason from our reasons today. But today the need is greater, in my opinion. Today it is not just a matter of my father or anyone else's father dealing with the problem in terms of economics; it is now a matter of national significance that people should turn off the taps and the lights to ensure the further development of this nation. With those words, I suggest that the Government ought to give the matter of water far greater priority than it has done in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on the papers covering the amendment to the agreement between the Fraser Government and the uranium miners all over the world and the paper that puts forward the apologia for reducing the safeguards under which the Fraser Government will sell our uranium. For many years in Australia the population has been against the exporting of Australian uranium. A gallup poll taken as recently as the beginning of this month showed that more than four in 10 Australians believed that the Federal Government was wrong to encourage the export of uranium. The number who feel that the Federal Government is wrong in exporting uranium has increased every year since 1975, and I see no reason why that number will not go on increasing until we have the vast majority of people in Australia strongly telling whatever government happens to be in power that they feel that, until the world can handle uranium, the export of that substance is wrong. People believe it is wrong because they know that the technology is not advanced to a point where nuclear power can be handled safely. If we need any great example of that, Three Mile Island is perhaps the most well known. It is not the only reactor that has caused and will go on causing problems but it is certainly the one that people know the best.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to find people such as Senator Jessop who, in most areas, can be a quite sane, reasonable human being but when it comes to nuclear power he cannot see any reason or logic. He maintains that nuclear power is the power that will do the least damage to the environment. If that is so, I wonder why most countries that have moved into nuclear power in any way at all are now moving away from nuclear power as fast as they can. For instance, was there ever another power station in the position that Three Mile Island is in at the moment? Has there ever been another power station that has endangered the lives of the people around the area and will go on endangering the lives of the people around the area until science can find a way of defusing it? At the moment, Three Mile Island is not defused because science cannot find a way to defuse the dangers.

If coal-powered plants are as dangerous as Government senators such as Senator Jessop maintain they are, why do those senators such as Senator Jessop not do something about it? Why are they not campaigning as strongly against coal-powered stations as those of us who believe that uranium and nuclear power are dangerous are campaigning against nuclear-powered stations? There can be only two answers: Firstly, they do not believe that coal-powered stations are dangerous or, secondly, they do not care. Frankly, I do not care for either of those answers. People are afraid of uranium because it is used to produce nuclear weapons and nothing that Government senators can say will defuse that argument. They have to accept that that is so. People are concerned because of the increasingly irresponsible attitude in the world to the production and use of nuclear weapons. None of that can happen unless we take our uranium out of the ground. There are an increasing number of countries which either have nuclear weapons and the material and the technology to produce those weapons, or wish to acquire the weapons, the material and the technology. All the fears that people around the world have about those areas are very well founded.

In every country where the production of nuclear power has been attempted there have been accidents. There have been accidents that caused death immediately or there have been accidents that caused creeping death by cancer over 30 years. Some consequences of the accidents are not even known yet because, as we have so often said, the cancers that are caused by radiation do not make themselves very obvious until it is almost too late.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which deaths have been caused directly?
—In the United States of America, many cancers have been caused directly by radiation and fall-out from nuclear power plants.
—That is pure supposition.

—It is not supposition. If Senator Thomas were really concerned he would read the papers, he would read the books, he would read the information that comes out of the United States that quite openly links cancer with nuclear power, with the production of plutonium. Senator Thomas should not shake his head. It is true. If he does not like the scientific facts, if he does not want to read them and if he wants to live in cloud cuckoo land, he can go on that way. But, I suggest, there are many parts of the United States he would not live in because of the prevalence of cancers in those areas. In countries such as the USA, Canada, Japan, France, Britain, West Germany, Italy, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Spain, there have been break downs and there have been accidents. There have been accidents that have caused long periods of close down of those nuclear power stations and there have been consequences to the health of people in those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: One fact that is little known, I suggest, is that a nuclear power plant was established in the Antarctic in he 1960s. The Americans took a nuclear power plant there because they said, and Senator Jessop and so many other Government senators would agree with them, that it was a safe, good way to produce power-safe, clean and with a renewable source of energy. But it did not last very long because the power plant broke down. It had all the usual problems that nuclear power plants all over the world had had and even the Americans were a little afraid of what the consequences might be of leakage from the plant. So, late in the 1960s they packed it up, dug out the contaminated material-we all hope-and took it out of the Antarctic. One's imagination boggles at what the effect may very well have been on the fragile ecosytem in the Antarctic if that power plant had been allowed to remain there. What the effect of a melt down in the Antarctic would be is horrific to imagine. The interesting part is that there is a treaty that prohibits the use of nuclear power in the Antarctic, yet a nuclear power plant was established and working there. So much for treaties. So much for pieces of paper.

In all those countries I have listed, the people have demanded a closedown of nuclear power plants. They have demanded by public vote in very many areas that those power plants be closed down. They have demanded it to the extent that governments have had to listen. They have demanded it in the face of facts showing that millions of dollars of their money had gone into those power plants. Nonetheless, they have said: 'Close them down. You have not shown us that you can handle the technology and you do produce the material from which nuclear weapons are made'. Are all these people all over the world wrong and only the uranium industry right? I doubt it. But it is not just the ordinary person, the man in the street who is worried and concerned. There are concerns other than that people's health and lives may be at stake. More and more energy utilities are today shying away from nuclear energy. They are moving away from nuclear energy because of the continuing closedown of the plants, because of the faults, because they cannot build good nuclear power stations yet, because of the uncertainty of supply of electricity, because the power plants close down so often and with so little warning. They are also moving away from it because of the increasing cost. The cost is rising because of the increasing demands by populations for more stringent safety precautions when nuclear power stations are built. Those increasing costs cause greatly increased building costs that now run into billions when one talks about building a nuclear power plant. There is also, of course, the enormous cost of closing down a nuclear power plant. As the Americans have found to their horror, the cost of cleaning up plants such as Three Mile Island when they go bad is running into the millions. The quote at the moment for cleaning up Three Mile Island is $300m-plus.
At the same time the Americans admit that they do not yet know how to clean up Three Mile Island, how long it will take, or what the consequenses will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been reading the wrong novels.

—The honourable senator has been reading novels; he should start reading facts. The long delay in the clean up of the damaged reactor at Three Mile Island is now leading people in the industry to believe that it will be at least 1988 before the installation is back anywhere near to normality; and that is 10 years after its installation. A newspaper report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, in its final report on the environmental problems of the site in Pennsylvania, said radioactive solid wastes and more than 6.7 million litres of contaminated water had to be removed from the plant.
The report said that the task could take as long as eight years.
A major accident at the plant on March 28, 1979 caused the uncontrollable release of radiation and the evacuation of more than 100,000 residents living nearby.
The clean-up operation has been suspended until the NRC and other government organisations prepare environmental impact studies.

Of course, if 6.7 million litres of contaminated water is to be taken away from the plant, it has to be put somewhere; and nobody in America wants it in their backyard. The newspaper report continued:
NRC commissioners said today they are waiting for Metropolitan Edison, the owner of the facility, to present a detailed plan for cleaning up the plant.
The commission said it did not regard Three Mile Island as a safe waste-disposal site.
'Removing the damaged fuel and radioactive waste to suitable storage sites is the only reliable means of eliminating the risk of widespread contamination . . . '

So the company will not be allowed to leave the material on the site and will have to find somewhere to take it. That will cost billions of dollars and will take at least another 10 years. The cost will be borne not by the utility company, the company that was proposing to make money out of the electricity it produced, but by the taxpayers of America. That is another reason why people all over the world are moving away from nuclear power. They say that in so many ways it is just too costly. Other consequences of areas such as Three Mile Island are becoming obvious. Of course, Senator Thomas would like to believe that this is all fiction, but it is very apparent that it is not. Another newspaper report stated:
The infant mortality rate within a 16 km radius of the Three Mile Island nuclear power station has risen sharply.
In the six months after the accident on March 28 last year, 31 infants under the age of 12 months died compared to 14 deaths in the corresponding period in 1978 and 20 in 1977.
The figures were released today by Doctor Gordon MacLeod, who was fired as Secretary of Health in Pennsylvania by Governor Richard Thornburgh because of 'differences in institutional style'.
It would not, of course, have had anything to do with the research he did! To continue:
Initially, a Health Department spokesman denied such figures existed.
The spokesman said the mortality rate was twice the State average.
He was not prepared to associate the increased mortality rate among infants with radioactive emissions from the facility last year.
But he said accident-related stress in pregnant women might have caused the infant death rate to increase.

It might not have caused it, too. It is interesting that all these problems besetting the nuclear power industry are causing the power utilities to move away from nuclear power. Yet another newspaper report stated:

Eleven nuclear plants in the United States are now nearing completion. But they will not go into operation this year or next without 'drastic remedial steps' by the Federal Government, according to the Atomic Industrial Forum, the nuclear industry's trade group.
The Forum blames the dilemma on the delays between completion of a plant and the award of an operating licence by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them aren't licensed, anyway.
—It will not give them a licence because they cannot prove that they are safe. The report continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Because it is not producing power to pay off construction and interest expenses, the typical idle plant costs $US1 million a day, the Forum says.
That would add up to $US2.4 billion per plant over the expected 80 months of delays on the new plants. All that expense has to be passed on to the utility's customers.
Is it any wonder that people are shying away from nuclear power? The report continued:

Charles Komanoff, a New York energy and economic consultant, . . . asserts that for the plants now being completed, coal enjoys a 'modest' total cost advantage of perhaps 5 to 10 per cent that he conservatively sees widening to 25 per cent by the late 1980s. The main reason for this, he said, is that tougher standards for nuclear power will almost necessarily result as regulators attempt to maintain a given aggregate level of nuclear operating risk while the total number of nuclear plants in service rises.
In Mr Komanoff's view any utility such as Duke Power with nuclear units less than about one-third completed, should consider building coal plants instead, even if nothing could be salvaged . . .

In the end, industry officials say, the extent of nuclear rejuvenation depends not only on curbing inflation and finding a way to dispose of spent fuel but also on other factors of acceptance in the community. The disposal of spent fuel, of waste, is also a cause of great distress to the nuclear power industry, because there is as yet no answer to it. For years now the nuclear industry in America has been demanding of its Government that it find a way to dispose of the waste. It has said: 'We cannot go on and we will not go on. We refuse to go on taking the responsibility unless you provide a way to dispose of the waste'. It said that to the last President of the United States and undoubtedly it will say it to this President. Of course, it says it to the Government partly because in many ways the Government, through its military use of plutonium and thus its production of nuclear waste, has been at fault and has done nothing about providing waste disposal. It was reported recently that about 100 million cubic feet-three million cubic metres-of potentially harmful military nuclear waste have been virtually ignored in our national debate on nuclear power. A Press report stated:
This poorly stored and carefully shrouded mountain of radioactive materials represents the hidden burden of the arms race.

The same report went on to point out that radioactive rodent droppings had been found in the basement of an uncontaminated control and service building at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, the site of the worst commercial nuclear accident in the United States. Of course, that came not from military waste but from nuclear power plant waste. It went on to say very smartly that there is no possibility of radiation exposure from a rodent bite; but it did not say how those rates became radioactive, nor did it explain why people could not become radioactive from the same source. It has been said often by the proponents of the nuclear power industry that there is no problem in the storing of waste, it can be buried in salt domes. That too has been tried in many places, including the United States. It was interesting to discover recently that in the United States salt domes are being used to store not only nuclear waste but also hydrocarbons. I have here a report concerning a lady called Mary Harmon in Texas, which states:

. . . the domes are more worry than wonder. She and 2,754 others live over the largest hydrocarbon-storage dump in the United States. Last fall, when it began leaking gas, hundreds of townspeople had to be evacuated. Most have still not returned to their homes, and several have retaliated with law suits against eleven firms that store petrochemicals in the ground. Says Harmon: 'I wish that someone else had a salt dome and we had our town back'.

That was for hydrocarbons. But one wonders what the result would have been if radio active waste had been stored in the same salt dome. We know, of course, that America has already dumped waste in the Pacific. In a recent publication of Chain Reaction it was reported that:

After several years of incessant prodding the USA Environmental Protection Agency was forced to release the results of 1977 surveys of the major USA nuclear dumpsites, including one that occupies 12,500 square kilometres near the Farallon Islands off San Francisco. As scientific adviser to Quentin Kopp, Superviser of San Francisco, I analyzed the EPA data and found:
plutonium levels 2,000 times above background in ocean bottom sediment
deteriorating containers, with the worst contamination yet to come
extensive animal life in the dumpsite
released radioactivity stuck to the ocean bottom in the dumpsite, rather than dispersed by diffusion
radioactivity 5,000 times background in animal life, including edible fish.
In sworn testimony before Congressional Hearings last October the EPA could deny none of these disclosures.

The USA seadump programme was ended in 1970 not to protect the environment but to save money. It simply became cheaper to dispose of nuclear wastes on land. But now that land sites are filling up, the nuclear industry is again turning to the sea to bury its wastes. There are no fewer than six active programmes in the USA involving ongoing or resumed nuclear dumping at sea-

So it goes on. Dumping in that sea means that that material can wash on to any shore and certainly can wash on to Australia's shore. America has dumped nuclear waste in the sea. We know that West Germany has had problems with storing waste. On 1 March this year 80,000 demonstrators defied a court ruling against demonstrating and went out against the building of a nuclear waste dump in part of West Germany. It took 30,000 police and 10,000 special riot police to control the demonstration. Are we saying that these people are all just maniacs and are all just emtional? Eighty thousand people do not go out demonstrating against something unless the have great grounds for concern. We should have equal grounds for concern. We know that Japan wants to dump her nuclear waste in the Pacific. It is a problem which she has found very difficult to overcome. We know that Britain has dumped 10 times the amount that the United States of America has dumped in the sea.

So already if we do not do anything else, if we do not produce one other ounce of uranium, of enriched uranium or of plutonium, we have a problem which the world will find very difficult to solve. If Australia contributes to the proliferation of nuclear weapons, to the proliferation of nuclear waste and to the proliferation of power stations which can cause radiation and fall-out which endanger the lives of people, it has to accept responsibility because Australia makes the material available if it exports uranium. Once uranium is exported we have no control over where the waste goes. It is all very well for the Government to maintain that its safeguards agreement will prevent our uranium being used for weapons, but before we get to that point it cannot even control the waste which comes from using uranium to produce plutonium for weapons and power from nuclear power stations.

We are considering in these reports the conditions in which we will allow the reprocessing of Australian uranium. The Government maintains that the safeguards agreements will prevent our uranium being used for weapons. There are now more than 300,000 nuclear weapons in the world and the number is increasing all the time. The world spends $400,000m a year on nuclear arms. And this Government expects a piece of paper to keep our uranium out of the pile from which those weapons are produced! Does the Government believe this or does it want us to believe it and so allow the Japanese, the Canadians, the British, the French, the Swedes and the Germans to come here to mine our uranium, providing no great assistance to the Australian people, with great concessions from Australian taxpayers. This would contribute to nuclear proliferation in the world? It does not make sense. Why should a French company mining here care two hoots about a piece of paper which states that Australia's uranium must not finish up in nuclear weapons? What will we do about it if it does? How can we check that that little pound of uranium from Australia has not finished up in the pile from which plutonium is produced and which goes into nuclear weapons? What do we do about the nuclear weapons testing which the French carry out in the Pacific? Nothing. What can we possibly do to prevent our uranium finishing up in nuclear weapons?

A United Nations report estimates that 150,000 people have been killed or will die from nuclear tests which have already taken place. The report states that only 10 per cent of those people come from the southern hemisphere, but with the French persisting in nuclear testing in the Pacific how long will it be before that percentage increases? I suggest that Australia might get her uranium back sooner than she thinks, and in a quite uncomfortable way. We all know that the material from which nuclear bombs can be made has been stolen and has been diverted. It used to be a comfort to the Government to say that very sophisticated equipment and plant were needed before a nuclear weapon could be made. We all know now that that is not so and that terribly sophisticated equipment and high grade enriched plutonium are not needed to produce nuclear weapons and that one can produce a rather crude bomb without that sophisticated material and equipment. But a rather crude bomb kills, maims and kills by radiation in much the same way as a more sophisticated bomb does.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the fallout is worse.

—And the fallout, as my friend says, is worse. We cannot put up great big brick walls around ourselves-nor can other countries do it-to stop that fallout drifting across a country's frontier. We were told, as part of the apologia by the Fraser Government on allowing uranium mining, that the mining of uranium would bring great prosperity to Australia. At one stage, Mr Anthony waxed eloquent and said that 300 jobs would flow from the uranium province in the Northern Territory. Where is the prosperity which was supposed to come? Where are the sales? We have to beg countries to take the ore which we mine. Ministers rush all over the world begging countries to sign contracts for the purchase of our uranium. We have to water down our safeguards agreements to get those countries to put their signatures on the bottom of these safeguards agreements which are necessary before they can sign the contracts. The price for uranium has fallen to $25 a pound and it is likely to fall to $20 a pound. In fact the other day the Wall Street Journal stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Declining nuclear power projections, large uranium inventories in utility backyards and serious overexpansion in uranium mining have together conspired to bring the world market price of uranium fuel to its lowest level in 5 years.

According to the Californian-based uranium brokerage firm, Nuexico, prices for the heavy metal have dropped by nearly 30 per cent in the last year. In 1977 uranium prices stood at a high of $53 a pound in 1980 dollars. Today's price, again in 1980 dollars, is $35 a pound, the lowest price since 1975. The Wall Street Journal states that the market could not be worse. The miners therefore are getting desperate for a return. If one has invested over $400m in a project and the price is falling one is worried. It takes a lot of sales at $25 or $20 a pound to bring in a profit on that sort of investment when the industry is dying. We were told that there would be 300,000 jobs. When I went to Nabarlek and Ranger with Senator Jessop two weeks ago we found that only four men were needed to run the Nabarlek processing plant-not hundreds, not thousands, but only four men could run the entire processing plant. So where will the 300,000 jobs come from? Ranger is not yet finished, but its plant will not be all that much bigger than the Nabarlek plant. How many more than four men will be needed to run the Ranger plant-eight? For the next 30 years we could have eight men running the Ranger processing plant. Thousands of jobs, Mr Anthony said! Of course Ranger will have miners. Sometimes I think Government members would like to think we are back in the days when miners went off every morning with their hat, lamp and pick, but we do not mine that way any more. So there will not be thousands of jobs there.

It is interesting how two people can go to the same place and yet see things so differently. I went to the Ranger area with Senator Jessop. Certainly the Atomic Energy Commission has done studies on base lines for water control, for the control of fauna and flora in the area, but the overwhelming point, if one cares about the environment at all, is that no base lines have been established. We still cannot tell anybody what insects were in the area, what plants were in the area, what animals were in the area, where the water in the area goes or what the quality of the water was before we started to mine uranium. Of course the mining companies are concerned to respect the environment. Why should not they be? Because they have now found difficulties which they have always refused to believe existed they are now more anxious to do research into this area. For instance, when people told the mining companies that the area flooded and had enormous quantities of water over it the companies said of course they could cope with all that and it could not be so impossible. When we went there two metres of water were lying over the site where the mine in Jabiluka is supposed to be built. Even the uranium miners are worried about how on earth they are going to control a mine when in an ordinary year-there was nothing extraordinary about the level of water this year-two metres of water is lying over the surface of the area.

Senator Jessop said that the mining companies are monitoring water flows up there, including the movement of water in the area. Of course they are, but they are doing it because they are forced to do it; because the people of Australia made this Government at least acknowledge that the mining companies had some responsibility in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you shown figures on the levels of uranium in the Alligator Rivers before any activity at all commenced?

—Senator, you have been listening to the Atomic Energy Commission for too long. There were no levels of uranium in the water before mining started in the area, certainly not in all the rivers there. Senator Jessop spoke in glowing terms about the tonnes of uranium for which the uranium mining companies have overseas contracts. He forgot to say that in respect of many of those contracts Australia has not yet got signatures on safeguards agreements from the countries to which the uranium miners hope to sell the uranium. For instance, we have not yet got a signature from Japan on a nuclear safeguards agreement; so we cannot very well have signatures on the contract. Senator Jessop spoke glowingly about the $1.3m laboratory that Ranger built in the area. He should have pointed out at the same time that the Supervising Scientist works up there in a series of portables and that this Government has done precious little about giving him the sort of laboratory he needs if he is to do his work properly. There are still no signs that the money will be made available for the construction of a proper laboratory with proper equipment to give dedicated scientists the chance to catch up on the enormous amount of work that needs to be done. The spending at Ranger might show that the companies are concerned, but all I can say in respect of the Government laboratory there is that the spending shows how little regard the Government has for the work that should be done in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to know just how much these uranium mines are costing the ordinary people. It is hard to find out because in so many areas subsidies appear to be hidden from the view of people, even members of Senate committees. For instance, when we were there two weeks ago we discovered that electricity for a house being built at Jabiru, the township, will be $1,600 a year. That is not the real cost of electricity in the area. That cost is based on north Queensland rates which are subsidised. The Commonwealth will pay the difference between that $1,600 a year and the real cost of electricity in this area. Again the taxpayers will subsidise the uranium miners.

Uranium mining is endangering our environment. We are not getting any sort of advantage from uranium mining. No jobs are flowing from the mining of uranium. There is no increase in the standard of living of the Australian people. They are not getting any share of the prosperity that is flowing out of the uranium mining at the moment. We are, as I said, endangering our environment. We are endangering the lives of the Aboriginal people who live in the area. We are endangering the lives of the workers in the uranium industry and in the long run by supplying the materials we endanger the lives of the people in the countries to which we export uranium because the technology for producing electricity from uranium is demonstrably imperfect. We endanger people all over the world because we provide the raw material from which nuclear weapons can be made. Those countries increasingly are becoming aware of the terrible consequences of uranium being mined. May I in conclusion say that a well-known German magazine, Der Spiegel, quoted in a current issue an unnamed American scientist as saying:
If I had the total US civil defence budget of $US120m at my disposal I would spend it on painkilling morphia injections.
That is what this Government, with its assistance to and encouragement of the nuclear industry, is making Australia responsible for.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 December 1980, on motion by Senator Evans:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melzer Sen J.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly on this report of the Joint Committee on Public Works. Over the years that I have been a member of the Public Works Committee I have found the Committee in essence to be what in my opinion governments really should be about. The Committee is a watchdog. It is a committee that asks Departments to prove that the project for which they are seeking approval is necessary; that the project is accepted by the community; that the project is of a cost that is in keeping with the necessity for the project and that the money of the people of Australia that is to be spent on the project will be spent in a proper way. The Committee makes departments commit themselves to a project and show that it has a real worth in the community and is really needed. As I said, I think that is what governments really should be about. By now the Public Works Committee has a vast knowledge of the needs of the community because all its hearings are public and it encourages the public to come to the hearings, comment, complain, listen and find out what is being done with its money. In some ways I think that is the essence of democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that over the years I have found that some government departments are quite arrogant about the projects they put before the Committee and arrogant about their role in government. Some departments tend to treat committees such as the Public Works Committee with arrogance and scorn, believing that they really understand what the community needs.
