The Public Works Committee, being made up of a vast range of people from the Parliament, who come from all walks of life and who have done all sorts of jobs in the community, are probably more representative of the community than people in any government department could be. Parliamentarians bring the knowledge that they have gained over the years to such hearings and test government departments, making them accountable for what they put up and for the way in which they spend the people's money. Over the years I have found some of these departments quite arrogant in the way they front up. Fortunately, they very soon find out that members of parliament have a real concern for their constituents and for the way in which public moneys are spent.

Perhaps matters often come to the Committee too late. It has been of great concern to members of the Committee over the years that when departments put forward a proposition to the Committee often it is a fait accompli because the planning stage has gone so far with so much money spent that really the members of the Committee cannot, in all conscience, say: 'We do not consider it a good project. We do not think it is worth while. We do not think you have designed it properly. Go back to the drawing board or scrap the idea altogether.' It has seemed to many of us on the Public Works Committee over the years that if propositions were put up as an idea, perhaps with some rough sketches giving a rough idea of the project as the architect and the Department saw it, it would be much more sensible and realistic for the Committee to view it at that stage. At that stage the Committee could look at the project and decide without any pressure whether the scheme was worth while. If the scheme were not then there would be very little lost but if it were found to be worth while then it could be sent back to the Department and developed properly along lines strongly suggested by the Committee.

One matter that came before the Committee that concerned members deeply for a range of reasons was the proposed Casey military university. That project came before us after many thousands of dollars had been spent on developing the idea. Despite the pressure on us to acknowledge that the project had gone a long way down the track, in that instance the Committee refused to accept that the university was necessary at all. Finally, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) overrode us and said that the university would be built. If our recommendation had been accepted and the construction of the University had not been proceeded with we would still have wasted thousands and thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money in getting the project to the stage at which it came to the Public Works Committee.

I hope that the Public Works Committee goes on to take a stronger role when it comes to approving government projects. I hope that the time will come when all government projects, right across the board, no matter how much they cost, will come before the Committee for scrutiny. It does not always matter how much a project costs but it does matter whether it is a proper way in which to spend the people's money. Sometimes a project costing $5m can be put forward in a most economical way and can cover a need that is very apparent in the community. In other cases a department might waste $200,000 on a project which is absolutely absurd and quite unnecessary. In acknowledging the role that the Public Works Committee has played up to this point I hope that the Committee's work can be expanded because I think that it will only be to the good of this Parliament and the people of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the question asked of me earlier this day by Senator McAuliffe concerning accommodation for the Parliamentary Library, I advise that I have made reference to this matter in the Senate on a number of occasions, including major statements on 30 August 1979, 28 February 1980 and 18 September 1980. In addition, as most honourable senators would know, I have answered numerous questions at hearings of Estimates Committee A over recent years. To the best of my knowledge an assurance to the effect that the Parliament would be consulted prior to the making of decisions on accommodation has not been given by me. I did however give Senator McLaren an assurance on 29 August 1980 during a hearing of Estimates Committee A that 'no major determinations on locations will be made before the Parliament reassembles'. This was a reference to reassembling after the 1980 election. That assurance has of course been honoured.

INTERJECT.PARA: I might add that, as foreshadowed in my statement of 18 September 1980, I have established an advisory Senate Accommodation Committee to assist me in the consideration of possible solutions for accommodation problems in Parliament House. The Speaker has established a similar House of Representatives committee.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Allandale Geriatric Hospital-Parliament House: Air Conditioning System

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The rising cost of public hospitals is a matter of serious concern to us in this place. These rising costs are reflected in higher medical care costs to all Australian families. Of course, this Parliament is concerned to the extent at least of funds it appropriates that go to the hospital system. How is that money spent? Are spending priorities right and to what extent should that concern us here? I want to narrow the subject down and speak particularly of conditions obtaining to the largest geriatric hospital in New South Wales and one of the largest in Australia. I refer to the Allandale Hospital in Cessnock, which has almost 500 inmates and which is controlled by the Health Commission of New South Wales. During a visit to Allandale Hospital on 11 February last I was appalled to find myself in scenes which might have been taken straight from the pages of Charles Dickens, a place in which helpless old people, formerly hard working and presumably respectable and decent citizens of this country now live in daily conditions of unnecessary hardship, discomfort and indignity. I did not raise the matter publicly at that time, although in fact the Australian Democrats were campaigning for a State by-election, because I hoped that I might obtain improvements by communicating with the New South Wales Minister for Health, the Honourable Kevin Stewart. I wrote to him on 13 February as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: As you will know, Allandale was built originally as a psychiatric hospital and has been adapted to its present purpose. During the visit I made on 11 February, certain difficulties seemed very apparent. The average age of the occupants is 82; very many of them are incontinent and a high proportion of them have dementia. The challenge to nursing staff in day-to-day dealings is very considerable. Because of this a case could perhaps be made for the best possible conditions to assist them. In many areas the hospital has a heavy odour problem, which is unfortunate from the point of view of staff and the elderly patients, to whom I believe the community owes as much comfort and dignity as is reasonably possible for their final years.
I am not at all convinced that this is the case at present, but it would appear that some modest alterations could change the situation a great deal.
Specific points would include the following:
A. Provision of exhaust fans in wards, and especially bathrooms.

B. Replacement of the present vinyl tile floors, which have been laid throughout the hospital, with impervious vinyl sheeting. This measure alone would alleviate what is now an almost impossible hygiene problem.

C. Provision of chairs with coverings impervious to body fluids and designed to provide the best comfort and support for that group of patients who obviously and urgently need this. I gather that these patients who might be in bed through much of the day cannot be so located because of the low staffing of the hospital.
D. Some redesign of bathroom and water closets so that nurses are more able to assist patients. More space is needed.
E. Provision of better bathroom facilities.

Partly due to its design faults the hospital would also appear even to have an acute staffing problem. I understand a staff ceiling has been applied as policy and I am only too well aware of the financial problems that have caused this.
However with respect I suggest that Allandale might be a special case, due to the difficulty of design and the very considerable degree of attention nursing staff must give to the patients.
As the average age of the patient increases these problems must also increase.
May I say at this stage that it was plain to me that the staff at the hospital are doing a magnificent job, which is well deserving of community commendation.
I received no reply to that letter, so on 13 March I wrote again to the Minister as follows:
May I please have a reply to my letter of 13 February 1981.

It is now 2 April and I have had no response from the Minister. As a senator for New South Wales I have a direct and personal responsibility to my constituents, and these include the patients at Allandale hospital. I am raising this matter here tonight in the hope that an enlightened and indignant public opinion in New South Wales might see, if they know the facts, that something is done. As I said, I admire and respect the work being done by the nursing staff at Allandale, fine selfless work under the worst of conditions. The matter is made even worse because relatively small expenditure could transform this place. Continuous impervious flooring, air conditioning, even exhaust fans in the wards and especially in the bathrooms, would make a tremendous difference. This expenditure has been denied by a State Government which saw fit during that same series of by-elections to give funds to provide an ethnic club in nearby Maitland with air conditioning. Cessnock is regarded as a safe Labor seat, which is bad news for everybody who lives there.

I refer again to the question of the flooring at Allandale because it is vital. The vinyl tiles have thousands of crevices and cracks between them, as such things normally do when they are laid. In spite of the best efforts, they make it impossible to keep the hospital clean, in conditions where people, incontinent through age and no fault of their own, are living. This results in the terrible odour and insanitary conditions which pervade large areas of the hospital and which I have experienced personally and which both patients and staff are expected to endure continuously. A young person who accompanied me on that inspection said: 'If ever I have seen anything that would turn me off being old it is what I saw at Allandale'.

Further indignity and discomfort results for nurses and patients from small bathroom cubicles in which it is almost impossible for nurses to help patients clean themselves. In these bathrooms hot, humid and stinking conditions-I could use no less a word-persist because of the lack of proper ventilation that a few exhaust fans, which could be provided at small cost, would alleviate. Most pitiful of all is the plight of very old, senile patients, most of them old ladies, who are daily taken out of bed in the morning and propped up for the day in chairs in which they sit lolling like rag dolls. They are not allowed to go back to bed when they feel tired because there are not enough nurses to carry out this work. It is a fact, I understand, that the Health Minister, Mr Stewart, imposed staff ceilings on Allandale. It is a sad sight to see these old people propped in chairs which give them no degree of comfort or support. Furthermore, the chairs are not impervious to body fluids and because of this are constantly soaked in them. Here again, small amounts of expenditure would mean that these old people, who surely should have some expectations of the community, could have comfort and dignity in their last days.

I speak of these matters with distaste and I am sure that honourable senators must hear them with distaste. Yet it is vitally important that I raise them. It goes against my conscience that people of decent and honourable antecedents should have to tolerate these conditions. If anything else goes against my conscience it is merely that I have held my hand in this matter for as long as I have. Old and senile people do not have appreciable voting power. Is this the cynical basis for the degree of neglect and pinchpenny methods that one sees in the Allandale hospital? While at Cessnock I visited the prison there. It is fair to say that in many respects prisoners serving sentences for violent crimes are treated better than the old people in neighbouring Allandale. What more cruel and unjust irony could there be than that?

There is growing evidence that this whole area of hospitals for old people needs careful re-examination and planning and a degree of en- lightened concern on the part of governments. Such hospitals ought to be planned properly and built for their purpose. They should have the best possible facilities for caring for the senile and incontinent since this is an arduous, difficult nursing job at any time. Well-planned geriatric hospitals should have at least three clear categories of care-one for the senile, another for hostel-type accommodation for more self-sufficient patients, and another for adequate domiciliary extension services for those who wish to remain as long as possible in their homes. I hope that these things will come with time. Meanwhile, I suggest to men and women of good will in New South Wales and elsewhere that there is a responsibility to see that the deficiences of places such as Allandale are cleaned up. That at least would be a necessary beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter which I believe to be of great concern to members of the Senate. It concerns reports in the media this evening of an organism known colloquially as legionnaires disease circulating in parts of Parliament House. One understands, and one is basing one's remarks only on media reports, that following the severe and recurrent illnesses to which, as we all know, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been subject in the past year or so, certain tests have taken place in the region of his suite and in particular in the air conditioning and surrounds, to try to establish whether any disease organism is present which may be an explanatory factor in those illnesses.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the understanding of many of us that a disease organism known colloquially as legionnaires disease has been isolated in the area of the air conditioning in the Prime Minister's suite. If that is the case, certain questions immediately arise. When it is stated, as it has been, that the disease organism has been isolated there, does it merely mean identified there, or isolated and held there? What tests have taken place in the air conditioning throughout the building? What tests have taken place in areas of the building other than the air conditioning? More importantly, I believe, why is it that parliamentarians and those who work here were not informed that this series of tests took place or of the results of those tests until apparently they were leaked to the media? Not only are some 200 parliamentarians who disperse at the end of each week to various parts of Australia in some sort of danger, if not to themselves then perhaps by spreading this disease when they return to their home bases, but also those members of staff who are constantly working within this building, and there are many hundreds of them, seem to be in even graver danger. It seems to me, and no doubt to other honourable senators, unpardonable that parliamentarians and those who work within this building have not been kept informed of this series of tests or of any results from such tests.

Perhaps no assurance can be given by you, Mr President, that it is safe for those who work in this building to return to it next week, but at least I ask that you make contact with our offices on Monday, or perhaps even tomorrow, to inform us of any facts which are at your disposal and which I believe ought to have been put at your disposal and that of the parliament much earlier than this, to allay the fears. If those fears cannot be allayed, perhaps you could tell us what steps ought to be taken so that those of us who return from interstate and those who work within the building are not subjected to some risk of a severe and, at times, fatal disease. I think that I would not be going too far to suggest that there has been some dereliction of duty on the part of those who have been involved in this series of tests in not informing the Parliament of what was going on. I hope, Mr President, that you will pursue that matter also.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I had no knowledge of this matter prior to the honourable senator referring to the media reports a little while ago. I will make inquiries regarding the matter and take heed of what the honourable senator has requested. At the present time I have no knowledge of it.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.29 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Departmental policy of non involvement in communities without secure land tenure is causing drastic hardship to at least three Kimberley Aboriginal communities, viz., Gordon Downs in the East Kimblerley, Warringari Community at Muludja near Fitzroy Crossing, and the Kroonull community on Christmas Creek also near Fitzroy; if so, will the Minister review this policy, particularly in respect of important commodities such as vehicles, store services and water supplies.

(2) What action has the Minister undertaken to obtain land for communities without secure land tenure, such as those referred to in (1), especially through excisions from pastoral leases as recommended by the Gibb Committee (Committee to Review the Situation of Aborigines on Pastoral Leases in the Northern Territory) in December 1971.
(3) What action, if any, has the Minister undertaken to provide community schools for these and other Aboriginal communities which request them.

(4) Has the Minister investigated claims by the Kimberley Land Council that the management of the Gordon Downs station is endeavouring to starve the Aboriginal community off the station; if so, has the Minister taken any action in respect of these claims. (5) Does the Minister support the view of the Court Government that no more land in Western Australia should be transferred to Aboriginal control; if not, given that constitutional powers in respect of Aboriginals now reside with the Commonwealth, what does the Minister propose to do about it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There is no ''Departmental policy on non-involvement in communities without secure land tenure.'' Where Aboriginal communities are living on land which is held as leasehold by another person, any buildings or other fixed improvements provided with Commonwealth Government grants would become the property of the leaseholder and not of the community. This was one of the major considerations leading to the recommendations of the Gibb Committee in 1971 that suitable land on pastoral properties should be subleased, or excised and leased, to Aboriginal communities. Where leases of community areas have not been provided, applications for assistance can still be considered by the Department and there is no obstacle to the provision of grants for such things as vehicles and radios, where this is appropriate.

The Gordon Downs community has recently decided not to return to the Gordon Downs pastoral lease, but to settle on land at Yaruman (Ringer's Soak) which has been temporarily reserved for the purpose. Details of a grant to help the group to resettle at the site are being worked out.

The Warringari group is camped on the Go Go pastoral lease, although members have links with the Fossil Downs station. One area on Go Go station has already been excised and a housing program for the Bayula community there is in progress. The lessees of Go Go are unwilling to consider a second excision from the lease for the Warringari group. The lessees of Fossil Downs are prepared to negotiate but there have been problems in finding a site on Fossil Downs satisfactory to the group and not subject to flooding.

Similarly at Christmas Creek station one area has been excised and a housing program is underway there, but some of the people living on the station have left that area and moved to another site some 19 kilometres away. I am informed that an application by this group, the Kroonull community, to the Aboriginal Development Commission for help in obtaining land is being considered by the Commission.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is continuing to review the needs of all Aboriginal groups living on pastoral properties in the Northern Territory and in Western Australia and to advise and help communities which are seeking to negotiate the provision of land by way of sub-leases or excisions.

(3) The provision of schools is primarily a responsibility of the relevant State or Northern Territory Government. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs provides advice and assistance to any community seeking the provision of a local school and has provided funds for independent Aboriginal community schools in Western Australia at Noonkanbah, Strelley, Lake Gnangara and Coolgardie.
(4) The Aboriginal group living at Gordon Downs left the station early in January and, as indicated above, has decided to resettle at Yaruman rather than returning to the station.

(5) The Western Australian Minister for Lands has been reported as saying that the embargo imposed last year on the transfer of leasehold land to Aboriginal groups has been lifted. The Minister has confirmed this in a message to the Aboriginal Development Commission stating that the Western Australian Government is prepared to consider the transfer of pastoral leases to Aboriginal communities subject to the merits and particular circumstances of each case.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost of relocation of the Aboriginal population at Lake Nash Station in the Northern Territory to the Bathurst Downs area.
(2) What facilities exist for the Aboriginal people at their present location, near the Lake Nash homestead.
(3) What facilities will be provided at the proposed new site at Bathurst Downs.
(4) Has an adequate water supply been found at Bathurst Downs.
(5) Has fencing been commenced around the Bathurst Downs site.
(6) How much money has been spent on the relocation to 19 February 1981.
(7) What evidence does the Minister have that the Aboriginal people wish to move to Bathurst Downs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Northern Territory Department of the Chief Minister has indicated that the relocation of the Lake Nash community is dependent on the location of a suitable supply of potable water and no firm estimate of cost can be made until this has been achieved.
(2) There are no permanent facilities for Aboriginals at Lake Nash, except an ablution block and a school building (recently damaged by storm) and staff housing.
(3) Detailed planning for the provision of facilities at a new location will begin consultation with the community when a satisfactory water supply has been established.
(4) No. Three bores have yielded unpotable water. Feasibility of desalination is being examined.
(5) Yes.
(6) $36,000 has been spent on water drilling and $31,542 on fencing.

(7) At a meeting on 12 February 1980 of the Lake Nash Aboriginal community with Northern Territory Government and Department of Aboriginal Affairs representatives, a Central Land Council field officer and the Lake Nash station manager, agreement was reached on the area to which the community would relocate. There have been discussions with community representatives since then and there has been no indication that they have altered their views about the move.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was a station owner at Urapunga paid $5,000 by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to provide power to the local Aboriginal people, if so, when was payment made.
(2) Has the power been provided as agreed, if so, when did this occur.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department made a grant of $5,000 to the Rittaranga Community Association, the Aboriginal group resident on Urapunga Station, to allow it to make a contribution towards the costs of providing a power supply on a cost-sharing basis for the three consumers on the station-i.e. station management, education staff and the Rittaranga community. The amount was paid on 4 May 1979, although the transfer of responsibility for essential services to the Northern Territory Government from my Department was effected on 1 July 1978. This action was taken pending clarification with the Northern Territory Government of the responsibility for essential services for Aboriginals on pastoral properties.

(2) No. I am informed that problems have arisen in the implementation of the original cost-sharing agreement. The Northern Territory Department of Community Development, which has assumed responsibility for essential services, is now dealing with the matter and examining the overall power supply requirements for the station. I understand that a meeting of the parties concerned will be held soon at Urapunga to resolve the issues involved. In the meantime, my Department is seeking reimbursement from the station owner of the $5,000 originally provided. The cost of providing the power supply will now be borne by the Northern Territory Government which has responsibility for essential services on Aboriginal communities including Aboriginals residing on stations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many apparent breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in relation to the authorisation of electoral advertisements were brought to the Commonwealth Electoral Office's attention immediately prior to or following the 1980 Federal election.
(2) Did subsequent investigations produce satisfactory explanations in some cases; if so, what was the general nature of those explanations.
(3) How many alleged breaches have been referred: (a) for further investigation; (b) for legal advice; and (c) to the courts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) In respect of 18 October 1980 elections, the Australian Electoral Office received some 26 complaints alleging breaches of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in relation to the authorisation of electoral advertisements.

In respect of 11 such complaints the Office received satisfactory explanations in the sense that after each case had been considered on its merits-having regard to the nature of the breach, the explanation of how and why it occurred, and where appropriate, the steps taken to rectify it-the Office did not consider it necessary to institute court proceedings against the persons concerned.
Of the remainder, 3 complaints clearly did not, in fact, involve a breach of the relevant provisions of the Act and 12 were referred for legal advice and/or further investigation.

Court proceedings have not been instituted in respect of any of the matters in which legal advice has been received and/or the investigations have been completed. The investigations into four complaints are still proceeding.
For obvious reasons I do not propose to make available details of the replies received in those cases in which the Australian Electoral Office has declined to prosecute.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government, either by inclusion in the next census or by other means of enquiry, review the population statistics of Aboriginal people, region by region, living in the States and Territories to determine population trends so as to enable authorities to plan, in the short and long term, in regard to health, welfare, education, housing and employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The national census every five years provides figures on the Aboriginal population by States and local government areas and these are available to the authorities responsible for health, welfare, education, housing and employment in the States and the Northern Territory. The Department of Aboriginal Affairs also prepares and publishes short-term projections of population growth based on census figures (see Department of Aboriginal Affairs Statistical Section Newsletter No. 9). Population statistics are used by the Department in reviewing the allocation of resources to Aboriginal programs in the States and Territories and in planning the provision of services for Aboriginal people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Young Sen H.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Mawson's Hut, built in the Antarctic by the late Sir Douglas Mawson during his expedition in 1911-1914, deteriorating badly and does it require a lot of repairs.

(2) Is the hut a long way from any manned research station and able to be seen by very few people, if so, will the Government consider bringing the hut back to Adelaide, Sir Douglas's home town, where it could be restored and kept in a sheltered place available for all Australians to see.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Mawson's Hut is situated at Commonwealth Bay which is 120 km from the nearest manned research station, France's Dumont D'urville in the Terre Adelie Sector, and 1400 km from Casey, the nearest Australian station.

In January/February 1978 a party from the Antarctic Division visited Commonwealth Bay to inspect Mawson's Hut, to assess the feasibility of returning it to Australia and to do some restoration work. The party found that the condition of the hut reflected the severe weather conditions it has had to withstand. They reported that the outer timbers had been reduced to half their original thickness and had shrunk leaving gaps between the boards. The inner and main timbers were generally in good condition, however some repairs and replacement would be necessary.
The party recommended that because of the condition of the hut and the variable weather conditions no attempt should be made to return it to Australia and that it should be restored on site.
The arguments leading to a decision to leave the hut in situ are:

The high probability that the hut will be destroyed in the process of dismantling. The foundations and floor are encased in solid ice and due to limited access time it is not possible to free the hut of this ice in the course of a single season;

Even if the foundations and floor were abandoned it would not be possible to dismantle the remainder in a single season, bearing in mind the need to exercise extreme care to minimise damage, the time required to number and pack removed timbers and the time required to ensure the residual portion would not fill with snow and ice or be blown away in the ensuing twelve months. (As a point of interest, winds of up to 200 knots have been experienced at Commonwealth Bay);
The hut has been declared an Antarctic historic monument and it is the general practice of Antarctic Treaty nations, of which Australia is one, to leave their nominated historical monuments in situ;
The voyages of Sir Douglas Mawson were the basis of Australia's claims in the Antarctic and the Commonwealth Bay hut forms an integral part of those explorations; and

The Committee of Inquiry into the National Estate considered the dismantling and removal of an historic building to another site in order to save it as a 'procedure of last resort . . . an admission of failure to preserve an authentic environment' (Paragraph 4.113 of the Committee's report).

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 December 1980 (Hansard, page 337) Senator Tate asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the practice of some employers of opening the mail addressed to employees at their place of work. This is of particular concern to union officials written to in that capacity, and general concern to employees whose correspondents may know of their place of work but not their private address. Will the Minister consider making a statement or requesting Australia Post to advertise the fact that such opening of mail is almost certainly illegal and definitely improper?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:
Complaints of this nature have been raised with Australia Post on a number of occasions in the past.

It is appreciated that the opening by employers of mail addressed to employees at their place of work can cause concern to employees, particularly those who receive mail in their capacity as union officials. However, Commonwealth legislative provisions concerning opening of mail relate only to interference with articles in the course of postal transmission. There are no Commonwealth laws relating to opening of mail after postal delivery has been effected.

As far as Australia Post is concerned, the different methods of effecting delivery of mail are set down in the Postal By-laws and include delivery through private bag or private box. There is no requirement for a postal article to be handed personally to the addressee. Indeed such a requirement would be quite unworkable in the context of providing a national postal service.
In these circumstances the statement requested at least in its suggested reference to illegality would be incorrect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 February 1981 (Hansard, page 147) Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry a question without notice concerning the facilities and staff at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands animal quarantine station.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney subsequently referred the question to the Minister for Health who has provided the following information:

The animal quarantine station being established on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands incorporates the latest advances in animal husbandry. Full consideration was given to animal welfare during design and the station will include a number of special features aimed at ensuring the comfort and welfare of the animals. These include: Spot cooling to each animal pen and a system of flow-through ventilation to ensure that animals are not unduly stressed by the hot climate; rubberised bedding surface which will minimise foot soreness and joint problem; a slat flooring system in animal pens which facilitates removal of animal waste and reduces temperature, humidity and odour problems; covered stockyard, walkways and exercise areas to prevent animals being exposed to tropical sun; fully equipped laboratory facilities to enable diagnosis of intercurrent diseases together with isolation pens and surgery facilities; pasture areas to ensure supplies of fodder balanced with pelletised feeds imported from the mainland; pens having design parameters allowing almost twice the floor space per beast as is normally accepted by Australian agricultural authorities.

The station will have a total of nine staff, six of whom will be experienced in handling large animals. These will include two senior veterinarians, a Senior Stock Inspector and three Stock Inspectors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 March 1981 (Hansard, page 241), Senator Harradine asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the level of medical benefits in Tasmania for obstetric services.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The fees for medical benefits purposes listed in the current Medical Benefits Schedule have their origin in a list of common fees submitted as being fair and reasonable to the Government by the Australian Medical Association in 1970. The list of fees was adopted as the basis of the new medical benefits arrangements introduced on 1 July 1970.

The State surveys which led to the setting of common fees indicated that the fees charged in certain States often varied from those charged in other States. Since then, the levels of Schedule fees for medical benefit purposes have been adjusted following an independent enquiry by the Medical Fees Tribunal in 1973 and a number of subsequent independent enquiries. To an extent these differences in fees among the States have been maintained.

The Government considers that any move from different State fee levels towards uniform fee levels has to be based on substantial arguments, largely related to parity of practice costs and not incomes. Further, the Government considers that moves towards uniform fees should not increase the overall costs of medical benefits to the community and hence uniform fees would not be acceptable if they were on the basis of lifting the lower fees for some States to the level of the highest fees in another State. This policy has been followed by the Government in fees enquiries and has been ratified in the determination of those enquiries.

To date, information about medical practice costs and incomes provided by the medical profession has not been sufficiently detailed or representative to demonstrate that there should be further moves to uniform fee levels among the States. I might add that the Government's requirements have been made clearly known to the Australian Medical Association over a number of years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the following document, which was included in 'An Inside Dopester's Index of One Hundred Examples of Secrecy', an appendix to the book 'Secrecy: Political Censorship in Australia' by Jim Spigelman (Angus and Robertson, Sydney, 1972), now been published: No. 31-Central Testing and Research Laboratories tests of anti-corrosive coatings.
(2) Has the above-mentioned document now otherwise been made available.
(3) If the document has so far not been made available, would the Government now be prepared to make it available either unconditionally or on any, and if so what, conditions.
(4) If the Government is not prepared to make the document available, why does it continue to refuse to make it available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Central Investigation and Research Laboratory Report titled 'Exposure Tests on Some Anti-corrosive Coatings for the Protection of Steel' has never been published. It is an internal Department of Housing and Construction Report which is updated every six months.

(2) The Report is circulated on a Commercial-in-Confidence basis throughout the Department of Housing and Construction for use in its design, construction and maintenance operations. Copies are also made available on the same basis to Commonwealth Departments and Authorities with an interest in anti-corrosive coatings and to those State Government Departments and Authorities represented on the Government Paint Committee.
(3) and (4) The Department of Housing and Construction would not be prepared to make the Report generally available.
The Report is neither comprehensive nor applicable to all circumstances.

It covers only products of interest to the Department of Housing and Construction (perhaps 20 per cent of commercially available commercial coatings) and deals only with properties and conditions of major concern to the Department.
Testing is not necessarily to a national or recognised standard and the results of tests require experienced and professional interpretation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 24 February 1981 the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister or his Department circulated detailed drafts of proposed plant breeders' rights legislation and an Information Paper of the implications of the draft legislation to the seed trade industry.
(2) Does the Minister propose to make such information available to environmental and community interest groups; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Draft Bills are confidential until they have been approved by the Government and presented to the Parliament. Accordingly, detailed drafts of the proposed Plant Variety Rights legislation have not been circulated to the seed trade industry or to any other groups or persons. In fact the drafting process has not as yet been completed.

In mid 1979 an early working paper in the format of a Bill was made available for discussion, and change, at a meeting in Canberra of representatives of Commonwealth and State governments and the three industry organisations which initially proposed a Plant Variety Rights Scheme for Australia. As a result of this meeting and subsequent discussions at meetings of the Australian Agricultural Council, a substantial number of amendments have been made to the scheme as originally proposed in the working paper. These changes are reflected in the proposed legislation.
An information paper on plant variety rights in Australia was prepared by my Department and copies are available for distribution to anyone, including members of the seed trade industry.

(2) The information paper referred to in (1) is available for distribution to environmental and community interest groups. A substantial number has already been distributed in response to requests received from such groups.

Further, it is the Government's intention to introduce the Bill during the current sitting of Parliament and to allow it to remain on the table without debate until the Budget Sitting later in the year. During this period it will be a public document and available for examination by interested persons or organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: In the years 1977-78, 1978-79 and 1979-80: (a) how many appeals against decisions of the Department of Social Security were lodged with the Department; (b) how many were finalised; (c) how many were conceded without reference to Social Security Appeals Tribunals; (d) in how many cases did the Tribunal recommend in the appellant's favour; (e) how many were upheld or partly upheld by the Director-General or State directors; (f) how many were rejected by them; and (g) what percentage of favourable recommendations from the Tribunals were rejected by the Director-General or the State directors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The required statistics are provided in the table below:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 February 1981 (Hansard, pages 13 and 14) Senator Melzer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the withdrawal from sale of tampons associated with cases of toxic shock syndrome. The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: Extensive laboratory tests conducted under the auspices of the National Health and Medical Research Council by leading Australian research institutions on all brands of tampons sold in Australia have now been completed. The tests have investigated the chemical composition of tampons and the possibility of contamination with Staphylococcus aureus, the pathogenic organism which has been shown to be associated with toxic shock syndrome. Special attention has been paid to Carefree Super, the brand associated with the first two diagnosed Australian cases; examples of this product of both Australian and New Zealand origin were examined.

No unusual features were found in the chemical components and only one variety of tampon, Tampax Super Plus, was found to contain the chemical additive carboxy-methyl-cellulose. However, this material does not now appear to play a significant role in the causation of the disease.
It is of particular significance that comprehensive bacteriological testing has failed to confirm the presence of Staphylococcus aureus in any unused product sold in this country.

During the course of test procedures consultation has been maintained with health authorities in the United States, New Zealand and other countries. The results we have obtained here have been in close agreement with the findings in these countries. There is, therefore, no valid scientific reason for continuation of the voluntary withdrawal from sale of Carefree Super brand tampons of New Zealand origin which was imposed following the diagnosis of the first two Australian cases. Neither is there any evidence to support the more general withdrawal from sale of other tampon brands. The two subsequent cases have been associated with tampons other than Carefree Super.

My Department is completing discussions with manufacturers and importers of tampons and arrangements are being made for comprehensive ongoing surveillance of tampon quality and hygiene. Matters under discussion included inspection of manufacturing facilities, codes of good manufacturing practice, standards for tampons, revision of package inserts and the placing of warning and ingredient labels on outer packages.
On 5 March 1981 I issued a news release on the results of investigations into causes of this disease.

The Chairman of the National Health and Medical Research Council has also issued a press statement stressing the necessity for a high standard of personal hygiene in the use of tampons, and recommending appropriate precautions to reduce the risk of tampon associated toxic shock.
In addition to the industrial surveillance I have outlined, Australian scientific research and consultation and co-operation with health authorities at an international level will continue.
